The Venice Canals Historic District is a part of Venice in Los Angeles. Tobacco millionaire developer Abbot Kinney built these canals in line with his vision of recreating Venice in Southern California. A little known fact about Kinney is that apart from being a developer, he also was a conservationist!The lighted canals with arched bridges and gondolas with gondoliers actually imported from Venice, helped Kinney sell property lots in this newly developed area. Apart from their novelty, the canals were also meant as aquatic arteries to connect the residential community.Sadly however, as with many other things in the US, the Venice Canals too became a casualty to the rising popularity of automobiles. Built in 1905, most of the canals had been filled in by 1929 to make way for roads. By 1940 the canals and the walkways running by their side had fallen into abject disrepair, the canal water contaminated with trash and debris.This state of affairs continued for the next four decades as numerous proposals to renovate the canals were debated and dropped for both environmental and financial reasons.Thankfully, the reincarnation of the Venice Canals did happen with new walkways and walls being constructed even as the canals were drained and refilled. The canals reopened in 1993 and this has since become an expensive residential area of Los Angeles.Completely removed from the chaos of Venice beach, the canals look beautiful and serene. There are walkways along both sides. Each canal is spanned by two or more picturesque footbridges. While they look similar, no two bridges are exactly the same.The bridges add to the quaint charm of the canals and serve as excellent vantage points to click some beautiful photographs. While the water could be cleaner, the rest of the landscape is restful, simply beautiful.Almost every house on the canals has a tiny pier and some form of kayak or rowboat to navigate the water. We even saw a person who was paddle boarding standing up!The chic houses lining the canals are very well maintained, some with exquisitely manicured gardens and many with comfortable outdoor seating and barbecue arrangements.No two homes are alike and each bears the distinct mark of its owner’s personality. Truly the good life, which I guess is the least you would expect for homes that cost north of a million dollars!While far removed from the boisterousness of Venice Beach, in style the canals too are as distinctly original. Set in the midst of a frenetically busy area, this here is a calm, quiet, serene world with egrets, ducks and pelicans to keep you company.

column3: I've moved to Venice twice, so there must have been some attraction, now some years ago. Somehow wealthy poseur hipsters have driven the home prices into the stratosphere. But here's what you really get: if you park on the street overnight, there's a high chance of it getting broken into. Just a mile away is a neighborhood where you might get killed in a driveby shooting. The canals are filthy and putrid. The sidewalks everywhere should have been regularly power-washed with bleach. Homeless and psychotic people are everywhere! And the beach itself is so broad and sandy that it's a trudge to get to the actual ocean. I wouldn't live there again for 1/10th the price. -- Oh, there are numerous nice restaurants within a few blocks on Main St. And the Venice beach promenade is an "entertaining" circus crush of people, worth seeing once. But go in the daytime where the police are everywhere on bicycles. And I wouldn't really take children there!

column2: Definitely not somewhere I would return to.
column3: I was super excited to be seeing the Venice Canals Walkway and was highly disappointed. There are some moments that are picturesque and some lovely homes, most if it just feels dirty and the water is foul. Some areas have quite a lot of trash and the whole area could do with a good scrub if it really wanted to attract tourists. Instagram photos of the area are VERY creative, its generally just dirty and I would never go again. Yuck.

We had a lovely stroll in this area, really enjoyed the different houses, gardens and canals. Intersting history how it all came about. Also had a few nice chats with some of the people living here. Well worth a visit!
You feel like you’ve been transported somewhere else when you’re walking along the canals. It’s so beautiful and perfect for a post brunch walk.

When visiting Venice you have to see two things. One is Venice Beach. The second is the famous canals of Venice. While touring this area be sure to check out the beautiful homes located on the canals.
If you are in Venice Beach make sure you take a stroll on the walkways. So much beauty to see and lots to do in the area.

This is a lovely area to walk in. Must be amazing to live there! The canal area is very small and worth the hour or two of wandering around and admiring the many and varied homes located on the water.

The Venice canals walkway can be maintained better.It has stagnant water with over grown weeds.A few boats moored to the sides. The houses on either side are much prettier.It was nice to walk from one end to another.If the canal gets cleaned up,it will really be beautiful.
off the beach a bit, nice to walk around and see the pretty homes. i was just in venice so a bit similar.

column2: A unique little part of Venice - worth a stroll
column3: Much can be said about this unique little section of Venice. The thing to remember is that it is a stretch of homes you are walking through so I think one needs to recognize that the people living there must be feeling like they are on display at least half of the time. Having said that, it is a nice stroll walking between Marina Del Rey and Venice and you will see some fun and quirky details spread out. Go for sunrise or sunset and benefit from the nice light which will show off the area better.

column2: Not an area I'd visit again..........
column3: We thought it would be fun and interesting to walk the Venice Canals Walkway. NOT! While there are some interesting and a few beautiful homes along the canal, the canal itself is repugnant. The water was putrid and dirty, some areas of trash. Throughout the walkway, we encountered some interesting characters, bottle in a bag.... The walkways were filthy, looked like they long ago needed a steam cleaning. I'd never recommend going to this area.

This one pleasure to take in while in the Venice Beach area.A small section of homes away from the beach, between the areas of Venice Beach and Marina del Ray contain a series of watered canals instead of roads. It's a simple grid system and it's a little small, but it quite beautiful.It's a real nice peaceful oasis outside the bussel of cars and foot traffic. Appearances are also real good, as the real estate I am sure is pricey thus contributing to very well kept front yards, excellent walkways and clean surroundings. The water even looks quite nice too, and the little touch of small canoes and kayaks is a nice surprise.It doesn't seem functionally useful for anything, does it connect to a larger body of water? I am not so sure, but what's done or intended purpose is done. It's a nice piece of tranquility that is unexpected, and doesn't take much time to see or get too either. Very worthy stop.

I've come here a bunch of times and always see something different. It is peaceful and quiet and so I get into a meditative stroll up and down the waterways.Venice's motto is "keep Venice weird" and so it attracts a 'weird' element. This leads to Venice being a little loud, colorful, and a place for tourists to get taken for a ride. The canals are quite the opposite. They are still colorful, but they are quiet, and tourists and locals walk around here respectful of the area.Like all of Venice the area is clean, but because of the quietness it feels even cleaner here.
Nice to walk around the canals and see all the different houses. Very quiet area. Worth a visit if you like walking

column2: Beautiful, picturesque place for a stroll.
column3: The Venice Canals Walkway is a beautiful, picturesque for a stroll. There are some very cool homes along the canals and the gardens are gorgeous. It was a great to spend an hour or so.

column2: A Hidden Gem of Venice Beach
column3: We walked through the canal walkways on the Sunday of the Abbott-Kinney street festival. If no one had mentioned the canals we wouldn't have known they were there and had a great walk admiring the peaceful scenes of water, bridges, houses and gardens.Highly recommended!

column2: Beautiful tranquil location & close to Farmers Market on (on Fridays).
column3: Well worth a visit when in the Venice Beach area and if you go on a Friday, the nearby Farmers Market is a great place to pick up some yummy fresh produce.

This is a must see. I've been to this area at least three other times and did not know this existed. Great walking through the three to four streets seeing these canals. Make sure to wear comfortable shoes. Parking is very tricky, especially on warm weekends. I recommend going on a Monday through Friday while school is in session. Also try to arrive early. The bridge walking reminds me of Venice Italy!!!

column2: quiet way to pass the day
column3: we wanted up and down the canals and relived our youth and reminiss how it has changed since the 60's and 70's
Took a stroll one afternoon. Enjoyed seeing the hidden gem of Los Angeles.Lots of photo opportunities. Water was a bit dirty

We walked all along the canels and the views and homes are gorgeus. It is a must visit when coming to Venice. It has a long history and the beauty is breathtaking. It is the perfect stroll first thing in the morning or anytime. We love it everytime we visit

column2: I felt like I was on set with Hank Moody
column3: Loved the houses, all so different but have the same vibe of cosyness to them. This is definitely a must when visiting LA :)
Most people never see it.It's quite the contrast from Venice Beach Boardwalk.It's serene and beautiful on a nice day.
We didn't walk it but found the whole history and what views we did see interesting. Venice is worth a visit. The good news is there are more hippies than homeless.

I had never heard of the canals in Venice, CA until a recent visit. Our friend took us right to a few of the nicest spots and we had a lovely stroll. Many ducks were on the canal or the small docks. There were signs posted about keeping dogs on a leash and being careful to not disturb the nesting ducks. Some of the old, small cottages remain, but most have been replaced by large, new houses. We saw two homes with demolition notices posted. We were able to stroll along walkways by the canals to admire homes and gardens up close. The bridges across the canals make for nice photos.
Some of the canals are beautiful, others are filled with garbage and tents/shelters for the homeless and you can’t see anything but filth.
If we were not on a tour we would have never seen this. Very neat to see. If not for our tour guide we would have never known about these. Worth the time to go see.

A lot of little canals and beautiful houses. You almost feel like being in Venice, Italy. There are many walking bridges, and so many flowers. Very quiet place compared to Venice, Italy. Has to be seen at least once in your life.

have been wanting to check out the Venice Canals for a while now and a recent road trip weekend to SoCal seemed like the perfect time to do it! Venice Canals have been in soo many movies, just had to go see them for myself!We arrived right before sunset and it was just beautiful. The way the water reflective everything and the slight breeze. Walking along the canals are peaceful and not too crowded. Sometimes its nice to be off the beaten path and just walk and enjoy the scenery.Abbot Kinney, the developer of Venice, sought to recreate the appearance and feel of Venice Italy, and I have to say it does make you feel like you're away from the busy beach life and transported to another place. Jealous of those who get to call this place home.I can now say I have been to both Venice Canals.
So different from Venice beach, thankfully, delightfully decorated houses and little canals, picture perfect and a welcome break after Venice beach.
Not far from Venice Beach Pier, very elegant and peaceful neighborhood, historic building, fit for small group, family.

Venice Canals are like a different world from Venice beach. Very calm and peaceful. Interesting to walk around and look at all the different homes and gardens. I think it would have been nice to be able to rent canoes or paddleboats, but I suppose the neighbors may not think it would be especially nice. It is an easy walk from the Venice beach area.

column2: Hard to Find but Worth the Search
column3: Be sure you carefully follow your GPS because it's harder than you woudl think. It is such a beautiful and unique section of housing that you won't regret making it a priority.

column2: A magical spot for quiet, contemplative souls
column3: I'm almost reluctant to share about this spot as I wouldn't want it to get spoilt and overrun by tourists, though tourists do already frequent it, but I will, for anybody travelling to Venice who like me is a pretty quiet, nature-loving, meditative, contemplative soul as it is a lovely sanctuary in an otherwise fairly busy place.The canal walkway is a network of streets set along shallow canals. I have never seen a boat actually out on the canals though many of the homeowners have a boat or some sort of floating vehicle (swans and flamingos amongst other things) tied up to the little jetties that line the canals.It's very unique and very different. Venice itself has a very particular Bohemian flavour emphasising art and beauty with lots of little galleries and beautiful, unexpected street art all over the place and I would recommend just wandering around the place as you never know what you will find. The canal walkway carries on that theme but is that bit more serene and secluded and has a truly lovely vibe.There are many small, cute bridges you can stand on and take in the views, or cross over to the other side of the canal to look at whatever interests you and takes your eye.The houses lining the canal are unique, individual and many have interesting art or beautiful-smelling flowers adorning the tiny gardens.At the time of year I was there the whole area was populated by beautiful red butterflies, which were a joy to watch. For me it was a place where my soul felt calm and relaxed and I could spend an hour somewhere quiet just to contemplate or to sit and journal. It would be a dream come true to be able to afford a house there but I did really enjoy visiting and it's a place I will never forget.If you do visit please do so quietly so as not to spoil the vibe for those who live or holiday there and like-minded quiet-seeking visitors.
Love this aspect of Venice, I feel like I'm in Italy. If I could afford a house here, I would buy one. Very charming and relaxing to walk along the canals.

column2: A welcome relief from Venice Beach
column3: Really enjoyed walking around Venice Canals, partly property porn but also just a charming and relaxing relief from the craziness of Venice Beach.

Walked along the "Grand Canal" as part of a 'Secret Food Tour." Did not know that the canals are flooded by sea water at high tide, that properties go for $5M+ (but you've got to be able to stand a constant stream of tourists looking in your front room!). An interesting place for a 'less than hour' walk.

I live in Guyana, South America with its many canals, rivers, streams, famous waterfalls and rain forests and as I walked through the area I wished that with our riches from our natural resources that we could beautify our country in these spectacular ways. Lovely.

As you're walking those loud main streets in Venice and you suddenly make a turn into the canals, you find a complete 180 in noise level and tranquility. I do recommend taking a stroll in the Venice Canals, you get to admire all the pretty houses and get some cardio in.
When visiting Venice beach, it's worth taking a stroll around the canals too. They are very pretty and with cute little houses surrounding them.

I missed seeing the venice canals last time i stayed in Venice in February. I came here with another woman I met staying at my air B&B and I’m so glad i got to explore this area of Venice. I was going to go on a tour here but its really unnecessary to go on a tour its a lot of walking and taking photos. Its very beautiful the area with picture perfect photos of walking bridges and flowers wildlife etc. It reminded me of Amsterdam and Venice Italy of course but a more quiet tranquil place to walk and enjoy the afternoon,morning or night. I went in the afternoon it was hot and I must say its not a place to swim. However, I did see people standing in the water but I wouldn’t recommend it because water is murky and probably isn’t the best water to swim or get in. I do say this is a must see in the area to experience. There is a duck park there that you can feed the ducks too and a play ground next to it if you have children with you.

I love this area! Movies have been filmed here and it’s just a really neat vibe. That said, as much as I love walking around here, I’m cognizant that this is in the middle of people’s homes. Please watch out for traffic on the little bridges. And keep noise to a minimum so the area keeps allowing us to walk there. It’s a quite little area tucked back in a chaotic town.

We enjoyed our walk through the Venice Canals area. We were there mid-morning so it was quiet and we didn't feel like we were intruding on the homeowners, as some of the other reviewers have felt. It is well worth a visit if you are in the Venice area.

Talk about a photo opportunity.This is a breathtaking place that is kind of hidden.Small homes line the canals and bridges connect you from one side to the other.It is beautiful.The Doors loved to spend time here.So will you.George Vreeland Hill
One must visit this exceptional place at least once in their lifetime. So romantic.. So alluring.. Remarkably exquisite. I am going there agaon soon

column2: went here to have dinner with a friend, great!!!
column3: there is so many different things to see. if you are in the area you must go here to see the sites. you won't believe it until you see it !!!
Just ok - the locals keep the area looking nice. Many of the canals were lacking water and looked almost empty.

Not so far from Venice Beach, you can find this neighborhood with canals, little bridges and quiet environment with some tourist walking around. Not sure I would want to live where people wander around to enjoy the views and quietness, but as tourist it is welcome break from the crowds and noise.

If you're in the Venice area, this is a nice place for a stroll. It's a pretty and quiet part of the area. The "canals" aren't that deep at all. Maybe a foot (depends on rainfall I suppose). The walkways are right alongside the homes which if I lived there might annoy me with all these tourists walking by. Some of the bridges do allow for cars so keep an eye out.

column2: Walk This Way to the Walkway
column3: Nice wee walk looking at the different styles of homes on this Walkway.Calling it a "canal" is stretching it a bit, as there was very little water. More algae and weeds, but under better conditions, this would be a good photo op.

Its a good place to walk if you love walking along with canals. If you have seeing these type of things many times, it is not a place for you to visit. I would think this place is ordinary place, if you are from a place where rich folks stay all around the world.

We wandered the canal walkways very happily for an hour or so and enjoyed looking at the individual homes that line them. A very interesting section of Venice away from the business elsewhere. Recommend that you step off the tourist treadmill and explore this area.

column2: Beautiful walk - perfect place to bring visitors
column3: Perfect activity to bring out of town guests for a beautiful walk through the canals. There are a ton of great picture opportunities on the walkways and bridges with amazing architecture in the houses lining the canals.

Walked through the canals with my family. The neighborhood is beautiful and the canals are simply wonderful. Being down here is like being in Europe. This is a wonderful way to stroll away a couple of hours before heading down to Venice Beach for dinner at one of the beach-front restaurants. This is a LA hidden gem and well worth the time.

column2: lovely, peaceful place for a morning walk
column3: We are staying nearby and I needed to walk for an early morning coffee. Very few places are open at 6 am so I had a 10 minute walk. I realized from the map that I was close to the canals and figured out how to walk along them. They were filled with early morning ducks. The sidewalk along the canals was empty and it was really lovely. There isn't much water in the canals, maybe a foot or two deep. There were some jumping minnows in the middle. It was much nicer walking along the peaceful canals than the busy street. Worth seeing them. I'll do it again tomorrow.

The water level was really low, so didn't really look like a canal, more a muddy puddle. Very overrated. Venice was an absolute hole. Never want to go there again. Santa Monica was so much nicer. I didn't see any arty, hippy style people, going about their arty ways. It was just a dump, selling really awful, cheap tee shirts and rubbish. the only arty thing I saw was someone making a sand castle. We were a small, varied group and all of our opinions were the same. Couldn't wait to get back to SaMo.

This is true history these canals. This city was designed after Venice, IT. I have been to Venice many times but never seen this. It was nice to take a walk. It was restful and quiet. Quite different than the boardwalk. If you like to see something that isn’t over crowded and noisy, this is it.

This is a lovely area to visit. Worth a trip alone to ogle some of the beautiful houses along the canals! A great spot for a lazy wander with an ice lolly.Be warned that the pavements are very narrow, we tried to go down pushing bicycles but quickly turned back to drop them off as it was not practical.

Yes, its a great photo op and thats about it. You will cross some bridges in a small master planned community with a few gondolas and scenic walkways and there will be lots of people and traffic in your way. I don't understand the draw to this place, save your energy and visit the real venice, not some artificial neighborhood for ultra wealthy people.
Beautiful scenery lot of canals with boats having hand paddle shiney polished boats with men in uniform really wonderful Venice
Beautifull neighborhood, photo opportunities at every step.It is a gem, you don’t think you may find a place like this in the US

column2: Got engaged here. Super fun, romantic walk - worth checking out.
column3: If you're looking for a fun, casual stroll near the water in L.A. - this is the place to go. It's fashioned after the venice canals in Italy, with cute pedestrian bridges that lead you along a nice stroll near the water.

Gorgeous place to take a walk and get some photos! Here are my tips if you are planning to go...The canals seemed closer to Marina Del Rey than the Venice Beach/Santa Monica area I am more familiar with. My directions took me through Marina Del Rey and up to the canals, rather than down Venice Beach and to the canals.There is parking lot charging a flat rate of $25 which is great if you plan to spend an entire day around Venice or that area of Marina Del Rey. I found a parking spot in a shopping center and then we walked to the canals. Get there early, park and plan to spend a few hours exploring the area so you don't feel rushed!
What a contrast from Venice Beach. This small area is just lovely. So peaceful and pretty. Great for a stroll

I found that the Venice Canals Walkway was lovely. This is an area that is surrounded by private homes, so please be mindful. That being said, the little canals are gorgeous and I really loved walking around here. If you're passing by it's a great place to visit, however if you're in LA I would not recommend going all the at out to Venice to look at this. If you're in the area, it's a relaxing little walk.
This is a nice place to visit with friends or with someone special. It is not like the one in Italy but it really has nice views of the canals

column2: These are PRIVATE HOMES, PRIVATE BOATS
column3: These are private homes, private docks, private boats, that happen to be on a public walkway. Show respect!1-Walk your birds, bikes, boards..there are small children walking on the narrow sidewalks that could easily be injured by your carelessness.2-Dell is a street.. you cannot block it with your car, your self or your selfie stick.3-Professionlal photoshoots require a permit.

column2: Love the place for its relaxed mood
column3: Of course it is not like Venice in Italy, it is small, and crowded, and people who live there most probably hate every single person who passes in front of their windows, but still it is good to see. It is picturesque and romantic with a few bridges and some houses which are really loveable. I love the green part of Venice - there is plenty of trees and a lot of nice flowers. Also this is a nice stroll for the afternoon. Parking is available on the streets, but be careful there are plenty of patrols very willing to give you a ticket.

column2: An imitation attempt of Venice, Italy
column3: This small city have a lot of small houses, and some canals where are some boats.Venice of America is situated on the shore of the Pacific Ocean, and it have a large beach.There are a lot of souvenir shops.Close to Marina del Rey is the shop Cheesecake Factory, where are available some delicious cheesecake.

this former "beach slum" turned into a beautiful enclave of architectural inspirations. its almost like experiencing the Architectural Digest live. quiet, clean, and full of flowering plants and trees. A great relaxing place near the bohemian beach.

Nice quite place to walk about prior to or after going to the busy beach and boardwalk. Most of the houses are beautifully individualized with each having a unique architectural feel and decorated garden. Never too crowded with a good supply of bridges to take you across the canals into the direction you are aiming for. Parking on the periphery of this residential area is limited.
We strolled down to the canals from Abbot Kinney and really enjoyed the walk. The houses down here are incredible and no one seems to mind you peering in behind the fences for a look!
Lovely place to stroll among beautiful and charming homes and peaceful canals. Spent about an hour or so on a relaxing walk.

column2: Wonderful, another side to this area
column3: Quaint houses, narrow shallow canals, bridges beautiful.Stroll along at your leisure , feeling safe.A must do whilst in the area
April weather was perfect: slight breeze, sunny, warm. Relaxing place among busy city. Take comfortable shoes and enjoy.

Looking for a nice stroll inside the hustle and bustle of LA? Walk through the Venice canals. A historic neighborhood lined by canals. Each house is unique and the landscaping beautiful. It is very quiet and lots of ducks and other birds flying around. A good time for 1 - 2 hours.

I always ask visitors to LA who mention that they went to Venice if they visited the canals as well. Most often the person looks at me like I'm crazy and says that no he had no idea there was more to Venice than the famous boardwalk area. This restored area in LA is unique as it's so quiet and peaceful with the canals, footbridges and lush landscaping along the canals. I'm sure the residents like the relative dearth of visitors. Yet, anyone who braves the craziness of the boardwalk area deserves the respite to be found by walking through this area.

column2: Interesting to know they are there but not what we thought
column3: Interesting to know the canals here but not what we thought. I enjoyed looking up the history of the canals and the fact that the city was named after Italy's Venice and had actual canals was lost on me. I had wondered why I had not known of the canals before, despite that fact that I had been to Venice a half dozen times over the last few decades. Now I know. I had hoped for a lovely walk along a water side trail or even a gondola down one of the canals. However that was not the options. The canals are basically a neighborhood and not much of an attraction. Good enough just to take a quick drive of bike ride there to go over the 3-4 bridges and then be on your way.

I went here on the last day the beach is lovely with an old pier. Parking is right on the beach at 4 dollars. The canals are set back but lovely and pretty would not think you was in LA definitely worth a visit even if you ride along from Santa Monica.

I sorta fell into these walkways during a morning run. They are actually sidewalks that surround people's homes.. very lovely and a cool little spot of Venice. I was happy to see them, but I would not have wanted to make a special trip to do so.

Probably one of the most picturesque places to visit in the area. With its beautiful canals and pretty houses this is a great area to walk around, explore the canals and take instagrammable pictures! Don't miss out - you do not find any other place that calming and relaxing!
Enjoyed the canal walk with my son. A sort of oasis in the middle of the city. Seeing the variety of homes, the vegetation, the quiet, all was wonderful. Would recommend this walk.
I love walking through here during the day or at night. Seeing all the little boats and the feel of it is amazing. Such a gem in this city!

column2: More beautiful than the real venice
column3: If you're visiting L.A., take a trip down to Venice. It off the main stretch of Venice beach and its extremely exclusive. You can imagine only the wealthy live in this part of town. All the houses are different, their garden's lead down to the canals and its a small village of waterways . The only smell is from the greenery of the exotic plants and shrubs. You can't help but look into the properties as you pass by the open patio doors. It's like walking through a lush film set.

column2: Fantastic experience away from the beach
column3: A truly lovely area to visit about a block from the seediness of Venice Beach. Hard to believe people know Venice by the beach when it is in fact the canals that make this place worth a walk. The small house and humped bridges ad to the scene. Well worth a look if you're in the area. Parking is free a few blocks back from the beach too.
You can spend the morning by walking around this quarter. Canals are not so impressive but the view of some houses makes a beautiful postcard.

Great oasis in the quietest part of Venice. Take some time to walk among the canals and check out the multi million dollar homes. It's a great spot for a relaxing walk with a dog or just to escape the craziness of Venice Beach!
It is a copy of venice canal just these ones are constructed to copy.Nice place to have a romantic walk.

Took a walk down from Santa Monica and along Venice Beach, checking out the murals along the way. Venice Canals are tucked away, just nip up 23rd, 25th, or 27th, and you will find the canals. Take in the pretty homes and the waterways as you stroll along. So peaceful. Worth a look at if you're in the area.

column2: Welcome Calm Respite from the Vibrancy of LA.
column3: An is plenty to wander around the Canals and take in the peaceful tranquillity of the water & bridges juxtaposed with every conceivable style of colourful home and gardens. Walkways are narrow so watch out for Dog Walkers, Joggers and Cyclists.

A little quieter than the beaten path in Venice, this is a free walking activity to walk amongst interesting homes and beautiful plantings set along a canal system. Not any one place to see but peaceful and interesting.

column2: Little over-rated with lot of Hollywood drooling all over the place
column3: Its a man-made canal system replicating venice,italy. Extremely expensive and home to many hollywood stars. nothing exceptional about it, honestly. Lot of nice olden structures laid around the place, but kind of crowded.
As previous posters have said, it is well worth a walk. It is not an equal comparison to the real Venice, but still a nice place to visit once.
It really is like walking in Venice Italy with it lovely canals and stunning houses all different in shape and colour
Lovely place to visit if you like architecture, so many different styles of houses and beautiful gardens. do mind the dog mess seemed to be alot about.

It's definitely not the coolest thing ever, but being from the Midwest and also a avid GTA V player I really wanted to visit the Canals! I loved getting to see this in person and it was a fun date to walk to after a day at Venice Beach!
If you are in Venice, this is a must see! Perfect place for a walk. Very relaxing and close to the beach.
Even though not expecting something similar to the real Venice, there is nothing of really interesting.Maybe a quiet place for the residents.

column2: Interesting if you're in the area
column3: When we visited the water level was pretty low making for muddy, somewhat stinky waterways. The homes surrounding the canals however are fun to look at. If you're in the area, it's a nice stroll. Venice Beach has alot more to look at.

This place is a hidden GEM! I LOVE going here and walking along the canals after a rough day. Being there when the sun is setting or rising is beautiful! Even when the sun goes down it is so calming to walk around the canals ! I haven't been on any tours for the canals but you can definitely walk them yourself and enjoy alone time by yourself or with a loved one! I'm from the east coast and this place is a spot I come to when I'm home sick!

The canals are a fun walk on a sunny day, best done on the weekday when it is not over run by tourists. From the beach on Grand Canal, they span the area between Washington Blvd and South Venice Blvd., however, the canals perpendicular to the ocean start roughly at 26th Street if you are walking from the beach. And only go in as far as Eastern Court. Yes, a very quaint area of lovely homes: some massive ones and others still the charming beach shacks they once were.When visiting the area, please be mindful of the noise you may create when walking/talking by the houses. As one who used to live on Linnie Canal, I heard more than I wanted to of the conversations people were having as they walked past! Other than that, enjoy your stroll, and do not feed the ducks!

What fun this was. We knew that this was a miniature recreation of the canals in Venice and that they had fallen on hard times. But they have recovered and are a very pleasant place to walk and enjoy the water. We saw people canoeing, we saw others tending their shrubbery and we heard lottos people working on their homes. A very pleasant walk through the canals

If someone wants to know the history of Los Angeles and the beaches then a walking or a driving tour of the Venice canals will stimulate the imagination. How could a guy think of making this area an Italian paradise? It was an interesting try and with the canals that are left you will see a different way of life for the residents who have chosen to live on one.

column2: Not the real Venice but really nice
column3: If you're nearby Venice Beach you must do a walk of the canals Walkway ... it's nowhere near the real Venice but still it's amazing and relaxing ad you'll get to spot some amazing villas over the canals! Highly recommended!

column2: It was once MUCH larger, but kinda fun just to see it all...
column3: I live in LA...and I like taking out-of-towners to see the canals. At the turn of the century, it was SO MUCH more extensive, and much more impressive... But, you do get just a glimpse of how funky an area it is... Totally out- of- place in today's world...The surrounding area is nothing to write home about. Parking in Venice is almost ALWAYS a chore. But, like any beach town you'd expect that.. I'd say "SURE" go see it once, and then hit the Venice boardwalk for people watching and some out door food...WHY NOT???

column2: Cool! But when the water is low it is a bit unpleasant
column3: this is a cool network of houses and canals. The houses have a fishbowl effect...you can look in them and see what people were doing which is kinda fun to see how they are living.The water was low all over the region and in the canals though and that made them kinda smelly.
As many times as I have been in the area I never knew this was here. Parking is hard to find, but if you can get out and take a pic you should.
The Canals are cute and quaint, but I found it pretty awkward to walk through. People's homes are RIGHT THERE and I just felt as if I were invading their personal space.

column2: An Italian Escape Right Here in LA
column3: This is an area of LA few but the locals know about - and it is fabulous! Built in the 1950’s and modeled after the famed actual canals of Venice, Italy, the small 5-6 small street area is lined with small boats, canoes and gondolas that the locals use to get around. (The story goes that the local City Council agreed to let Venice flood the areas to create a Sister “floating city” - and then ran out of money! So this is all that remains). Walk around the million dollar mansions, up and down the tiny circular bridges for some exercise, catch gorgeous views of sunset, and feel like you left LA! BONUS tip: grab dinner at one of the fab restaurants on nearby Washington Boulevard and then walk off some dinner w a beautifully lit stroll around the canals. GORGEOUS anytime, but especially at Christmas and during the longer, lazy summer days to watch the sun go down.
Nice walk along the canals with some OK restaurants nearby. Quirky charm if you have half an hour after fish tacos at James Beach.

column2: beautiful day for a stroll through the canals
column3: It was fun to look at the houses as we wandered through the various canals. Very pleasant and the canals have an interesting history. I thik it is more enjoyable if you know some of it's history before walking through them.

Firstly, be aware that you are walking around people's home yard and you have the ability to look into other's home. Do respect the privacy and becareful when taking photos; ask permission if the owner is at their backyard, it's only polite to do so!

A nice break away from the crazy of Venice Beach and only a short walk to get here. It is another world of calm after the hectic waterfront. Nothing spectacular but a pleasant place to explore and stroll. My wife particularly enjoyed the HUGE and varied succulent gardens that many of the houses had on display if you are a plant buff. Worth a visit if you have an hour to kill.

column2: Nice place for a stroll and to take some pics
column3: We've wanted to visit the canals here on a couple of previous trips to LA, but never made it. We had a nice walk around talking pics and recognising places from movies/TV shows and felt like I was in an episode of Californication! :-) It's a residential area so obviously you can't be too intrusive but i reckon they're used to people walking about and photographing their houses! There is parking on the main street to then be able to wander over and spend half an hour strolling about in the sunshine.

column2: Relaxing canals on LA's west side.
column3: Such a calm place to visit, especially if you've never been. But this was my 3rd or 4th time. Nice to look at the bridges, homes, and little row boats. Be sure to be respectful as it is a real residential neighborhood.
This area is one of my favourite ones when in LA. The houses are quirky, colorful, and they are surrounded by beutiful canals. All good things in life are free, and thi is one of them.
We visited this place on Christmas day. All the houses in this neighborhood had very good christmas lights in place and it was a different experiences walking here. Very cute houses!

While my boyfriend was visiting me in LA, I kept trying to plan things for us to do. It being his 3rd visit, I was running out of some creative ideas. A friend brought this to my attention as something that could be really fun and romantic to do with your significant other.My story: We arrived to the venice canals just in time for the sun to set. It was the perfect atmosphere. We took a stroll up and down the canals and looked at the beautiful homes and swan boats. Finally as we were about to call it a day, we saw a man taking pictures of some other people in a perfect spot with the sun setting behind them on the water. Due to my love of pictures, I had asked him if he minded taking a picture for myself and my boyfriend. Immediately he replies, I am actually a wedding and engagement photographer, I would love to take some pictures for you! Boy did we luck out. About 10 minutes and 55 photographs later, we ended up with some pictures that will last a lifetime. It is the perfect backdrop for a picture of you and your special someone.Highly recommend for the view, the sunset and some great photographs!

column2: Great place to walk along paths! Nice vibe with great scenery! Cool houses!
column3: We were riding bikes down threw Venice and found these cool canals in between luxurious houses and condos. They have dirt walking paths across the concrete bridge. You can actually walk all the way around threw the neighborhoods. There is a lot of stunning art culture in and around every turn. You never know what you might see in Venice! Cool vibe with cool surroundings! Great location near the beach!
We really enjoyed seeing this neighborhood. There is a great variety in the type of houses and gardens. Fun to see the ducks on the water.

This area was super cute. It’s nothing too eventful, but it’s a super cute area for a nice walk. It’s a couple minutes past Venice Beach and then off the beach inland a few minutes. We went around Christmas time and loved the mistletoe and lights on many of the bridges. The houses were also very different and interesting to see.
We walked around this neighborhood at Christmas time. Most of the homes were decorated and it looked pretty and festive. A pretty little walk and much more to my liking than Venice beach.

column2: Unique neighborhood with lots of character
column3: Great place to walk and explore houses new and old with various styles of architecture, landscaping, colors and decor. All situated along the Venice Canals. Very suitable for a nice walk and exploration on foot.
The water was especially low the day we walked through, but it was still nice to imagine living in this little enclave.

column2: File under nice oddity not a tourist attraction.
column3: If you accidentally walk into this all well and good have a look see if you'd like to live in any of the houses beside the canal and that's it. This is not the eighth wonder of the world or even the eighth wonder of Los Angeles. The highlight of your visit will probably be seeing a few ducks. Enter at Washington Blvd and Strongs Drive
I wanted to see this for years so when I knew I was going to la I made sure I visited it.very nice place and very quiet

column2: Great place to walk and take photos!
column3: I have been to Venice Beach before, but that was the first time that I took the time to walk through the canals.Great photos and scenery.Sunset was great.
Very nice place to stroll around and see all the decorated houses and bridges around Christmas time. Probably just as nice the rest of the year ;-)

I've been going down here for years and it dawned on me I'd never really took a stroll along the canals. So recently finally got around to it. It's cool to wander along. The canals were pretty depleted in the water department when I was here. Makes it seem little rundown and ancient. I imagine when the canal levels are higher it's pretty cool. Must be nice to live right along them.
Had a stroll across the canal ways and enjoyed the tranquil surroundings. Would love to have a house here.

Grab your camera and snap some photos while walking along the Canals... Get the history of why it’s there a little research makes it a more fulfilling visit.It’s a nice walk and I’d recommend a visit!

Funky Venice Canals are fascinating. Not far from the beach and definitely something not found in Iowa. What once were bohemian cottages are being transformed into mega mansions. The counter culture that thrived in Venice are being replaced with computer geeks. Still, worth a gander and a very interesting walk about.
Definitely worth visiting if you are around Venice beach. Short walk from the beach, quaint bridges and great properties.

I used to visit the canals on a very regular basis for a long time and until now it has always been fairly " a local spot". During my recent visit there were tons of tourists (groups of 20-30) walking the canals and disrupting the experience. My advice, visit in the early hours of the morning and you'll be sure to have it all to yourself.
This area has featured in a few movies and I know why, it's quaint and easy to get around, with small row boats tied along the canals.

column2: Unique place but with Christmas lights is really magic
column3: I love this place in every moment ! After the sunset is even more magic all the lights in the house .. look like Venice in Italy .. but now with the Christmas light is like a poem ... super suite location must to see
Very relaxing walk i had here ,i enjoyed the quiet atmosphere and lovely views of boats and houses by the canals.
A must visit and visiting Venice Beach. So peaceful and a great walk around the canals and surrounding neighbourhoods.
Loved this, didn't know this existed and it was a pleasant surpise to stumble upon. I would definately recommend seeing this if in the area.
quiet characterful walks to relax and take in the autumn sun, dipping into cafe's on the way. a different side to Venice.
One can walk around here, strolling and enjoying the ambience. 30-45min in enough. Than go straight to the venice brach
Had a lovely wee stroll around the canals, picturesque and quiet place for a walk.My wife and I really enjoyed our time here.

column2: A free and interesting place to see in Venice--and the reason the city was named
column3: I was taking my friend to the airport but we had enough time for one last tourist spot. She was surprised by it and I told her it was originally much larger. It's more interesting to know the history, that Abbott Kinney was trying to recreate Venice Italy. You'll see every style of house and can park for free on the streets nearby. Just make sure you note where you've parked because you can get turned around if you go through all the canals.

column2: A lovely place to take a walk
column3: I love walking the Venice Canals. It is a charming experience. You will walk up and over the canals- you will see lovely homes (some large and new and modern, and some small bungalows) - and you will see ducks in the canals and on the sidewalks. There is a nice little playground for small children which also has a duck pond in it.It is located between Venice Blvd. and Washington Blvd. in Venice, not far from the beach.It is also fun to drive over the canals on the elevated bridges. It is a highlight of your trip to see the Venice area.

column2: The nicest thing you could see in Los Angeles
column3: What a beautiully hidden retreat, we were overwhelmed by the beauty of the Venice Canal Historic District. Paths line the waterway allowing visitors to see the increible homes, owned mostly the creatives, and there's a surprise around every corner.The area was built in 1905 by tobacco pioneer Abbot Kinney as part of his plan to bring Italian Venice to America hence the waterway and one-time presence of gondolas.Look out for features in the gardens and boat parks that include a giant gorilla in the center of a love heart and a pink flamingo barge!Venice Canals are a perfect way to relax and escape the hustle and bustle of the city, allow around an hour to stroll through and enjoy the view!

column2: A wonderful place to wander in Venice
column3: I have been here numerous times and I never get tired of walking these walkways. It is so peaceful, serene and beautiful, compared to the noise and activity along Venice Beach. It can get crowded especially in the summer, so would avoid this time of year or go early in the morning or late afternoon. I'm not sure how the homeowners feel about having hundreds of tourists walk their community, but I love looking at the housing and am envious that they get to live at such a unique place in LA.

You blink and you'll miss them, but a total escape from the crazy LA lifestyle. Gorgeous place to take photos. If you're lucky (like I was) you'll meet some people who live on the canal and get a nice boat ride around this hidden gem.
From musicians to roller skaters to head shops to Muscle Beach, this is quintessential southern California street life. A melange of sensory experiences.

Venice canals is a beautiful place to walk around. Located at the back of the beach along a walkway. It is a quaint peaceful area full of boutique homes overlooking the canals with pretty fauna and bridges. Small boats are moored up to some of the houses which I must say look idyllic. We did encounter a group of security men who had a guy on the floor and who was under arrest for I guess breaking and entering? We diverted our route from a possible crime scene and enjoyed hidden corners and pathways. A lovely place to jog or enjoy a romantic walk. Seems a world away from the buzz of Venice and the beach just a short walk away.
Doesn't have the romance and history of the "real" Venice but it is a very appealing part of LA and a lovely walk. A far more interesting part of the town than downtown to enjoy variety.
The Venice Canals are beautiful. Having been to the real Venice, it is a different vibe than the Canals here but it is still beautiful.

Very eclectic area with numerous types of homes. Quite the high societal place to be. The canals are shallow so none of the boats can have motors. Find a place to park on the main drag to the south of the canals. It’s worth a visit if you’re in the area.

Venice Canals Walkway is very nice for a short walk of less one hour. The houses around the Canals are so variously: fancy, luxury, sometimes odd but always in a good shape and renovated with passion and love to details. A very splendide area to live.Marcello M. Switzerland

We read about the canals and the community and couldn't wait to do the walk. The houses were incredible and most were beautifully landscaped. Going over the bridges of the canals were fun but it was the quiet walk in these surroundings that made it very special. We didn't see any big tour groups of people. It was pleasant. It's even better when you learn about the history of the canals before you go. It gives you an appreciation of the vision of this planned community. We had the weird and noisy time at Venice Beach boardwalk and finished with this serene walk. Perfect!

It's hard to believe this unique little upscale area is only a few blocks away from bum central (i.e. the boardwalk). This was another bucket list item I wanted to check off this trip. Many of us have seen the canals at least once in some Hollywood movie, and I wanted to check them out to see it is person. It was actually better than advertised IMHO. There is not much to see, and you are better to park and walk the couple of block area so you can see the unique houses along the canal. Plenty of people out walking their dogs and running around the area.It only takes you a few minutes of your time, but rewarding if you like that kind of thing.
It is a few blocks of hidden treasure that must be visited.Reading a little of the history behind is good to give you perspective of the idea behind

This gives you an oportunity to view the different architecture and design which vary from old California bungalows to sleek creative modern. The canals create a cool respite from the heat and traffic.

column2: A relaxing escape from a vibrant city.
column3: Take the time to hike the historic Venice Canals. The area is rich with history, amazing architecture and it's just a great way to relax and feel more connected to the area.

column2: A mini Venice canal system in Venice CA
column3: A beautiful sight of mini canals in Venice CA. Beautiful place to walk in the evening. Very close to quite side oVenice Beach and close to Venice Board Walk. Coffe at Cow'sEnd, an iconic place in Venice, a must.
We did not walk the walkways but did drive through this beautiful neighborhood. It is close to the Venice Boardwalk so a visit is an easy inclusion to your Venice trip

The Venice Canals...CALIFORNIA!? It's great right? Wild, right!? I live in Santa Monica and visiting the canals never gets old for me. Abbott Kinney...visionary, perhaps madman? Who knows! But he had passion and vision and just up and built some canals a la Venice Italy! It is charming and fun to visit. Remember to respect the privacy of the people who live here. ;)

A nice place to visit, go for a walk, quiet, relaxed, interesting to see how some people in LA live. Anyway, it does not remind of Venice at all, it seems like the boats are only a decoration, so if you expect anything that remotely is close to Venice - don't. But it is a nice place anyway.
Walking down the canals in the evening is very relaxing. The houses are beautiful right on the water and it's very peaceful.
This canal is a small one but beautifully maintained, Both side you find wooden houses and calm and quite at most of the time. It will be very nice in the morning . Photographers will love it.

The small man-made Venice canal quarter is an LA must-see. Nice wooden houses, some gardens, a quiet oasis close to crazy Venice Beach, all reminiscent of what used to be a laid back hippy area (now I imagine the number of the price tags on those properties to be quite long). Unfortunately, the draught causes the canals to have a lower water level with not-so-fresh water at times :( Still nice though.

Just a short walk from the Venice pier (see picture-a great place to view the bay and SM pier) are the famed Venice Canals, a small enclave and remnant of the work of architect, Abbott Kinney. Here you walk among the original cottages and mega-mansions of this unique West LA neighborhood. In addition, you will explore diverse botany and architectural design. Birds are also plentiful so don't wear your dress shoes. Be sure to do some bridge hopping and if someone invites for a small boat ride, take them up in it.
We were surprised to find the canals in Venice. If in the area, make sure to find the venice canal neighborhoods. A very beautiful area to walk or bike through.
Nice relaxing walk to take few beautiful photos. Located not so far away from Venice Beach. Worth to see.

Having visited the canals in previous visits this time we were able to stay in one of the properties; it was magical. The canals are a tranquil area just a short walk away from the liveliness of Venice Beach and also the shopping opportunities of Abbot Kinsey Blvd. The canals are lined by attractive houses and gardens, the attractive bridges crossing the canals, the colours of the flowers and the palm trees all add to the charm.

A pleasant pocket in LA to get away from the traffic and shopping and tourist traps. If you like to walk and talk this is as good a place as any in this odd neighborhood of bridges and canals. Some nice pictures to be had here on a sunny day.Parking off the canals is a hassle so it's best to try two blocks away near Washington Blvd.

column2: Easy and close walk to the beach
column3: The canals are a must see if you're headed to the beach at Venice. It's a very fun, relaxing stroll and it's somewhat tucked away so you don't feel any hustle and bustle from the beach crowds. The houses are also very beautiful to walk past and look at.Don't skip it!

This you have to see. Beautiful homes line the canals. It's a residential area which has walkways along the homes and over the canals. The homes are all on top of each other but it's really neat to see their individuality in both décor and landscaping. Its a nice way to pass an hour before you hit the boardwalk

column2: Free parking, easy walk to the beach
column3: Instead of paying expensive parking fees in venice beach and santa monica beach, best to park in one of the numerous streets near the venice canals and walk to those beaches instead.
Very. Ice and beautiful walk. The water is low due to no rain but still beautiful. Lots of colors, flowers, art, clean, interesting.
It is a must see location for my visitors when they visit me in Manhattan Beach. I usually combine this place with the Venice Beach to enjoy a whole day trip and feel so blessed.

Found out about this treat by accident. It's really delightful. One interesting sight along the walkway is a home that has about a million different oddities and dolls. You'll laugh yourself silly. The walk around the canals is very pretty. Not sure if they have gondola rides but have heard that they do.

Need a Gondola or Gondoliere in Los Angeles? Need a Canale? U got it! Meds Ponte dei Sospiri? Ok, folks, Venice is in Italy. But kitching along the channel in gondola a Los Angeles is funny and shows u how much Americans do believe in our history. They realize they do not have history but they want to know everything about it. So they try to be cosmopolitans. However. And so immerse y'self in a different Venice surrounded by nature and buildings. Close your eyes, open'em up suddenly. What difference does it make if your fantasy's engine is functioning? Enjoy it.

column2: See Venice On The California Coast, WoW, its Special.
column3: Venice is a special So Cali coastline location, and walking the canal streets is so unique. Enjoy the walk, then head to the pier and walk north along the boardwalk toward Santa Monica. During the summer and fall months it is so amazingly fun and festive.

column2: Fun to do while in Venice
column3: The canals are indeed a "hidden gem" but I wouldn't make a separate trip just for this. It's a nice walk and house-gazing is very fun, but that's about it. Pro tip: The water is public property so you can drop a paddle board in there and enjoy the water!

This is a curious place but definitely worth come to. My first sweep through here was by a car driving up Bell street & looking. After that I found a park and walked through. It is quite amazing what has been created here & that it has been (in part) maintained.
Walking distance from Venice's famous Muscle Beach, this lovely setting is stunning and relaxing. Beautiful!!

column2: Nice walk, small canals in Venice, CA
column3: If you want to walk, bike, or drive to see Venice canals east of Los Angeles, CA, this is your place. The canals are small with cute little bridges and roads. Worth a drive thru if you have time while in Venice Beach, CA.

column2: A place of peace and calm
column3: Venice Beach is manic so no better place to get away from it. The walkways provide lovely views of the canals and a good chance to be nosy and look into homes along the way.
We happened to stumble upon this beautiful location and decided to take the walk in the neighborhood. A Very cute area with lots of interesting houses. Great way to spend the afternoon!

After spending a busy day cycling through Venice and Santa Monica it was lovely to return our bikes and spend a while walking around the beautiful canals. It was peaceful as we enjoyed the little bridges and beautiful homes and gardens. I am so pleased that we took the time to enjoy this area.

column2: Refuge from the busy Venice Beach
column3: Venice Beach is a super crowded and at times, overbearing place. The canals promise nice views, shade, and few people. It's a nice walk with beautiful houses and bridges. It's a must see.

Subdivided in the early 20th century, originally small single family houses on a half dozen canals, with a central business agora behind the beach. Now pricey residential. Sidewalks along the canals in front of the homes and over the bridges allow visitors to dream about their waterside dwellings. Anyone can paddle through.
Sadly we had to time to walk 30' enjoying the houses and views of the channels. But we enjoy the little time we had. Take more time please!!

column2: Venice Canal: Awesome stroll (TIP/ADVICE for visiting)
column3: Great place to stroll, take a leisurely walk. We went here before the beach and strolled the 5 canals. They aren't long, but it's nice to see the houses along the canals. Some are old school, some are more modern. Nice colors. They do have security patrolling it so you feel safe (rest of town has an issue with homeless people).TIP: These are all homes, it's not a place to shop or eat if that's what you were intending.

Visiting LA with the family, we made it a point to see the canal walk and the unique houses that are there. I LOVED it. Everything about it is so charming and the area is actually quiet. The houses were amazing and the bridges gave you wonderful photo opportunities. The teenagers in our group were not as impressed...I don't think they appreciated how unique it was. They went along with me and posed for some pictures but I think the adults liked it more. It's a hidden gem and I would visit again for sure!!!

column2: Away from the hustle and bustle of the ocean front
column3: Scenic and very different from the highlife of the boardwalk, but very small. It's worth the detour. We walked there in the morning with its water reflecting the colors of the gardens and the houses it was romantic.

I am amazed at how many people do NOT know about this hidden treasure in LA, walking distance to the Venice boardwalk, pier and beach. There are no hotels on the canals, just multi-million dollar homes with small canoes and kayaks attached which no one seems to use. You will not be disappointed if you find an Airbnb, like I did, to stay in - worth the extra $. You can walk over foot bridges that connect the 3 islands. You can easily also walk to Washington Blvd. and Pacific Ave. for shops and restaurants. I used Uber/Lyft for the first time on this trip and got everywhere from the canals usually for under $6. There is plenty of bustling, crowded activity in LA, Santa Monica, Marina del Rey - why not have your peaceful, beautiful place to go back to. If you stay somewhere else, make sure to at least pay a visit to the Venice Canals. You will temporarily feel like you are in Europe.

column2: very nice quiet area in Venice
column3: Lovely place to take a short walk. Park the car north of the canals and walk to the beach. Super trendy area and very different from everything else in the city.

What a beautiful little oasis ! Reminiscent of certain areas of the Thames , London only far prettier.We managed to park in an adjacent side street (be careful of residents only parking areas) and walk the short distance to the canals.As we went on a Friday mid afternoon it was very quiet and peaceful. Spent about an hour here.

column2: Beautiful place to take a stroll.
column3: Tucked away from the madness of Venus Beach and Santa Monica is the Venus Canals Walkway. Gorgeous little houses with beautiful gardens face onto these man-made canals. Picturesque bridges span the canals and colourful canoes and rowboats line the edge of the waterway ready for high tide to return. must see.

We stayed in Marina Del Rey and used the Canals to walk thru on our way to Venice Beach. Very fun to see the different types of homes/architecture and watch boats and ducks in the water. Got some great photo backdrops!

column2: Enjoy a quaint walk on the canal to brighten your day.
column3: Few settings have appeared in movies more often than the Venice canals. Of course, there's a reason -- it's absolutely beautiful. High tide is the best time to stroll, for it can get a little pungent at low tide, but the reflections from colorful boats and homes beacon you.
Beautiful landscaped walkways. Takes you back in time. A nice little stroll through the canals is a necessary!
Lovely area. Not sure why they drain the water from the canals on a Monday. What about those of us who are not just weekend visitors.
The Venice canals are beautiful. It's a very peaceful place to visit. We have rented bikes and ridden there on previous visits, but the walk was lovely.

... to wander and see how the other half live (in our case!). The houses are spectacular and views are incredible. The people are super nice too, we chatted to loads and were offered some champagne by some residents whilst wandering along the canals. It's so beautiful and appears to be a bit of a hidden gem. It's nice and quiet as well, should you want a break from the busy streets.
This part of Los Angeles is peaceful (usually) and very scenic. Bikes are often part of the scene, so bring one or be careful if walking!

We just were trying to buy some time before our next event and we took a Lyft over to walk as it was close to our hotel. Just a nice place to see and something free to do. If you like the beauty of nature, water, walking and architecture then this walk is for you. Intimate and be mindful this is persons residents so be respectful. A must see for lovers of the things mentioned above.

its a really nice place with ducks and a few other birds,flowers occasionaly in the spring but in the summer this canal can have a slight odor. great walk though for couples and just a get away. no gurantee you will have it all to yourself though. so come early or late in the evening.

column2: Interesting area for a relaxing walk
column3: The Canals near Venice Beach are unusual - it's a number of homes built on canals, with most having a dock to the canal. The "Walkway" is mostly a sidewalk in front of each home, with the occasional bridge to get over the canal and onto the next.It's flat walking (except for the tiny bridges), and interesting to look at the houses the that surround the area. Fun as a diversion.
This is a lovely residential area. However, don't think of living there unless you have lots of money. Real estate is very pricey. Still, a beautiful place to pass some time.
Saw this on LA in a day bik tripDid not expect to see this but explains Venice beach and interesting LA history
Happened on this area more by chance but we were very pleasantly surprised with the whole area. Lovely place to stroll and enjoy the many varied houses and quiet. Highly recommend.

Our grandsons (14 & 17) wanted to see the sights of Venice Beach so we included walking the canals. One of our grandsons is interested in architecture, so this was of particular interest to him. Our July 4th outing was crowded on the beach, but walking the sidewalks along the canals was peaceful with few tourists. There is quite a variety of architectural styles of all ages of homes. The boys liked picking their favorites and taking pictures of them. On one of the bridges over a canal, we got a great family picture taken by a volunteer tourist. While this was not an exciting adventure, we all enjoyed the change of pace from the beach and were glad that we took the time to see a different part of Los Angeles.

Spent 2 days in Venice while waiting for a Cruise. Loved every moment. No traffic. Quiet friendly and romantic. Winding narrow cobblestone streets throughout. Food and drinks at nearly every corner. Lots of history. Very charming. One of my faves in Europe.

column2: Canals in the middle of the city
column3: The canals of Venice are one block off a main street(Washington Blvd) but are probably unknown to most people driving by. You walk by lovely home fronting on the canal...it is a lovely walk and is, of course, free.

These beautiful canals are located in Venice (not too far from the boardwalk). The canals are surrounded by small paths that you can walk along and take in the beautiful sights of the canals and houses. Great for photos. Allow 1 - 2 hours max.

This place was very cool to see. The water ways are beautiful and nicely kept. The people that live on these homes have some nice scenery to look at outside their back doors. It's worth seeing if your in the area, take a nice quiet stroll.
As the Abbot Kinney has the character, the neighboring canals do too. It is a fairly small area, yet it is lovely, cozy and is worth a D-tour if you are in the area.

This is a must. Believe it or not, there are Angelinos who don't know this place exist. It's tucked in the middle of Venice. Worth going for a little stroll any day of the week. It feels like you are in a completely different city, not LA at all. Absolutely love it.
One of the great things to do whether you are a local or a tourist. There's nothing like them except in a big, big way in the real venice, Italy.
Hard to believe it is a short walk from the vibrant hustle & bustle of the boardwalk. Very enjoyable stroll, some may say romantic but definitely worth seeing.And it's free!!!

We walked through the canals on our way from Abbot Kinney back to the boardwalk. Very cool atmosphere in the middle of Venice, transforms you a little. Lots of unique houses, nice photo ops from the different bridges.

column2: The most stunning place in LA, period.
column3: If you are in LA, make the effort to go to Venice and check out the canals. It's like another world, nothing else in LA, heck, probably the US compares to this little bit of paradise. The houses are all beautiful, and the perfect canals that wind around are just breathtaking.
It is definitely worth walking to see the beautiful homes on the Venice Canals!!! The homes are so beautiful and unique! The manicured lawns are so spectacular!!
Enter of the Washington Blvd side for better parking and get lost in this wonderful maze of houses. Some people will even be on their back porches to say hello.

column2: One of the beautiful attractions in LA area - free!
column3: I've been coming to LA on business and vacation for decades and never knew this was here, until a few weeks ago I saw this on TA. So we headed there straight from arrival at LAX. It's totally amazing, The houses and yards are simply beautiful, there's always something new and surprising around every corner. Best place to park is off Pacific at Venice Bl., $10 flat rate. Well worth it!
Great for taking a nice walk and enjoying the Venice area. The house's have great designs and scenic views. We viewed several boats sitting in the canal. This area is very nice.

column2: Beautiful, quiet walk in the heart of Venice!
column3: Charming walk, right in the heart of otherwise 'eclectic' Venice! There are beautiful and varied homes here - modern, Spanish, cottage, traditional - and the gardens and flowers are gorgeous. Several walkways and bridges to meander around - worth it while in Venice!

My hubby and I went for a lovely walk along the Venice canals. The homes are just lovely and some of the gardens are quite beautiful. It would be lovely to sit in the yard and just watch the world go by... the canals are also very quiet, and it is a nice escape from the hustle and bustle of Venice Beach.

I, for one, did not know that the California Venice had canals similar to those of the city in Italy. There are many charming and sometimes quirky homes among the many canals to be explored. An interesting interlude after the hustle and bustle of downtown LA.

column2: Pleasant lifestyle, away from the boardwalk
column3: I saw maps of the canals (after all, this is why it's named Venice!) and owner's boats, so I had to check it out. Some very beautiful houses, but not in a grand way. Very modest, yet of course Venice is a high end living area. Seemed like people left their doors open, and it was a relaxed and beautiful stroll through a different time period and shift away from LA. This is prime LA LA Land!

column2: A peaceful oasis in Venice Beach
column3: Its a lovely walk around the canals walking past all the different style of houses, all with charming gardens. Its quite a large area, with little bridges from street to street.
What a lovely peaceful little place away from the hustle and bustle. Amazing place to just walk and take in the scenery.

Coming from Europe and knowing the real Venice in Italy, it was kind of 'weird' to discover this Venice.But the idea of wanting to copy the real Venice is quite amazing and I found it attractive enough to take a walk over there.There are some nice spots, bridges and colourful houses.So going there for a walk and 'play the tourist', as part of a larger visit of the region, Santa Monica, the Eames Foundation, some Frank Gehry buildings in the area, etc is quite ok.

column2: Surprised and delighted by this charming enclave
column3: Reeling from a tourist-induced anxiety-ridden afternoon, I was delighted by the Venice Canals Walkway. The charming enclave is Venice's gem, second only to the ocean itself. A must see for any visitor, particularly those who enjoy the wide variety of plants and architecture the area has to offer. Accessible on Dell road, there are eight parking spaces at the end of the street where Dell meets Venice Boulevard. Get out and walk - you'll be glad you did!

Walked through as a shortcut, tide was out, was fun watching the birds, every house is different in its own way and the floral scenery is amazing. Went through again, went over bridges and walked most of it, tide was in this time, just adds that extra charm. watch out for the hippo ! (its only a paddle boat, but too funny)

column2: Combine with beach trip and other attractions
column3: Very cute and hidden. You'll love the ducks. Won't take long so do combine with a Marina Del Rey/Venice beach/Abbot Kinney Blvd. trip.
Pleasantly surprised to find this gorgeous gem around the corner from Venice Beach (which was unimpressive). Take a stroll and checkout the quaint homes and peacefulness of the area. Very cute!
Really pretty area. Worth a drive through when visiting Venice. Sweet house which oberlook the short canals.

column2: A Beautiful Area To Walk Around!
column3: While at Venice Beach, walk a little farther to the Venice Canal Walkways....May be hard for some to walk the area, because to get to them, there are some hills and rocky areas.It is a very pretty area and nice for picture taking.
If you are in the area and it's extremely convenient then check it out. Otherwise don't bother. Basically home after home on the canal but nothing special about the experience.

You can take a walk through these canals and see the beautiful houses that overlook them. Some are luxury homes, others are small properties, but the place is perfect for staying in a quiet place far from chaos. If you are lucky some owners may invite you to the house
Such a cool area inside another unique area. Located a couple blocks from the ocean is the'canals' neighborhood. A wonderful walk over little bridges, by beautiful gardens and unique homes.
Walking the Venice Canals is generally a pleasant experience. It's a treasure in Venice Beach area that can be easy to miss. The fun part is observing the different architecture of the homes.
the houses are beautiful, and when he tide is in the canals are full of ducks and other birds. good for any age.

This place was on my list of things to do when visiting Los Angeles, from London, I absolutely loved Venice Canals. It was so much more than what I expected. Authentic, stylish charismatic houses with a canal view It was beautiful. It is a well-hidden spot that allows you to walk for a nice quiet walk and just take in the amazing experience. We brought our bikes expecting to be able to ride along the canal, but unfortunately, it was a little too narrow, but that didn't matter as the place was too mind blowing to even care. I will definitely be visiting again. I love LA but it definitely didn't feel like I was in LA here. That is the good thing about LA you get the best of both worlds.
A hidden gem at Venice, very beautiful and relaxing place at heart of Venice, LA. Enjoy narrow paths, no crowds, nice atmosphere.
It is nice to get away from the crowds and craziness of the boardwalk and walk along the peaceful canals. The views are lovely.

column2: An amazing little gem in Venice
column3: The canals are downright gorgeous! If you're looking to get away from the crowds of Venice right by the ocean, then this is a nice little stroll where it's much quieter. You'll probably spend 20-30 minutes walking around and enjoying the scenery—it really is just waterways and people's homes—but a cool spot to check out.
Stumbled upon these canals without ever hearing about them, and so glad I did. So very charming, it will put a smile on your face. Beautifully quaint homes and lush landscapes.

column2: A relaxing stroll through the quieter side of Venice
column3: If you've walked the bustling boardwalk in Venice and you're ready to see the softer side, head to the canal walkway. There is a variety of water fowl, beautiful flower gardens and stunning architecture along the way. Take your time with a coffee and enjoy the stroll!

I was totally taken aback to discover how the Venetian canals had been used as a marketing and city planning device for the new real estate developed into Venoice. CA. What a sotry. They are delightful to visit. just fun!

column2: Really nice antidote to the hustle and bustle of the beach
column3: The locals have managed to protect the remaining waterways from development as a marina. They're slow regenerating the vegetation and theres lots of birds visiting now. The house are lovely, well kept with nice small gardens and there are a number of park like alley ways between rows of houses to explore.

column2: Not As Great As Pictures Make It Out to Be
column3: The Venice Canals Walkway was very small and smelled pretty terrible. If you need something to do and want to walk around a bit, then this is a good option. I just wouldn't recommend planning a day around this attraction as it was a little underwhelming.
Over rated. If you are going to walk through here, remember to go when the water is up or you will be looking at a dry ditch. Just a sidewalk behind homes, nothing special.
Very nice walk along the pathways and over bridges. Lovely homes. Reminiscent of Venice, Italy though the architecture couldn't be more different.

column2: A nice walk among the canals
column3: The Venice canals based on Venice, Italy is a nice walk. There are 8 canals left but it's so nice to see the architecture of the houses, the plants and the vibe.
One of the highlights of my tour in Los Angeles. Truly stunning place and not at all busy. Great photo opportunity.

Venice Canals is right in the middle of the city, yet the vibe is very quiet and laid back. I love strolling along the various canals on a hot summer night, there's nothing like it! The homes are very nice and it's a great spot to come and chill for the evening. There's restaurants nearby in easy walking distance and I usually park on one of the side streets.

so these canals spans a couple of blocks and has its own charm to it. A nice place to have a soothing walk across the canals where people have their own private yards and kayaks to go for. A hidden place right behind the Venice beach and crowded roads but once you enter the canals, all the noise, traffic is kicked out.
