A must see. This is a quiet magical walk. Just inspiring for a relaxing walk watching birds and flowers. This is like an enchanted place.

column2: Beautiful and somewhat hidden gem in Venice Beach
column3: The Venice Beach Canals span for just a few blocks, so you might not even see them if you don't locate them in a map in advance. But we made a point on stopping there first before we even headed out to the beach, as we were so eager to find and photograph that gem in this neighborhood. The paths around the canals are narrow, but we saw folks in bikes, however walking is much more pleasant. I was surprised to see how close you get to people's homes and even have an insight on interior decor going on in the area. The landscape is full of trees and flowers, which conveys completely different feel from the beach boardwalk. Definitely a great spot for pictures and lasting memories.
Perfect for a romantic walk, relaxing and I love the different feel that you get from here. It doesn't feel like you're in Venice:) I highly recommend it.
this place is really beautiful for pictures, if you are going to Venice you should stop by and take some shots in this area for sure

This is a beautiful area, very different from the rest of Venice. I would recommend to walk or drive through here and look at the beautiful houses and the beautiful bridges over the canal. Also a few scenes from "Californication" was shot here, which is just a fun face. Go here if you're in Venice, you will love the views.

column2: There's not really much to see.
column3: The canals are hidden amongest a quite suburb and can be viewed from the many little bridges criss-crossing over the canals for the access of traffic. There's not really much to see, something different I guess, but hard to get parking to be able to hop out and go for a walk around.
A lovely place to check out, stroll around, take in the sight and end with a nice glass of wine near the beach!
This beautiful area makes you dream of living there. The canals are picture perfect and the homes are breathtaking.
You don't get to experience LA if you don't visits the canals. The architecture, the vibe - it's whimsical <3
We rented a house in Venice and walking the canals was a fun stroll admiring the million dollar houses!

Lovely walkways and bridges allow you to meander around the neighborhood. Walk slowly and check out all the well kept gardens, particularly the succulents. An eclectic array of architecture adds to the character. It was a nice quiet refuge from the business of the beach. It is a residential area so shhhh and retain the serenity for visitors and residents alike.

A friend told me to venture over to explore this neighborhood when visiting Venice Beach. The walk wasn't too far, and my teenage daughter and I were happy we had made the effort to see this unique little area.
Went after breakfast so it was so peaceful - these are a delight .Oh to own one of those houses! Abbott Kinney is a short stroll so head for a cool coffee, a really fab place in Venice to eat

column2: Lots of interesting buildings alongthe canals
column3: A short distance from the noice and loud music along the Venice beach, this is a wonderful sidestep that cannot be missed.

It's hard to believe that just a short walk from the colour and noise of Venice Beach is this peaceful gem. How lucky are people to live here! We walked along some of the canals and over the quaint bridges, soaking in the quiet atmosphere. It's definitely worth stepping away from the beach to visit this stunning location.

column2: OK walking tour of overpriced homes on the canals
column3: Some of the homes you walk past are cute and eclectic, but most are new out-of-proportion tear-down remodels squeezed onto these tiny lots. The canals can be more mud than water, depending on the tide. I'd rather walk along the ocean at Venice Beach.

column2: a pleasant escape from Venice Beach
column3: just a few blocks from the beach, this is a pleasant quiet diversion from the madness of Venice. The houses are beautiful and unique, and the neighbors are nice as long as you repect their property and privacy. Worth the walk.

After walking on the city center for a couple of hours it felt lile heaven. Is really peaceful and pretty, like a haven. If you have a bit of spare time i would advise to go to st monica and then pass by.

If you happen to be in Venice and have some spare time, it's worth a visit for a walk! it has nice views and it was also where some of the scenes of 'californication' series were filmed :)(Check out my intagram for my travel photos!:) IG: anamafalda8 )
This is a great little area to take in for an hour or two. There is a very interesting mix of houses and it's just so peaceful, considering it's proximity to the madness that is Venice Beach.

column2: Nice route for your leisurely walk
column3: Enjoy a stroll through the canals on the west side. Will provide an interesting look at LA history and some interesting architecture viewing the houses on your stroll. Well worth the effort finding it and getting a parking spot near the entry point. Weekdays re probably better.

column2: Lovely stroll through an eclectic area
column3: This is worth a walk through. Thought the canal was mostly sludge when we were there, the eclectic homes and decor were enchanting.

column2: Feels Like Miles from the Madness
column3: Just blocks from the madness of Venice beach & boardwalk is what's left of the original canals built by Abbot Kinney in an attempt to recreate the canals of Venice, Italy.It's rarely that crowded but if you go at the right time, you can enjoy a quiet stroll along the canals and pass no more than a handful of people the entire time.Definitely worth checking out if you're visiting the Venice/Marina del Rey area.

column2: Glad we made time to see this
column3: All three days we were in Venice Beach were very foggy so we didn't get to enjoy the beach and instead headed inland. Because of this, we almost didn't stop by the Venice Canals. I'm glad we did on our last evening. It was just nice to walk through all the beautiful houses and see the different architecture and design choices. It was a very relaxing way to end our trip.
eclectic character and charming mix of architectural and garden styles make this a fun place to wander around

Lots of people don't know there are canals in Venice. I lived in LA 10 years before I discovered them. They are so charming to walk through. You can explore for 30 mins and be satisfied with the cute yards, attractive homes and back yards and occasional wildlife spotting.

Despite its name, it really was a surprise to discover blocks of diverse houses along canals right in LA. The lack of master planning has led to a wildly broad range of homes and landscaping, all linked by paths and arched bridges. Strolling along the pedestrian paths near homes is a relaxing, architectural treat, especially at quieter hours of the day.As someone else said, it might not merit a special trip, but if you are in the vicinity, it is well worth exploring.

This is one of my MUST do's in Los Angeles. Walk the canals! It is simple and it is free and it is beautiful. What a place to live and relax. A maze of clans and small bridges. This is a selfie stick dream! Truly an LA original and something I recommend to out of town guests!.

column2: One of the prettiest neighbourhoods I've EVER seen!
column3: Simply stunning! The variety of architecture is amazing, the houses all nestle along the canals harmoniously. The streets and water are really clean & it's a lovely way to spend a relaxing half hour wandering over the bridges and around the neighbourhood. Lots of fab photo opportunities.

This is a beautiful spot to check out if you're in the Venice Beach area. I wouldn't necessarily say it's worth a special trip if you're coming from outside the Venice area.We found the eastern edge of the canals (furthest away from the ocean) to be the most beautiful area. Our vacation rental was just two blocks away from this place, so it was a convenient site to see.Walking over the bridges reminded me of many scenes from Californication!

Beautiful walk down the Venice canals. Great view of the small and unique California houses. Perfect for a romantic stroll down the canals or a whole family just wanting to see a different part of LA.

column2: One of my fav's in LA area
column3: It is just so weird and cool to find this neighborhood and wander around it, checking out fun and funky architercture before hitting the beach for ice cream. So glad I stumbled on it!

My daughter and I rented bicylces to ride down a very busy bike path from Santa Monica Pier. We found the Canals and walked our bikes through many of the paths. It was a bit difficult with bikes. We maybe should have got a chain and locked them up and just walked around without them.

These canals are beautiful. It's very quiet where you can see ducks and beautiful houses along the way. Almost all of the houses have a boat and it's just a beautiful very unexpected place for a city as busy and loud as LA.If you're looking for somewhere romantic for a date or wedding or engagement pictures, this would be the place to go.

column2: A beautiful, unexpected place to stroll in Los Angeles
column3: What a romantic walking area of Los Angeles! I went there on a first date a few years ago and the man and I ended up in a two year relationship :)
A walk along the canals in Venice is a unique experience. The homes along the canal range from old cottages to fantastic modern residences..fascinating!
Peaceful and beautiful homes with clean water and plenty of kayaks.Safe walkways for 0630 am.Highly recommended and free!

We spent about an hour and a half walking throu the Venice canals recently. It was a very sunny day thus making for a wonderful and picturesque experience. There are some very lovely homes along the canals and all-in-all it was a very relaxing experience.

We were fortunate to be able to wander the Venice Canals Walkway area with a life-long resident of the area, which made for wonderful walking and talking (e.g., about Jim Morrison and the Doors). Very enjoyable activity on a pleasant day.

The Venice canals are impressive and fun to walk around in after spending time at the beach. The houses are neat and it's fairly quiet and peaceful. My friends and I went here in the late afternoon and it was nice to watch the sunset and see the life in this neighborhood. Compared to the chaos of Venice Beach, this is a great place to go to escape. Definitely would recommend if you're in the area!
Live all my life a couple hours from here, finally can put it off the bucket list! We even got to see it with the sunset which made it extra special!

Such a unique and enchanting experience, the Venice Canals Walkway had to be one of our favorite activities during our recent visit to the Los Angeles area. Located near the vibrant Venice Beach, the canals are a serene, hidden gem (located off 25th street/Venice Beach) – if you didn’t know they were here, you would easily miss them. I find it hard to believe that we had visited Venice Beach so many times over the years and missed the canal walk. There are five canals - each with unique, charming and/or lavish houses lining the canals. Most of the houses, in absolutely pristine condition, have a dock and a boat. It is simply stunning – would love to live along the canals but a tad out of my price range. The bridges spanning the canals are also unique – none seem to be the same. Would have loved to have seen the original Kinney concept prior to 1928 (when all of the original canals were filled in except the 5 remaining today) – I imagine it was absolutely gorgeous. A great escape from the chaos of Venice Beach – highly recommend!

Just a short walk away from Venice Beach there are some fabulous canals that are a must see. Bordered by beautifully quaint houses these canals are definitely a lovely attractions away from the main touristy area. A must see.
This walkway is beautiful and fun, the weather was perfect so we walked for hours just looking around

My sons took me on a "Day in Venice" excursion which included a nice walk along the canals. I would highly recommend a walk along the canals if you want to get a feel for how these folks in Venice live and enjoy the great weather and scenery. Also walk along Abbott Kinney and shop at the various unique boutiques and check out the restaurants.

The canals are not large or a major tourist draw, but instead are a pretty and sometimes whimsical glance at a unique slice of life in So. Cal. You stroll along walks and bridges that abut the backyards of homes along the canal. It was nice to get away from the crowds and tour this area.

column2: Fell in love with this place
column3: Well, if this "Venice" is so charming and romantic, I'd definitely like to visit the real Venice :) This area is not that big, so it's not worth coming here only for this place. But I advice you to spend here 30 mins to take great pics and enjoy beautiful cozy houses.

column2: An enchanting walk among unique houses nestled among canals
column3: We must have visited during high tide on Sunday, January 29th as we did not notice any bad smells. We’re from Canada and I found walking along the canals enchanting. Every house is unique. Beautiful and so quiet early morning with a few other people jogging or walking their dogs. We even saw a policeman on a bike go by. Granted you wouldn’t probably spend more than 30 minutes walking around, but why miss this when it’s so close to Venice Beach? After admiring the houses and choosing which one we’d live in, it was a short walk down to the beach.

column2: So this is why it's called Venice
column3: Very cool, the history of Venice and the charm of the walk ways. My son brought me here and I had no idea how involved it really is. Houses are unique and interesting. The water doesn't look the greatest and area's are run down. But, overall it's worth a walk and an interesting piece of California History
It's just a neighborhood with the typical canals, but don't be fooled, it has nothing to do with Venice (the city in Italy)It's a tourist trap...
A great way to travel around, with great historical architectural buildings surrounding.Unavoidable for falling in love with Venice once you've visited.
Lived most of my life on the west side and only recently did we discover this hidden gem. Fantastic walk if you pick just the right day, not too hot or cold. Loved it.
It is a lovely walk through the canals where you get to see the back yards of the interesting homes of Venice. The walking bridges offer ideal photo stops. Great neighborhood to explore.

nothing to do there but walk up & down & eat at a few restaurants there - saw some ducks and it's all residences - if those all turn into restaurants & gift shops it'll be worth going - the city can zone it mix used - like in singapore - downstair business & up stair residence - there are such pockets all over la & building more & more - solve traffic problem - no car - just lift or escalator to work - offices should have shifts like grocery stores so there never be jam anywhere anytime

I'm not a California native, so when I saw the canals for the first time, I finally realized why it was called "Venice" Beach. There aren't too many canals, so it won't take very long to walk through a fascinating, sunny, green version of Venice, in contrast to the cobblestone streets and Renaissance architecture of its namesake. Although it is a residential area, I like that the public can come and enjoy the beauty of the Venice Canals as well. If you've already been to the beach, the canals are a nice break from the boardwalk crowds.

column2: Avoid Venice Canals at low tide
column3: I decided to visit Venice canals having fallen in love with Venice from my first honeymoon.this was very different from Venice.Unfortunately, we reached there during low tide and it was obvious that there could not be much "boating" during the time. There was also a slight stench from the river. However, the whole place did have a different vibe from LA. You almost forgot that there were any land transportation as cars were out of sight. We saw people jogging there, walking the dogs.I guessed that we were the only tourists in the area. However, there were nice deco due to Christmas. There were also few charming houses with nice coats of paint / architecture.After walking for 30 minutes, the kids got kinda "tired" and we turned towards Venice Beach instead. Overall, a place that you can miss if you do not have the time. I recommend to visit Venice, Italy instead. :)

column2: nice thing to do while down in venice
column3: I think the canals are nice, don't get me wrong, but I wouldn't go out of my way to cross through LA to get there. If you plan on going to Venice beach anyway, why not add this little walk to the list. It stretches about 4 blocks close to the beach and you can go in, walk around a bit and take some pictures. I would say about 30min is enough, if you like to walk all of it, maybe an hour at the most. The most interesting part for us was seeing the cute little homes and their great gardening ideas in small spaces.

column2: No Cost And Beautiful To See!
column3: Walked the Canals early in the morning, taking in the quiet and beautiful sights. What a lovely experience I had with my wife! We both enjoyed our walk and the views. Even met some friendly residents along the way.
visiting a friend nearby and had never actually seen the famous venice canals - really delightful walk around -
They can be a little smelly at times, but this is a fun stop if you are walking home from the bars in Venice at night.

Most people head to Venice Beach while in the area. Many don't realize this little gem of a place is very close by. Just a few square blocks you can spend an hour or more leisurely walking up the hills or along the water. There are beautiful private residences along the water. The only issue is parking. Since it is a residential neighborhood and not an "attraction" per se, there is no parking lot specific to the site. You may have to pay to park at a private lot in the area and walk there. That was the only hassle....
A great place to walk around and enjoy the canals. Best time to go seems to be in the morning. The homes along the canals are also really cool to look at as they are of all different styles.

A short walk from Venice Beach is this delightful, unique, quiet little neighborhood (about 4 or 5 square blocks) of houses along canals with footbridges. The houses are an eclectic collection of different architectures, no two looked alike. Lots of pretty gardens. We did kinda feel like we were traipsing though people's front yards though I'm sure the residents are used to it. We got a few friendly waves as we admired the homes. A great place for an early morning stroll.
It's a nice little area in LA but I wouldn't plan your day around it. Take some photos, maybe go for a short walk, it's okay.

column2: Ahhh! Venice and still in the USA!
column3: Absolutely worth the trip! The canals and each bridge crossing makes one experience magic. A 360 view happens and a feeling of joy is felt deep within. Venice Beach never felt so nice and is within walking distance to all of the shops too!

A beautiful, quaint, peaceful, artistic, tranquil, out of the way community. We enjoyed walking around the interconnecting channels across bridges – some with Christmas decorations up. Every house is unique, hinting at the personality of the owner. I'm sure during the summer, it could be very busy, but in December - this is definitely a side of LA that seems to be hidden away from the hustle and bustle.

This was a beautiful setting and great to walk around but I felt like I was intruding, you are mainly looking at peoples houses which are a lot closer to the canal than I'd expected and it's not as far to walk as I'd thought either so I'd allowed a lot more time than needed but it's very pretty to see and I'm glad I went.

Such a nice place to walk around with excellent photo-op. Just near the Venice beach, the canals lined by beautiful thematic houses with some floating platforms and figure boats. It is a must visit place while you are around. A very romantic setting.
Great free way to spend an afternoon. A really pretty walk through a unique neighborhood. We walked back over to the Venice Beach Boardwalk just in time for the sunset.
Great experience, nice and romantic walk on the canals. Beautiful scenery and houses! 2 minutes walk to the ocean. A must see!

column2: Most people don't even know it is there
column3: You need your GPS or an in-the-know Angeleno to find the canals of Venice. Originally designed and dredged in 1905 by the developer Abbot Kinney (for whom a near-by street is named that you really must see). Kinney dreamed of beautiful homes on both sides of the many canals with unusual bridges crossing them. That was before cars took over LA and about twenty years later, most of the canals were filled in creating instant streets. But, enough of them still exist to get the flavor and feeling of what was - and still is, in part. That remaining part is truly gorgeous. You can see REALLY expensive homes as you walk along both sides of the canals. The owners seem to accept the tourists and the gawkers who likewise tend to give the owners some "space" (and let's face it, courtesy is essential here). Kayaks are still paddled here, ducks still swim by, the chance to stroll along the edges and across the bridges, hints at what once was. It is more than worth seeking out.

Visited the Venice Canals Walkway in the last week of December 2016. The houses around the canal walkway were beautifully decorated due to Christmas and New Year celebrations. Few boats could be seen. It is an ideal place for stroll. It is near the Venice Beach. Houses glittering with light looked very beautiful.

Very nice "mimic" of the actual Venice Canals. When the tide is out though it exposes all of the filth sitting on the bottom which ruined the experience; not something that can be helped, but try to go during high tide.

It's hard to believe few people come here for a walk. It's very pretty, and at Christmas especially. Would recommend for a break away from the hectic business of the beach. But watch out for dog poo!!!

column2: Ahhhh - that´s why it´s called VENICE !
column3: This is really fantastic for a morning stroll. You would not believe that this neighborhood is just one block away from the Venice Beach walk.
great romantic subdivision free to walk through, not too many tourists, I did it on the way to venice beach.

Only went because of the movie Valentine's Day and wow what a let down. It was like swamp water that smelt like urine and while there were some nice houses others had derelict back yards that looked like something straight out of mt Druitt (Aussies know what I mean). There was rubbish in the water and sunken run down kayaks. Also a few houses tented up getting fumigated.

column2: This is what So Cal is about. The Canals are the soul of the community
column3: A must see for tourists or locals who have not been here before. It is the soul of the area and a welcome contrast to the high energy of the Venice boardwalk.

column2: Very Unique, Like visiting Venice, Italy. Clean, beautiful scenary
column3: Very Unique. Must see when visiting Los Angeles. It's like you are visiting Venice, Italy except lot cleaner. Gorgeous view and a very nice walk.

We used to live near the Venice Canals and would not miss a return visit to them every time we're in the area. These narrow canals are all that is left from developer Abbott Kinney's vision of a holidaymaker's Venice in the city of Los Angeles. Houses range from funky shacks to rebuilt swanky homes. Combine this with a walk along the ocean, and you've had a real L.A. Beach experience.
This place is unique! I really enjoy walk true the bridges and contemplate each beautiful houses over there. Look for the public parking, is $10 for the day.
This is one of the nicest areas to visit any time of the year.If you like to explore places on foot, this is the perfect choice. It is quiet and full of interesting buildings, bridges and gardens.

column2: Quiet and lots of beautiful sea birds
column3: Get an ice cream at Coldstone and walk the canals, enjoying views of lovely and interesting homes and the varied sea birds. We saw mallard ducks, a very large brown bird I couldn't identify, pelicans, and snowy egrets (they were roosting on top of a house).
I cannot believe how quiet was this place. Beautiful at sun rise, this place take you back to some of the shows you've seen on TV. Really liked to walk around there.

This was one of the nicest walks we did in Los Angeles. If you are going to be in the Venice beach area anyway it's only a five minute stroll from the beach front. The area is very quiet and a pretty area to wonder around.

Take a trip around the Venice Canals Walkway - it's very interesting and a fun way to meet locals - you almost feel like you are in their backyard sometimes. The bridges and the gardens, the boats and the decorations are all fascinating!

column2: Pretty place for a nice stroll
column3: This place apparently not many people know about, maybe I'm wrong but its really beautiful. Pretty houses and pretty streams, and really nice place to take a nice stroll after wandering around venice beach. Worth taking a little detour for.

column2: A hidden gem in the big city.
column3: I found this in my favorite local book Walking LA. While only 9 of the original 27 canals still exist and they are so shallow you could probably walk across them, what I love is the uniqueness as well as no traffic while walking along the front of the homes. There is quite a variety of home styles and sizes on tiny lots and some of the yards are unique. The bridges over the canals are all different from each other. It is just a beautiful and interesting walk away from the busyness of Los Angeles.
The remainder of Abbott Kinney's "Venice-By-The- Sea".See some original bungalows and the results of gentrification-mini mansions,architectural gems and "what were they thinking".

column2: It lives up to it's name
column3: Nice place for a stroll. Clean and very quiet canals with an interesting set of homes along the canal. Bridges span the canals.

The canals run parallel to the beach and are only a few blocks away. Finding free street parking can be tough, but there are loads of lots where you can park all day for around $10. The canals are beautiful and peaceful, it's a nice break from downtown LA

We had a stroll through the venice canals expecting so much more than what we saw.The water line is really low, there is algae in the water and the houses around the canals were just not in great condition.The attraction is nice to see, but don't expect to be WOW'd by it.

column2: An American version of the Italian city with the same name
column3: The last remaining Venice Canals are located off 25th Street in Venice Beach. If you didn’t know they were there you would easily miss them. But don’t. Strolling the historic myriad of waterside trails and small bridges is a dreamy way to while away a sunny afternoon.Here you will find relatively newly built design house side by side with the more bohemian housing facilities.Expect, however, no great boat traffic on canals
really enjoyed the walk around the canals. lovely homes and very quiet. a good break from there venice beach scene.

It was a cool day and we enjoyed a leisurely stroll down the canals. The houses and courtsyards are so pretty. We could imagine hosting an evening dinner party in the courtyard on one house.. We considered knocking on the door on more than one lovely residence....we thought we could ask if we could be there friends for just a couple of days...to experience what they live each day. We wondered...where do they park? Is supermarket shopping just a real pain and so eating out every day is just the thing to do? We loved it!
A very nice place to walk around. The area many years ago was much larger. This is all that remains of the canals. It's fun to walk around and look at the lovely homes.
You feel like your not in the USA with big streets and cars wherever you go. Its small, really quite, you can only go by feet and get a lot of nice views in pretty nice houses :)

We drove around in our car, on narrow streets, over small bridges, passing beautiful and unique houses. We stopped quite some times to take pictures. Recommended even if you only have 10 minutes and drive through!

column2: A great walk just off the beach
column3: We stumbled upon the walkway by accident when riding along the beach, there was a point where we had to detour when the path ran out so decided to take some of the back streets - so glad we did. Its really nice to see how the locals live and exercise away from the crowds.

Nice place for an afternoon walk. Don't forget your camera it is a beautiful place to take pictures. Something different to see. Something to do for an hour or two. Just walk and enjoy this peaceful place.
We drove by and over the canals the area was unremarkable just lots of houses by the canals. The history of the are was interesting.

column2: This is a fun walk- you will recognize movie and TV filming spots
column3: I try to bring all my out-of-town guests here for a walk on a nice day.The canals are very unique. Each house is different and special. So many famous people lived here at one time. You will definitely recognize various views from movies and TV. There are many good restaurants near by when you get tired of walking.
you get to see nice views of the canals and nice houses. We went for halloween so the decoration was really attractive as well. Nice walk.

column2: nice enjoyable walk through such a pretty neighborhood
column3: we walked around the canals and enjoyed the variety of house styles and the different landscapeing the owners have done to make their homes appealing to themselves and visitors. worth the effort to find parking and stroll through the area

This is a bit out-of-the way place, but one that was especially fun for two reasons: 1) I had just finished watching the show Goliath, and the canals are featured in the location, and 2) it was Halloween week - and some of these people go all out! I loved seeing the skeletons and spiders on the roofs and cobweb decor - what fun! I imagine it is that way around most of the holidays - you can tell the everyday homes with kids from the weekend adult playhouses. It's a popular dog-walking spot, so be prepared t for occasional odors or doggie disagreements.

column2: Fun to Explore While Walking in Venice
column3: We stayed at an airBnB house in Venice during our Los Angeles stay. I had lived in L.A. for 7 years prior to moving to the Philippines and had been to Venice Beach but never the canals. So it was a new experience for me as well as my girlfriend who was visiting the US for the first time. We really enjoyed walking along the canals. The homes and landscaping there are an attraction in themselves...very eclectic and all different from each other. It's a nice way to spend the afternoon and then you can walk the short distance to the beach to watch the sunset like we did. :)
Park your car and walk the canals, which have been restored recently. Beautiful houses and landscaping along quaint canals of Venice.
Charlie Chapman made tis rea famous all those years ago. Lots of movie stars live in this area. Its an interesting walk with plenty of history.
Really unexpected, very beautiful homes (anything from hippie homes to all glass villas) around theses canals. Not very crowded, but a MUST see.

column2: Definitely worth a visit, very pretty and so relaxing.
column3: Worth stopping here and having a wander around. Very pretty, Free to park on the roads. Venice beach is excellent too so you can do both at the same time.
It is beautiful to walk around the canals and check out the houses. It's close to the beach. So definitely check it out.

Take an easy stroll and wander a bit to fully enjoy the sights and sounds as you walk along the canals. The homes are amazing and there are lots of egrets and other wildlife. Best of all it is never crowded and is free. A welcome break from the hustle and bustle on Venice beach,

The last time we were in LA, we only drove up to a couple of the area canals in Venice and were disappointed that we didn't have enough time to stroll around and take in all the beautfy and charm. We had a lovely visit this time, biked around here and stood on all the bridges, walked on the pathways, admired the houses and cuteness of the area. Makes one forget about the city. We found it relaxing and peaceful. Worth a visit.

Historic district in Venice, CA built by a "dreamer" who wanted to replicate the waterways of the original Venice in Italy. While many of the original canals have been paved over by the City, there are still 9 canals to enjoy walking on their bridges and viewing the charming and eclectic houses that surround this charming area. Definitely worth a visit.

I recently discovered the Venice Canals Walkway but wasn't overly impressed with the area. Yes, the neighborhood has some interesting houses built along canals. It's not too busy because it's off the beaten path of the shoreline promenade. If you've already wandered up and down the beach, I don't recommend walking further inland to see the area. It is interesting to see but I wouldn't make an extra effort to see it. Instead, enjoy the beaches of Venice and the neighboring communities up and down the shore.Note: Venice Beach may be iconic but be aware of your surroundings. I don't recommend visiting the canals later in the evening as this is a residential neighborhood. I definitely don't recommend visiting Venice Beach after dark as it is a bit sketchy at night.

Certainly the Venice canals of Santa Monica are well known, but we were surprised how few people we found walking them. Many interesting houses dot the shores and it's worth visiting. We found the nearby Venice Beach area very trashy and touristy, with other 'beach towns' more interesting.

column2: Not only worth driving over but walking around
column3: The canals were based on Venice and only 8 remain. It is so beautiful walking around the canals seeking all the different architecture and some original homes. It's like its own little community.
A very beautiful hidden gem in LA. We had a great time walking through the walkaway, it seemed like we've crossed the borders into a European city in Southern CA

column2: Loved the Venice canals - a beautiful enclave
column3: This was a a special place, with strong historic and film/TV significance, and it does't disappoint. It betters expectation, in fact. There are several car parks nearby, with low hourly rates, and short walking distances. We went of an evening and it was peaceful and scenic, and would imagine that it is most of the time. Really pretty.
Its really nice to see..if you visit venice you have to go there, its romantic and beautiful place, with fancy houses.

The canal walkway offers you a very different view of Venice from the one you experience at the beach boardwalk or elsewhere. Very peaceful, very clean, not many people. A little island of peace. Worth the walk. Make sure you get briefed by a guide for which celebrity houses to look at.

column2: Nice place to walk and browse
column3: These canals may not be like the Europe version of Venice, but they're pretty places to walk and talk, and are more relaxing than most places in Europe and in the U.S. We've spent many happy hours walking and looking at the lovely scenery and homes along these canals.

column2: I loved this little piece of history
column3: What a delightful area to live for those who are fortunate to live in this little pocket. It first came to my attention in the movie Valentines Day, and I really enjoyed strolling down the waterways.

Very tranquil area with beautifully landscaped private homes bordering a series of canals. Active area for birdlife and just saying hello to your fellow wanderers. Only 2 blocks back from Venice Beach and at the southerly end there is a great Thai Restaurant worth visiting also.

column2: Worth checking out if you're in the area
column3: The Canals aren't too spread out, so perfect for a walk in the sunshine. Fun to see the houses, but not sure I'd want to live there as it's not very private! Some good photo opps to be had too.
Nice walk about, seeing the canals that made the name Venice California famous... now it's the Boardwalk, plus multi million dollar homes all around!
These canals are perfect for walking and exploring, day or night. You could probably see them all in about an hour. Definitely worth it if you have the time.

Lovely place so close to all ameneties and shops 2 streets from the beach. A very pleasant stroll past beautiful houses and along the old canals and over bridges. Not quite real Venice but a good effort and well worth a visit.

column2: Lovely little spot for a stroll
column3: I would definately say go down here, ask to use someone's boat if there about, haha why not ay, lovely little location and then go down to the beach to watch the sunset.

The canals in Venice provide a great afternoon walking experience away from the crowds. The area is quite extensive so along from getting some gentle exercise you'll be rewarded with views of gorgeous homes lining the waterway. And the foliage is just amazing.If you're in the area, I highly recommend you check this out!

Looking for a break from the crowds, the canals are an area of natural beauty, with a number of really amazing houses and real sense of the tranquil. Well worth a visit,!if I lived there I would certainly be a curtain twitcher 😳

I was surprised at the lack of tourists walking around here, we wandered up and down, the place if gorgeous and the houses are stunning. Nice people walking past and saying good morning. A lovey way to spend an hour wandering around with some price and quite, seems a million miles from the Venice Boardwalk.

column2: PARADISE IN THE MIDDLE OF INSANITY
column3: After enjoying driving the 405 with 20 million of your closest friends head down to Venice, park, and enjoy. The walkway is fantastic. An escape from the city with great views, watching folks fall off their paddle boards and the hub-bub of sailing boats going in and out. A great way to detox!

Very picturesque when the sun starts to go down. Beautiful houses backing on to the canals of Venice. You feel a little rude sometimes just looking at the architecture of the houses while someone is in the kitchen cooking dinner.

If you are in Venice, it is definitely worth walking to the canals. There are some pretty houses and lovely bridges over the water. It is a very different bit of scenery to the rest of LA. Bear in mind though that it is only houses - we were expecting maybe a little waterside café or coffee shop but there are no amenities just houses.

This was a nice little trip. a few canals in the middle of a vast concrete jungle. Not too far from the Santa Monica/Venice area. the pretty little homes have stunning back drop of small canals. A few little boats dotted around and the odd ducks swanning around.

looking for interesting places to visit in Los Angeles I found Venice Canals. I saw the pictures and I liked it. when you visit on Saturday. It is a jewel of engineering. pass by bridges and canals are beautiful. being a residential area need to be careful around with pedestrians and pets.
Interesting development, canals are kind of shallow, I assume those are mosquito fish in the water?? Nice homes, but who would want to live in these 'glass houses' with strangers walking by everyday?

The canals are tucked away off the main road, but are signposted. Very pretty to walk around, with some of the houses having special designs. We were able to find a parking spot not far from the Walkway, but also visited there when cycling in the area, which is much easier. Very quiet pretty area.
Have been to SMA plenty times but never been at the canals. Its a nice stroll (if there is no one else as the pathes are narrow) and lovely houses to see
Well worth a walk around, this is an area full of charm and beautiful houses. The bridges offer great views and photo opportunities

column2: Meander through tranquil living in LA
column3: To see a special area in LA of living like on a vacation go to see the homes on the canals. You walk amongst nature and see peoples creative talents where their homes express their love of nature and beauty. It is a unique experience for LA living.
Nice walking paths along canals, far from real Venice, but still relaxing. You can see some beautiful homes and cute bridges.

column2: Beautiful and relaxing both day and night
column3: The Canals provide a beautiful scene for a stroll alone or with others. The homes are beautiful and there are ducks that enhance the beauty.

Wander along the canal-side paths and over the bridges for an hour or two to enjoy this unique, hidden community, then head back to the bustling part of Venice near the beach or pier for lunch or a coffee. Wear walking shoes, sunscreen and a hat and be sure to bring your camera. Savor the tranquility here - you will be glad that you did.

This area is such wonderful place with some unique houses to just watch and walk by them. The bridges which you can find plenty of them around are somehow really Venice(Italy) style which is very interesting.

Wow, this is a hidden gem! Just a couple of minutes walk from the busy Venice beach area these canals are beautiful and peaceful. Definitely worth exploring them and checking out all the amazing houses right on the water's edge

I love cruising around the canals. A friend, his dog and I went at night and it was awesome. Checking out all the houses, it is set up perfect for strolling around. People were out having dinner parties. I can't wait to go back!
This was a first for us and Venice is a must for anyone to visit. Went on the gondolas which is a wonderful experience.

column2: Charming hideaway of fun, but expensive real estate
column3: set to the south of the Venice Beach boardwalk an set a little inland from the sea, this small collection of beach cottages, houses and "shacks" is charming - especially when set against the wild brashness of the Boardwalk. You can literally peer into the houses and wonder who lives there and what do they do and how did they get there.Worth a wander as part of the Venice Beach experience

column2: the highlight of my trip in LA
column3: you have to go there. your like in another world. so calm and chill. not a lot of people round there, it gives a break from hectic boardwalk. relaxing. romantic. LOVE IT.

column2: Beautiful place to take a stroll
column3: It's fun to take a peaceful walk up and down the Venice Canals. We were a little surprised to be so close to people's back yards, but the canals are open to the public to stroll around. It's a surprisingly quiet -- so it's a great way to get a break from the hubbub of Venice Beach.

This is a really cute area. It's worth the visit and is easy to ride to if you are hiring bikes, park and walk. It's not a huge area but very charming. There are no restaurants or Cafes on the canals but plenty nearby. Highly recommend

column2: Leisurely walking day in Venice, CA
column3: I was so excited to finally walk around the Venice Canals that I heard about years ago but never saw! And all this time they are only waking distant away from the beach and Venice pier and all the attractions on the boardwalk! Wow what a beautiful site and such diversity of homes along the canals. People have tiny docks with canoes and travel up and down the canals. There are beautiful bridges across some areas and walkways all around! You feel like you are transported to another place, like Venice Italy when you find this hidden treasure!
The canals have beautiful homes right on the water. The water itself is a bit stagnant and not too clean but it's nice walk after lunch!

column2: Nice change to the beach walks
column3: What a lovely area. Beautiful houses. It's probably best not to visit on a Sunday like we did! It was very crowded.

The walkways are very narrow on the canals so I recommend parking your bike on one of the side streets before venturing in. It is a great place to walk and look at very nice properties on a nice day. Very close to the beach, so if your looking to break away from the beach for nice walk, this is the place to see.
Beautiful area in the Venice neighborhood. If you want to get away from the hustle & bustle - I'd definitely suggest this for a short walk.

column2: Such a serene and quiet neighbourhood
column3: The area is so quiet and calm. What an ideal neighbourhood! The houses within the area also seemed really very nice and well furnished. The walk down the stretch was really enjoyable and relaxing.

I was in Los Angeles for a business meeting and was staying near Venice Beach. I went out to eat and while I was walking back to my hotel, I came across this amazing neighborhood. It is so beautiful! Sidewalks, bridges, water and doggies...what more could you ask for. Definitely take the time to walk the Venice Canals if you ever get a chance.

This area it is nice to visit by the way it is not big area and there is difficulty to find it I ask a lot of people but no body know it also in use google maps but not find it in the end I try in my self by car and find it
Atmosphere is fantastic and houses is so nice.... just want to move right away :) Go for this walk, it is really enjoyable.
Amazing houses and quiet walk away from the crowds at Venice Beach. It's a really good route to get up to Abbot Kinney as well for it's shops and restaurants.

column2: Really pretty walkway; a must if you visit LA
column3: Very lovely walk by the Venice canals. You are close to the water and can look at the pêle-mêle architecture that is typical of Venice Beach: old (ish) bohemian cottages, ugly Tuscan-style McMansions, and interesting and not-so-interesting postmodern rectangular blocs. Something for everyone.

I learned only last year of the canals in Venice Beach and was curious to see for myself. Finding ourselves nearby, my family and i made a point of strolling among them. They are a tranquil and leisurely stroll mere blocks from the beach. We enjoyed the botanical beauty as well as the cool architecture of the whims. A great - and free - way to spend 20 minutes or so.

column2: Nice to compare to the real Venice
column3: Very tranquil area, try to visit during the week when it's not that busy. We drove around and stopped very easily to take pics.

column2: Relatively unknown jewel next to Venice Beach
column3: Venice owes its name to an attempt to create within Los Angeles limits a small replica of the canals of Venice, Italy. However, maintenance costs and other reasons led to a mostly undesirable area of dirty water. A major refurbish transform it in a grid of small canals and very well kept walkaways that have attracted upscale construction and has become one of the most desirable places to live in Los Angeles --for those who can afford it. A must see for anyone visiting the area.

We had a brief 20-30 minute walk around the Canals and even had a nice chat with one of the locals who moved there from Ireland 20+ years ago. It's a cute and scenic little area of Venice and worth a walk to admire the canals/bridges and cute houses.

I have to admit that i have always thought that the Canal in Venice would have been a sad replica of the canals in Venice. Not at all. They are a peaceful oasis in L.A. and they have a great identity and personality. It's a nice stroll few blocks from the beach. The houses are gorgeous, really fantastic. Definitely a must go when you are in Venice

column2: Nice place to visit but you wouldn't want to live there!
column3: A brain-numbing contrast to a lot of the local LA area. Beautiful walkways, gardens and houses in a waterfront setting. You feel as though you are somewhere exotic.But.....If I lived there, I would stand at the front of my house all day fending off tourists!

It is a great place to walk around. The walkway is a great place to take pictures. This place is not too far from LAX. I recommend people should take their out-of-town friends there for a walk if they come to visit via LAX.

We live just down the road so this is one of the walks we do when we have people visiting. When Abbott Kinney first designed Venice as a getaway for people in Los Angeles, he had Venice, Italy in mind. The canals are pristine and peaceful. Alot has changed in architecture styles, but there is still a mix of quaint beach bungalows with the new, modern architure thrown in. For people who love to admire echlectic houses and get garden ideas, it is a good place to check out during sunset. We love to stroll before Christmas too, when homeowners decorate their homes. There is even a small vessel parade!

I would like to see where on the face of the Earth someone could replicate what the good people of Southern California have put together here. Yes there are places not too far from here that showcase the excesses of LA, yet give the locals their due for this one. The owners of the impeccable Gardens that face the walking paths have outdone themselves. The care and attention to the horticulture is unsurpassed, each backyard its own work of art! One has to wonder when they can get out and enjoy what they have created, what with all the gawking tourists of of which we were 5.No kidding this place is not like the "real" Venice, give me a break! Where else in the world can you walk from garden to Garden unmolested, where the locals have broken out such loving creativity, almost for the pleasure and enjoyment of passers-by. Can anyone say where on Earth people spend millions of dollars to have a little piece of land in which to share their love of beauty with strangers ? Clearly "keeping up with the Joneses" plays into what we behold, yet there is something positively celebratory about what is offered up for our enjoyment. I for one am very grateful.

column2: Awesome when there was no drought
column3: I had the chance of visit this place multiple times, and I can say that when there is no drought and there is plenty of water on the canals, the view is great, Great place to walk with your special other, date, etc. before the sunset the view and the feeling is kind of Romantic, the place is quiet and if you are lucky you will see some ducks splashing on the water.But if or when California is on a drought, I suggest to skip this place, because the lack of water just makes it sad. view.

column2: Away from the Hustle and Flow
column3: This walkway is tucked away near Venice Beach. I spent 3 whirlwind days in LA for a combination of business and leisure, and found the crowds and bustle of LA a little overwhelming. A stroll through this quiet neighborhood was the antidote. My mother, sister and I all enjoyed this walk, recommended by a local friend, which was very quaint and picturesque.

Walked along the beach. I am always going to love to visit places like Venice. I must highly recommend eating at Centanni if you are around and need some good Italian food and cannolis. They had the best, and I was with three Italians!
Visit the canals is the best you can do in Venice, It´s a really nice walk with beautiful houses there.

When walking in the canals, you enter into a tranquil lovely secret space. You have stepped into a time warp - to a sleepier, small town feeling and a relaxed pace. Strolling along the water, you may pause to notice ducks swimming in the canal, or a cat lying in the sun on a porch. The little bridges that connect different walkways are perfect photo opportunities. If you go toward the end of October, there will be Halloween decorations galore, including some animatronics. At Christmas, beautiful lights reflect on the surface of the water. Magical.I love joining this small community by supporting the quiet and the calm that are so important to the experience, and have always had the experience of others being highly respectful and appreciative as well.

column2: Nice stop in our bicycle tour
column3: A few streets above Venice beach you'll find 4 canals in a quiet neighborhood with nice villas. Nice pictures stop in our bike tour.
A retreat from the general craziness that is Venice. Definitely worth a peaceful walk through. A nice detour from a beach bike ride.
The canal walkways are a great way to explore the architectural gems of the neighborhood and escape the chaos of Venice beach.

column2: If there is nothing else to do
column3: A short walk along the canals.Might remind you Venice but it is far away from the real thing.It is close to Venice beach so I guess it worth spending a few minutes if you are there

column2: Pretty to see, but just walk around and look at the houses
column3: It is just a pretty walk and although I enjoyed it, I don't know that I would put them high on my list as there is so so much to do in LA. You basically walk all around the area and see the canals and houses. I did enjoy the walk and really enjoyed walking the shopping district and most of all, Venice Beach and the Muscle Beach.

Being a Westside Local comes with its benefits. This includes taking a walk in the Venice Canals on a bad day. If I want to dream a little dream and just escape from the hustle I take a stroll through the canals and all is well.I love when things are nestled away for a great escape.

Nice area with nice (expensive) houses. It has somewhat of a special atmosphere to it, but nothing like real "venice". If you are in the neighbourhood, ok, take 30 mins to see it, but otherwise dont bother to make a big detour for it.

column2: If You Are At The Beach Anyway, Go, Otherwise, Don't bother
column3: The Venice Canals is a neighborhood with pricey houses lining a concrete filled in canal. Designed by Abbott Kinney in the early 1900's as a vacation spot it had the man made canals and a huge pier on the beach. Those days are long gone.It is now a lovely spot to walk if you want to walk. There are ducks and now in a blue moon you may see someone in a little boat. But the water is not for bathing or swimming, the houses are no longer little and charming and the area is just a really expensive place to live.If you are at the Venice Beach (at the end of Washington Blvd, not Windward) then go for it. It is several blocks of canals with homes.Enjoy. Your wallet is in your front pocket.
A really quiet and quaint place to take a stroll. Tucked away not far from the beaches.Not ideal for large groups -walkways can be narrow.

column2: Nice to see but nothing amazing
column3: I had wanted to see this place for a long time. So one morning i cycled from my hotel to here. It is nice to see the area and the houses are cool but because it is Venice it is hard to relax in the area. I love Venice but as a tourist it can be hard to know where is safe.
After the busy beach it's very calm walking along the canals. You get to see the varieties of houses along the way.

Venice beach is amazing for people watching and alternative views on life... But it can be crazy busy and not at all restful.Head inland a little to find the canals - walk up the road from Venice pier and you'll get to the start of the canals.Gardens in summer are very pretty, you can 'chat' with the occasional dog or cat and the ducks are quite amusing. Surprising to see so many little fish in the water.Worth a wander if you are in the area.

column2: Interesting architecture, history and an easy walk
column3: Having a tour guide to point out the history and the architecture, is great as you could miss so so much around the areaEasy walking with the opportunity to have a bite to eat and a glass or two of win
An unexpected surprise- easy walk from the beach. you can stop and have a lovely glass of wine along the way.
We walked over the sweet bridges arm and arm. Peoples gardens were beautiful,and watching the ducks in the canals was great. Definitely a must see!

column2: If you can't make the trip to Venice
column3: Italy nope! But on a warm afternoon with a nice beach breeze and a little imagination one can see the gondola's passing by these narrow but well groomed canals.Very picturesque for those out of town travelers on a budget.
The canal makes up for a fine walk and it is pretty and quiet. But not worth traveling through all of LA for

We came for lunch before a visit to La Brea Tar Pits. My son melted down as we discovered he was running fever. Our waitress zoomed over with a drink and then a free chocolate shake. Husband dashed to nearby pharmacy for meds and we were all able to enjoy our delicious lunch. Best matzo ball soup ever. Very tasty pastrami and corned beef.

The area is nice and quiet (it's a residential area) so its ideal if you want to take a casual stroll. The area is pretty shady too, which was lovely. They are hidden from the beach a bit, but keep walking through the streets and you will find them. I don't think they are a must visit when in LA, but if you've visited a few times and are in the area, its not a bad way to kill some time.

Not really a must but if you are done with the boardwalk but it's still a bit too early for lunch/dinner go for a walk around the canals and see all the nice houses in the area. The lake was a bit dry when we were there so not a lot of boating going on.

The canals are hidden behind normal houses but once you find them you feel like you've been transported to little Italy , grab a drink put on comfortable shoes , grab your camera and walk the paths admiring all the beautiful houses as you criss cross the little wooden bridges you forget your in America . Lots of lovely photo opportunities a definitely not to be missed excursion !

Pretty and unique homes in a peaceful setting. Nice place to take a stroll. Take Dell avenue starting from 28th ave heading northwest over the bridges and get a general idea of the area, find free parking on any of the streets then walk around.Not worth making a trip from a far but if you are going to be in the area, I would recommend.

one walks pass an assortment of different designed homes in the higher $$$$ range garden are pretty and most well kept .People and dog friendly environment. Shame that the actual water level in some parts of the canal are drying up

Got the tip from a colleague who lives here. Great place to walk around and admire the beautiful houses! Not crowded at all despite a very busy day at venice so dont think it is well known to tourists but definitely worth the short walk from venice beach. My teenage son of 18 loved it too! Takes 30 min and a must see!
It is amazing to learn the history of an area and see how the landscape has been changed over the years. Saw this locale with A Day in LA Tours.

column2: If You Can't Get to Venice Italy and are in LA......
column3: The Venice Canals are a wonderful addition to your tip to Santa Monica, Venice Beach, Abbot Kinney attractions. Wander up and down at a leisurely pace either during the day or at night. You'll see all types of architecture, from the "cottage" or "bohemian abode" to ultra contemporary concrete and steel homes. All homes of course have docks and a variety of boats. Parking is sometimes challenging, but read the signs and a couple of turns around will usually yield a space. I have visited this site many, many times over the years and always am glad when I have made time to do so. If you like architecture, and have fantasized about living on the water, this is a must experience.
Venice Canals- remnants of the original Venice. Tranquil and quiet this tiny oasis is situated right next to the hustle and bustle of Venice boardwalk.

Charming little houses with postage stamp yards, many beautifully landscaped, line the canals. Periodically the canals are bridged by arched, white, wooden walkways.. Skiffs and small rowboats tied up along the canals. I felt like I was walking in some epic romantic movie. I loved it. Unfortunately, I was not accompanied by a handsome lover - I had to make do with my best friend. But my daughter and her fiance certainly seemed to feel the magic, walking arm in arm, with their heads leaned in to each other. Wonderful!
Have been to Venice/Marina Del Ray prior but must have missed this area. Loved all the flowers flanking the paths, etc.

Walking along the canals in Venice is very peaceful. The houses are close by and you can see people in their boats on the water. There are bridges that cross over the water. Venice Italy has much more history and nicer architecture. But Venice California has better weather!

column2: When We Have Out of Town Visitors
column3: When we have out of town visitors we usually take them to Venice Beach to see the oddities and the sights that they have heard about back home. When we get to the end of the attractions on Ocean Front Walk, we cross Pacific Avenue and begin walking the Canals. Everything changes, the pace slows, they begin talking about how nice it would be to live here.If you are near and haven't been I suggest you take a little time and visit. Remember not to wear your best shoes, the many ducks often leave behind reminders that this is their home as well.
It was kind of hard to find parking in the area. Canals were beautiful and peaceful. I loved walking around and look at all the houses nearby. It was worth a stop
In my opinion, this was a neighborhood with a creek behind it. Very unimpressive. With traffic, very difficult to get to and not worth the payoff.

column2: Venice, CA, USA and not Venice, Italy.
column3: If you are in Southern CA, don't miss Venice Canals Walkway. You can walk it and look at the different homes, some are from the early 20's and some more recent. It is so relaxing and a great way to spend a few hours.

Great little neighbourhood, if included on a tour you will get info about the various celebrities that hve homes here but even without that it is nice jut to see a part of Los Angeles that time has forgotten. Highlight was the duck park (hope the ducks can read and know that park is for them)

The Venice Canals neighborhood is very peaceful and lovely. The residents take good care of their properties and it's a great location to take photos of some of the unique homes, landscapes, even pets and ducks who take up residence along the walk. Several movies have been filmed along the canals over the years. I just love looking at all the houses.

If you have an hour to spare in Venice, take your time to walk through the canals. - grab a drink to take along and just enjoy the scenery. Wonderful diversity of homes and relaxing event. Much of it is shaded. The architecture and landscaping of these smaller but plush homes is quite a lesson!

column2: Enhance your beach visit with history
column3: The Venice Canals should not be missed if you visit the Venice Beach. It takes no more than 45 minutes to 60 minutes to walk the canals completely. You can gain an appreciation for the houses that line the canals along with the history. I strongly suggest using your smart phone to help investigate the history of the canals before or at least during your visit. Understanding how they got there and why they are still there is very insightful.
Take a walk around the canals for something really different. The houses are amazing and the gardens are fantastic. The water does stink. It's just a short walk up from Venice Beach!
A drive along Dell Avenue (one way northbound) through the center of this canal community is enough. Stop on the bridges and take your photos.

column2: Very nice place place to walk
column3: Very nice place to walk and watch the interesting houses by the canals. Is is a very quiet neighbourhood. It does't even seem you are in a crowded beach area.
Very beautiful peaceful area to walk around with lots of bridges around to cross. Lots of unusual unique beautiful houses too.

column2: Fantastic family walks in the early morning as well as late afternoon
column3: Stayed at a lovely Airbnb right on Venice Canal and explored the neighborhood early in the morning (7 am on a Monday). The layout is like a hand - you can easily spend an hour or two walking along the sidewalks lining the canal without coming near any cars, which gives it an idyllic atmosphere. It's also easier to walk around with little kids like that! Pretty much every bridge is a Pokestop here by the way, which is a perk. Aside from catching pokemons, we saw lots of ducks & gulls in the still water and cats lounging around the picturesque little houses.I also snapped beautiful late afternoon shots here - the golden light works so well on the water with all those white bridges!

Basically dried out canals which seem like swamps. Seems more like a flooded back alley for expensive houses who got fooled into buying "canal facing houses" although they are a block away from Venice beach (selling ice to the Eskimo). Don't waste your time coming here unless you are tired from Venice beach and have nothing to do.

We were staying at a hotel nearby & decided to walk the canals as the sun was setting. The light was beautiful BUT it was low tide. Definitely would have been more scenic at high tide. Some lovely homes, some funky homes, and the neighborhood is very charming so I think it's worth a visit.
Venice canals walkway is a excellent experience. The restaurants, places for photographers and watching people. We had a great time in Venice and will do this again.

when you look closely you can see that the water is quite nasty and dirty and shallow. It looks best at night when you can't see what it really looks like. The canals are more like a swamp but don't tell the people with houses along the canals that. They'd be none to happy as they are quite proud to live on a stagnant canal of green water which harbors humidity, mosquitos and algae. I don't see how fish could survive in it but who knows....I've never seen any.
It is a really nice evening stroll before or after dinner. We walked through the canals several times and it never got old. Some of the houses are very beautiful.
Visited here while on a recent tour of LA. We thought this was a beautiful area. S OK glad we got to experience this arwa.

column2: Something To Do After Visit To Venice Beach
column3: After walking along Venice Beach to see ocean and all the different characters, which we enjoyed, walk a few blocks to Venice Canals. Worth the trip. Amazing how some of the small houses on the canals, go for one $ 2 million, with very tiny lots. But I guess being a few blocks from Ocean is reason.We were visiting family in LA area and this was one of our side trips. Glad we went.Being from Florida, parking is a challenge to us in L in general and Venice Beach in particular. Turned down places that cost $30, and found one that was $20. Used it was about 2 hours... Later saw large Municipal lot that cost $18, so did not feel too bad paying $20. You don't have much choice. Extremely crowded this time of year.If you have opportunity to visit outside of summer, you might find less stressful. We were glad we went.Be prepared for crowds, traffic, etc etc, but that is part of experience.

I have always been wanting to find the Venice canals! it is just as charming in person as it is portrayed in the movies. each house has character and no 2 are alike. its a good after dinner walk and exploration. it would be awesome if they had actual boat rides through the canals

Please check out the Venice Canals during the day. It was built with the original canals in Venice, Italy. There are a series of bridges over the water as you travel from street to street. This is a residential area, so best to be courteous to the residents by remaining on the bridge. The lighting at night is not as conducive to enjoy the view and you could be arrested for trespassing. Be respectful but enjoy the view. FYI: there are many restaurants within walking distance.
After walking the boardwalk on Venice Beach this is such an opposite contrast! Peaceful walk with beautiful houses. Wished I could live here!!
See the way the whole town used to look! Beautiful canal waterways just like Venice, Italy. Fun to walk around or take a gondola ride.

column2: Not Venezia but not to be missed if nearby
column3: Interesting canals in Venice surrounded by very nice residences. It's definitely worth a trekk through the neighborhood as it will not consume very much time to pass through. This is what gives this Cali city it's name.

Before I went there I thought a place likes this can´t exist for real. Each house is much different, clean modern bauhaus architecture mixes with old wooden houses. Go there and enjoy a sunset. It´s amazing. The only downside is weird smell from time to time, maybe coming from standing waters or dog leftovers;)

column2: Peaceful. Oasis in the capital of camp.
column3: LA can have some of the campiest places you'll ever want to see. So if you're tired of the camp and the tourist stuff, walking or biking through the Venice Canal area is perfect. Beautiful homes on the canals, different kinds of architecture -- including the different California styles. Great place to spend a quiet morning.

The Venice Canals are so charming! It's one of my favorite area in LA for sure. Feels like the time stops and you can enjoy such nice walks and dream about having a house there one day.I just wish that they had built more canals.
This is a place you don´t expect to find in LA, absolutely beautiful surroundings, nice walkways and laid back tempo. Worth the stop!

We rented bikes from the Venice Beach Rentals and rode over to the canals. You have to walk the bike on this path but it so tranquil and pretty. The homes are gorgeous and there was one homeowner playing music and chilling on his patio. He was very nice and didn't make us feel that we were invading his space - You are literally walking right behind their homes. Although I was with my Mom & sisters - I could see this being a very romantic place if you were with your significant other.
I had a wonderful morning walking up and down the canals. I love the eclectic variety of houses, each with their own well-manicured front gardens. Don't miss a stroll in this historic area!

column2: Only part of Venice Beach worth seeing
column3: We headed to Venice to take a stroll, do a little sight seeing, and find somewhere to have dinner. The Uber driver was confused as to why we had any interest in going to Venice, especially to a random side street. The canals were beautiful and it was fun to see the different homes and yards. After walking the canals we headed to the beach front and quickly realized why our Uber driver was questioning our decision. The rest of Venice was a bust. We quickly called another Uber and headed to Santa Monica for dinner.

Although we got moved on whilst taking pictures recently, this small-but-select area of lovely homes is worth taking a while to see. An eclectic mix of modern and classic, one next to the other, it would be a dream to own one...
Just a few minutes from Venice beach is the venice canals development. A beautiful community of houses and canals. It's great to walk around ans see some nice houses and feel the atmosphere.

column2: Nothing Special Regarding Venice Canals Walkway
column3: Was excited to finally see the Venice Canals Walkway but it wasn't as pretty as I was expecting. I've seen them on many TV shows and movies but the water level was low and the water isn't very clean looking so the appearance isn't what I was expecting. There are empty boats along the canal and quite a few walking bridges but I wouldn't recommend going out of your way to see this attraction. If you are visiting Venice Beach and have extra time you can walk over to see them. They are about 2 blocks off of the Boardwalk but more toward the sound end of the Boardwalk and I would ask a local to ensure you get there. There are only houses and condos next to the walkway except near a main entrance and you might come along a restaurant but I didn't see any gift stores or much else to see.

We came across this quite by accident after jumping out of an Uber taxi. We spent the next few hours strolling at a leisurely pace the canals - what a great little gem this was. Recommend it for anyone - on a hot day make sure u have plenty of sun screen and water !
Quet residential place. 5-10 mins walkthrough will be enough. Be careful on the bridges since they dont have allocated pedestrian track.
After the zaniness of the beachfront walk, we found the canals tranquil and simply strolled over the several bridges viewing from each. Residential area.

We were visiting Venice and decided to check out the canals which we only recently discovered were there. When we think of Venice we only knew of the 'freak show' and muscle beach. The canals were incredible peaceful and the homes along it were charming. It doesn't take very long to walk along it, but it was fun to see. Lots of people were having outdoor dinner parties; it looks like a fun community.
If you have been to Venice, you must visit this Western version of the great Italian city. You will not be disappointed.

Not a gated community which is almost unusual. The canal neighbourhood is in a small area so you can walk all the canal walkways in a short period of time. Nice to look at the plants the inhabitants have put in and also into their houses. Glass houses make for zoos.If you were wondering, locks keep the water level (should be tidal) high during low tide.

column2: faintly reminiscent of the canals in the Netherlands
column3: By all means go walk by the canals after you've "done" the Venice Beach boardwalk. Though the ambience is less the canals and palazzos of Venice, Italy. More like Marken or Vollendam. Lush gardens.

We rented a place right on the canal. Excellent place for a little walk. The canals get partially drained on Tue and Thursday so they get a little low. Pick any other day if you can to go there. Some of those homes are so creative. Its a one of a kind place. Give yourself an hour to walk the entire canals.

column2: Hard to find but worth it
column3: Went on a tour which helped us find it and understand how they came to be. We really began to understand the neighborhood after seeing these canals

I'm being a bit harsh by rating this a 3, and I did enjoy getting to see the canals in Venice. About a 5 minute walk from the Venice boardwalk (if you're near the Muscle Beach Gym), it is definitely worth seeing it just to say you have. The canals are in the middle of a neighborhood and it's a good jogging path for locals.The reason I rated it a 3 was as interesting as it was to see, once you saw it, you pretty much saw the whole thing. I wouldn't waste much more than a half hour here. There's so much more to see on the boardwalk, especially if you're restricted for time.

column2: If you like gardening, don't miss these!
column3: Such a relaxing walk, and a lovely way to see lots of backyards up close. Everyone has a beautifully landscaped garden in their backyard and each one is unique. Go enjoy a walk along the water with beautiful gardens!

Not quite like Venice in Italy but still fun - most people just go to the beach and boardwalk but miss out on such a gem. Very close to the beach and not too hard to walk - a very pretty part of the area and so different to the rest of LA.

column2: Great place to walk and discover
column3: Walking distance from Venice Beach, lovely place to stroll and take pictures. Went with my daughter in a rush but next time I will make it a point to do it more leisurely
We came on a sunny day and were very impressed to found the houses, plant and canals are so well-maintained there. The environment is so peaceful, totally worth the time to come.

A friend had told us to visit the Canals while we were at Venice Beach so we asked a local to point us there. It was a short walk from Venice Beach although we realised afterwards that we had only seem a small part of the Canals. We were pleasantly surprised at how pretty it was and the contrast to the beach area. I would recommend visiting the Venice Canals if you are in the area.

The canals are a peaceful respite in the heart of Venice. A short walk from the Venice Beach Boardwalk, the canals are worth seeing. Make sure to bring a camera because the light is great and the houses and gardens are beautiful. You can walk up and down the canals from South Venice to Washington Blvd.
Perfect place for a walk and contemplation. A hidden oasis in a busy big city with beautiful houses, bridges and walkways.

We went here yesterdayWhat a delightful place! We took a stroll around the homes are wonderful all are unique with beautiful plants. We even saw a boat that is a black swan. There was a cute fence with flamencos, a tree with hanging lanterns. We even saw a mermaid. It is a wonderful place to take a stroll.
Who knew that Venice, LA was modelled on Venice, Italy! These canals are an unexpected delight. Stroll along the walkways, and take in the charming homes and gardens. A truly unique find in LA.

We enjoyed walking and taking in the views of the homes, canals, flowers. We did get some nice photos, but I'm not including right now (don't want to take the time). We both thought it was worth taking the time to find a parking place + walk along the paths.
Make sure you're going on a good day. The colors and the simplicity of the place makes you want to have a coffee and enjoy the relaxed vibe. (It was Sunday so it was quite quiet.)

column2: Looking for a lovely quiet stroll...
column3: The canals were built by Mr. Abbott Kinney in 1905. Mr. Kinney was very influential in the development of the entire Venice area.The canals encompass 12 acres of narrow sidewalks, wooden foot bridges and bridges for cars too.So much to look at, I felt like I was watching a tennis match! People in their little boats paddling along. Art sales in the front yard. So many styles of homes and landscaping!No need to go to the gym today, especially if you cover the entire 12 acres crossing over each bridge.We met lots of interesting people of all ages out enjoying a quiet stroll too. We took pictures, with their camera, of folks posing on the bridges or in front of a special boat, in turn, they took our picture. Great way to begin a conversation.Wheel chairs and strollers are permitted, no other wheeled transportation allowed so the sidewalks are safe for folks of all ages, and well behaved pets on a leash. Just make sure to have pick up bags.Depending where you enter/exit the canals you can find restaurants and shops.There is no public parking in the canals nor public restrooms.Please be respectful to the residents, if they do not offer a greeting they may wish to be left alone.I am very much looking forward to going back. I am sure the canals are awesome during the holidays. Watch the parade of boats then take a stroll through.Such a wonderful way to spend an hour or two.We rode the 33 Metro bus from Western exiting at Rivera. The Big Blue bus and 733 also cruise the area. Washington is also a major bus line.

I grew up in this area as a kid, and it is nothing like it was back then. It is so much nicer! Cleaned up, polished nicely and only rich folk can afford to live there and the shacks and dilapidated buildings are all gone.
