It doesn't even stink anymore and I didn't see any oil floating in the canals at all, and no pond scum, either. And there is so much more water; the ducks can actually swim!

Not much going on here except exceedingly expensive homes and peaceful pathways along the canals. It's a gallery of architectural styles, and observing the lives of people in several terrarium style homes. Parking is very tricky on incredibly narrow roads and remember many roads around the canals are one way. There are often duck families and other animals (including people) running around that you may not see until you reach the peak of a bridge so drive slow - or better yet, just walk.

column2: If you are at Venice Beach, walk a couple blocks and take a look!
column3: It is pretty neat that the city was named after these canals. They are only a couple blocks from Venice Beach and offer a sidewalk along the canal to walk down to view. I was surprised that the water is only a foot or so deep - explains why there were no boats - just kayaks. There are even bridges like in Venice, Italy, you can walk over to access the other side of the canal. It is free and easy to get to and neat to see... so, why not?

The views are beautiful. Great facades to see. Ideal escapade to walk and talk with your loved one. Really great place if you like taking photographs. Tip: get a coffee to enjoy while you get lost on those tiny streets.

This was a treat we stumbled upon while walking back to our car from the beach. Beautiful canals with walkways and bridges. The architecture...oh wow!! All different styles of houses here. Definitely worth a visit.

Most people who come to Venice come for the beach. The beach and the strand are great places to people watch, from Muscle Beach to the entertainers. Most people, however, miss the canals and in so doing, miss understanding why Venice is called Venice. Located between Washington and Venice Boulevards, just a few blocks east of the beach, it is possible to walk the sidewalks lining the canals. There are a wide variety of homes, from the simple cottages originally built here, to the ultra modern homes that have been replacing them. Some of the homes are wonderful, others... You can also drive through the area. Go north on Dell, off of Washington. You will cross over 4 bridges getting good views down each of these canals.
Nice to wander through the canals on a sunny morning. But nothing much else to do. Really close to Venice Beach and Washington Blvd restaurants.
Really loved the stroll and the peaceful glimpses into the unique gardens and houses along the way. Stark contrast to the beach area.
Beautiful neighborhood, a must for anyone who loves architecture! The houses on the water are gorgeous.

I've been here so many times: Day and night, Alone and with a date, Party-holiday or no reason at all.Walking the canals is so good. Check out the eclectic architecture...italian-spanish-confusions, gaudy McMansions, slick moderns to funky original beach bungalows.It's a great place to view architecture. Take a date and find out what they like during the day. Take a date and find if they have a voyeur side.Plenty of nearby parking at the lot. Even better if you quickly read the history behind the manmade are canals.Yes yes yes

Daytrip to Santa Monica and Venice Beach, but walking over the the canals was the highpoint. I walked up and down each path, enjoying the ambiance. The houses are varied- some quaint bungalows, some modern, but all are really in keeping with the atmosphere of the canals. I really enjoyed the set back ones with patios. Next trip I do an airbnb and sit on one of those patios myself- and watch the tourists stroll past!
Just out for a stroll and loved the view. Very quiet and quaint neighborhood. Loved the winding walkways with overpasses

Quaint and lovely place snuggled in crazy Venice Beach. Easy walking and lots to see in a short span of a few blocks...the canals are so unusual for California...Looks like Venice Italy shared a part of its charm...only thing missing was the gondolas !

column2: One of a kind; not to be missed
column3: A perfect set up for a morning walk in between coffee stops or after breakfast. Don't limit yourself to the (infamous) boardwalk while in Venice. Together with the "walk" streets, this is the way to see the real Venice (and why it is called this way!).
Great place for a stroll. Very unique little out of the way neighborhood. Beautiful homes situated on the canals with multiple walkways, and bridges. Very peaceful and tranquil

Venice is not my favorite beach in the Los Angeles area. However, the canal walkways are worth seeing if you are ever in the area. You walk on a narrow sidewalk past peoples front doors. The houses are all unique and most are colorful. It only takes 30 minutes to accomplish as it only runs a couple of blocks.
A very beautiful area not to miss. Very peaceful atmosphere with nice houses. May be dangerous for children.
I'm staying close with my son and just love walking along the canals, it is hard to believe you are in LA, ducks/squirrels and water birds greet you everyday

column2: Beautiful and peaceful area to stroll around in
column3: I was quite taken aback by how lovely these canals were; the colourful houses with their beautiful flowers will make you envious of those that live there. It's a beautiful area to get lost in and just enjoy walking around, away from the hustle-and-bustle of Venice Beach itself. Very tranquil.

If you're in the area and you want to adventure past the beach, this is a nice scenic route. You walk past the houses on the canal, each of them unique. Of to little turns and bridge ways. The day we were there is was very quite but still a few people walking around. Not far from the beach so worth a little adventure.

column2: A short stop before the beach!
column3: The Venice Canals are 15 mins from the Venice Beach. There are 4 canals and they are all worth of pictures. The whole walk plus picture time should take about 30 minutes.Tip: Go during the week between 10-3pm. Park in Dell street.

Surprisingly tranquil & beautiful oasis right near over-the-top Venice Beach. A lovely way to walk from our hotel in the marina to the beach, admiring the beautiful homes and lush gardens, before hitting the frenetic Ocean Front Walk. To get there, head down Washington Blvd towards the beach and take a right just before crossing the Grand Canal. It's not Venice, Italy, but the water is cleaner and the weather is much, much better!
Interesting canalside architecture of many wellkept private homes.pleasant and relaxing stroll contrasts with much of LA.

This little slice of heaven came outta nowhere! I was biking and exploring the busy Venice Beach area. But decided to take a small detour not expecting much... But immediately the colorful loud atmosphere died away completely and I spent nearly an hour wandering around this area... Dragon flies, ducks, flowers of every color, and the most beautiful houses you can imagine. I went on a Monday, and only saw a handful of other people, not sure if I'd enjoy it as much if it was busier, the paths are very narrow.

I went to see the Venice Canals because last time i was in L.A. i didn't have time to see them. I was quite skeptic about them. I must admit that they are very nice. I was expecting a bad copy of the italian canals in Venezia but not at all. They are very nice, with beatiful houses and with their own identity and personality. We spent almost 1 hours strolling on the canal side looking at the houses and the gardens. It's a great alternative to the mess of Venice Beach.

The stroll through the canals were awesome. Very impressive homes, great flora, there are ducks all over. The only down side is that because of the drought the canals are down and there is literally not enough water to ride canoes or kayak which would make the view so much exiting. We spent about 45 minutes walking. You have to park your car and then walk along the canals. Parking is not easy to find.

column2: Worth the short walk from the beach
column3: If you go to Venice, don't spend all of your time at the beach or on the boardwalk--venture a block inland and take 20 minutes out of your day to stroll up and down the canals which frame a unique neighborhood. The canals abound with photo ops between the peaceful canals to the impressive and expensive houses which line the waterways. Our walk through the canals was the highlight of our afternoon in Venice.

column2: Such a Romantic location in a busy city!!!!
column3: Me and my wife went to Venice canals and walked for almost 2 hours and I really loved it and loved how the walkways are decorated. I recommend those walkways for every couple. Just walk carefully because cycling is allowed and you don't want someone to pump into you with a bicycle.

Well worth the visit on your next adventure out in LA - Venice as the name suggests - is just like Venice in Europe - and in the pas - before the introduction of cars - there were even more canals! We spent a couple of hours just walking around taking photos in this beautiful piece of LA! Enjoy!
we was been there and it was really nice before we saw the sunset in the beach. Kind people, and good lovely felling :)

column2: A quiet hour in hectic LA
column3: walk along the venice canals and treat yourself to a serene stroll - an unusual opportunity to find quiet and serenity in hectic, gogo LA -

Step away from the busy beach walk and a few blocks away you have the narrow, calm walkways in this residential area. We saw beautiful (and some not so beautiful) houses, people waking, and hummingbirds. Not a place to jog or speed walk: the pathways are too narrow. But ideal for an after dinner stroll

We had a fun time strolling along the paths bordering the Venice canals admiring the lovely houses and grounds and watching the ducks and other water birds. The experience made me want to move to the area so I could enjoy this charming walk on a regular basis. Parking is a bit of a problem, but we finally found a space on a nearby street.

column2: Nice and especially nice when Christmas lights are out
column3: Walked along the canals a couple times with family. Very quaint and picturesque. Houses are mostly lovely and walking along the canals makes you feel like you're someplace else. We went around Christmas time and the lights just added to the charm.

column2: Beautiful stroll which should not be missed.
column3: Since we stayed close to the Venice Canals we incorporated them into our daily morning walk. It is such a pleasant walk along the canals viewing the beautiful homes. One can do a quick walk from Washington to the end and then walk to the Venice Boardwalk which takes you to the Pier or to Santa Monica which can be quite the hike. As you stroll along the Canals make sure to cross the bridges from side to side to get a good view from both sides. This is such a pleasant way to spend some leisurely time. Do not rush. Take in the beauty of nature, the canals, the gardens and the lovely homes that the owners take such pride in their upkeep. This is a beautiful treAsure in the Marina del Rey and Venice Beach.

column2: Not so good with a bike
column3: I visited the canals during a bike around Venice Beach. Unfortunately you can't take the bikes along the edge and there aren't a lot of places to lock them up. The bridges over the canals are also very steep to try and cycle over so you have to push them. And avoid the tourist buses that take up most of the road.The area itself is lovely and peaceful, especially after the Boardwalk. Worth a walk, but leave the bike back in Venice.
Beautiful place in the hart of the beach life. It is a point of rest when you are coming from the boulevard with all the people who are showing themself.

LOVE the canals, a true walking area in LA. I don't like to say too much, because the best thing about it is the tranquility....but must share. It's great to stroll and look at the homes done in all different styles, say hello to the ducks and then walk 5 minutes over to the ocean.

We didn't even know these beautiful views existed until a local told us to wander back there. It was so nice to see these canals and the houses on them were so unique and interesting to look at. Each house was different and so cool to see. Just a few short blocks away from the beach and totally worth the energy. Highly recommend!

column2: Interesting quite neighbor near popular attration
column3: So everyone knows about Venice Beach, but not many people know about the Canals. It's interesting neighborhood that you can walk around. Not much to do but to just take in the view. It is pretty quite and peaceful here.

column2: Cool walk to do if you are in Venice area
column3: Very cool to find these canals in the middle of a neighbourhood, just a few blocks from the beach. Worth going while you are visiting Venice beach.
Really a beautiful gem in LA! Worth spending hours looking for a parking space and walking! Make it part of the day in Venice and plan the day accordingly. Very romantic and quaint.
Venice canals are very beautiful to walk around. You will see some truly beautiful house hidden in these canals.
Stroll along peaceful streams of man-made canals alongside beautiful homes. The area is renovated and clean. Many paths to explore. Simply a wonderful place to walk.

column2: Not what it use to be
column3: Was there in 2002 and again this year March 2016. More commercial, more places to eat, more expensive. Not nearly the entertainment, again more commercial.
Read up on the history of the canals before going. It's very interesting and adds to the flavor of what you see.

column2: Nice place to walk and watch
column3: Quiet area. Not a lot of people in comparison to the other areas of Venice Beach. We enjoyed walking through the neighborhoods. One thing to note is that the walkways are narrow in places. Some areas had landscaping that had grown out over the side of the walkway. We had to walk single file in a couple of areas. Lots of flowers to see!

This place is definitely hidden within the neighborhood, but it's a gorgeous place once you find it.Some of the homes, lining the waterways, are beautiful. I have yet to go out onto the waterways myself, but will have to go back and try it out.
I've spent 2h walking around the Canal. It's amazing, you think all the time that a fairy will show up to great you. Photos from the bridge are a must!

column2: A fun walk near Cow's End Cafe and C&O
column3: stroll the canals, up and over bridges, enjoying the water, boats, and lovely little homes that line it. An interesting, pleasant, easy walk.

column2: the only redeeming character left in Venice Beach :(
column3: At least it has a lot of murals. I used to live in VB, its not the same place it was 10 years ago. Hurry and see it before its character has been killed and left to dry in the sun on its immense sandy beach. Long live IVR!
Very unique and pretty little neighborhood, a little tough to find make sure you have good directions.

I've seen the Venice canals on TV shows and wanted to check it out for myself. Only a few minutes away from Venice's muscle beach, it was a fun walking trail to check out the flare of the neighborhood and see some cool, modern-style homes.

column2: So much fun for the family
column3: The Venice Canals are such a treat. We love to part on the far side of the canals when heading to Venice Beach; less crowded parking and we get to walk through the lovely canals! What a great start to a fun day!

column2: Calm walk away from busy Los Angeles
column3: We originally found the canals almost by chance and loved walking round the canals, across the bridges and looking at all the different styles and sizes of houses. Since the first time, we always seem to do a little walk every time we visit LA.Everyone we have taken there has lived it too - it would be amazing to live there - other than people walking round trying to look inside your house and garden.

column2: Beautiful Place to stroll- not to bike
column3: It's a beautiful place to stroll around and look at the beautiful canals. However my friend and I tried to take the bikes we rented on the beach onto the canals walkways and it is very had due to the thin pathways and the fact that the Borges are very steep. All in all, it is a beautiful experience.

We walked the canals on the first morning of our trip to L.A, and were really glad we did. It's probably not one of the first things you'd think of to visit but it's well worth doing. Lots of unique buildings along the banks, great picturesque bridges to take photos on and a really cool atmosphere.

column2: Stroll around as a nice tranquil break
column3: This is a great place to stroll around on a sunny afternoon, Hard to believe its set in the middle of Venice. You will bump into handle any people but see a lot of ducks and geese.

I was in Venice in Italy so I wanted to see how this part looks like. It is really beautiful. There is so many different kinds of flowers and boats. It is so colourful and white bridges make it so elegant.
Check before you go. The powers to be control the water level to the canals. When I was there it was not very pretty and they were harvesting green seaweed.

column2: Remote but worth a visit (if you got time)
column3: Remote and very quiet walkway with the look of Venice. Nice place to take a leisurely stroll but nothing much to do in my opinion...

Some people - like me - are too poor to go to the real Venice across the Atlantic so we settle with imitations, but hey, this is pretty cool too! Modeled after its namesake with its own SoCal flair, this charming canal-filled neighborhood is definitely a pleasant, interesting experience to walk through.Park your car just outside the block and walk across the bridges to pass through canals. I guess this is slightly better than its Italian counterpart because it's much more organized (rectangular areas organized by straight canals) and clean (no smelly canal) but maybe I'm just saying all this because I am a hater and want to make myself feel better for settling with this SoCal imitation! Before we engage in a Venice, CA vs Venice, Italy war, I would like to conclude that this photogenic area is definitely worth checking out, whether you have been in Venice Italy or not!Please please please be considerate that this is a residential neighborhood so don't be a loud tourist like you would in the real Venice Italy - at least that's what I envisioned the real Venice to be.---By the way, the famous Venice Beach is just a short walk away from here, so why not add the beach on top of your canal stroll too? I definitely know the real Venice doesn't have a dope beach.

column2: Beautiful place not to be missed
column3: Picturesque area. The walkway gives tourists opportunities to take pictures of the houses by the canal. The only drawback is the walkway maybe narrow if more people like us want to take a stroll alone the canal. There is not much to do there except taking pictures.
The canals in Venice are a beautiful place to stroll. There are many bridges over the canals and the surrounding homes are very interesting

column2: A Must see (Walk that is) if you are at the beach in Venice or Marina Del Ray.
column3: I walked in the canals in the 70's and it was a smely mess there. Today it is beautiful and the homes are all in the millions

It may have been a sight at one point...When I was there the area seemed like it could benefit from abit of upkeepWater is abit dirty and buildingd all abit oldPerhaps it was the overcast weather that day but the scenery did not impress at allIf u are passing by the venice beach area u can drop by but dont expect it to blow ur mind away
Great place to go for a peaceful morning walk or run. Nice views and very few people around. Enjoyable.

Away from the brashness of the Venice Boardwalk, the canal walkways are quiet and serene. The houses here are beautiful, and you might just spot hummingbirds visiting the colorful flowers in the gardens :-)

column2: A Unique Part Of The City
column3: Having briefly visited the Canals on a previous visit some years ago, we were keen to return and spend more time on the Bridges and Walkways. It was interesting to see how the arrival of bigger net worth residents has pushed some of the properties to a higher level of structure, although some of the earlier buildings still remain. However, the fascinating feel for the area still remains. Take a walk down Dell Avenue and over the four Bridges to enjoy stunning views.

This is a beautiful neighborhood by the canals. Many beautiful homes with nice garden.I keep hearing sirens at night, not sure if its police or ambulance? I was a little worried, however, my friends said it is quiet normal for cities in USA...!!!???.

The Venice Canals is romantic any day all day long. I recommend you read about the canals before you visit them because it is still a residential community so there is no visitors kiosk or anything like that. Be mindful to not trespass on private property 99% of the home are private residences. Please research how best to tour the canals to maximize your Lovely, lovely, lovely experience.

We stayed in an airbnb in Venice and I walked the canals and other neighborhood walkways every day. Cottages and waterfowl and boats and all the vibrant gardens of southern California. Yes, canal water came seem murky at times (don't think I'd swim in it), but the area never lost its fairytale appeal, with arched bridges and reflected palm trees.
The Venice canals are actually canals of sitting water collecting smelly pond scum in the LA heat. The houses are the highlight of the walk. Why anyone would want to live there is beyond me.
We discovered the canals a few years ago,and just love walking and looking at the different architecture. It is a feast of excellent ideas, as well as a very zen experience.

column2: bring a big bag of seeds!!
column3: fun place to feed the ducks, walk close to the water on relaxing little pathways,house dream and take pictures galore on all the little bridges. safe for even little kids.

After walking from Venice Beach to Santa Monica and being accosted every couple of minutes by people asking for money or to listen to their music, it was calming to walk back via the Venice canals. Gorgeous houses along the canal add to the beauty of the place.

beautiful homes and a great place to take walks and enjoy nature! you will be walking in between actual people's houses so I recommend staying away from their yards and keeping the noise level down! but its definitely mesmerizing!Plus there is a lot of restaurants nearby and walking distance from the beach!

column2: What a rare treat in the US!
column3: Luxury and large homes sitting on a planned community reflecting the peace of the canals and water reflections.

So Venice boardwalk is good for people watching, but to get the grungy feeling off of your poor bodies, take them down to the canals where one could have much time to kill walking many cute bridges near adorable houses. I went to see where Ray Manzarek and Jim Morrison use to live (just Venice really) , so if you like rock n roll, then roll on down! "Blood stains the roofs and the palm trees of Venice!" - Jim Morrison

We were pretty underwhelmed. Possibly we were tired, having just walked here from Santa Monica Pier, but we didn't really see what the hype was about. It wasn't at all as beautiful as Venice, in Italy, it was more like the canals in East London; but with better weather and more canal side detached properties. It was pleasant to walk through, but not that exciting. Enjoyed the walk down the beach more.

I strolled through on a winter weekday afternoon. Completely serene and plenty of parking, though I wouldn't be surprised if it's a different story on the weekend. Many styles of houses and all kinds of water fowl. Definitely a different side of Venice.

column2: Take a Tour of the Venice Canals
column3: Last July took a guided tour of the Venice Canals and the Venice boardwalk. The tour was a two and a half hour walk through the history of Venice and the building of the canals. Summer is a perfect time to take the walk, enjoy the beach and learn some history.

We never did find a place to park but drove over the bridges a couple of times to look over to see the homes and canals. This is a beautiful area, would be great to walk around to see more closely.It is rather hard to find, but with GPS you can be guided.
A must see during your time in Venice, within walking distance of the beach, hidden gem indeed. Very quiet neighborhood surrounded by beauty, the canals are amazing to see.

It's quite hard to believe that the Venice Canals are just a stone's throw away from the bustle of Venice Beach. But these canals, lined by quaint and unique homes are a great place to walk and take some time out to see a different side of both Venice and LA.
We heard a lot about the canals but didn't think they will be this awesome. Very neatly aligned homes at the sides of the canals. Make sure your camera is on. There is a photo waiting on each step
We read about the canals but never imagined they would be as cool as they are. Tucked away in Venice, CA this destination is complete with quaint wooden bridges and beautiful homes.

Highly recommend making a visit, though be aware that parking is not easy to find. Not a terribly large area but good for a leisurely walk to soak in the interesting details. Certainly not something one expects to find in the area. If you only know Venice for its boardwalk and beach, then this will be a pleasant surprise.

one of my favourite parts of LA. On Sunday morning if you don't have good plans go to Venice beach, enjoy the sun and after take a walk in the canals. you will discover amazing homes and beautiful gardens hidden in the canals...
I really loved seeing this area. We spent about 40 minutes here. It was nice before dusk and after it got dark. Romantic and pretty little area.

We went here right before exploring Venice Beach..really peaceful and serene I would say a must see as far as tourist attractions. Really cool houses that line the canals with funky bridges connecting them. A short walk to Venice Beach we just Ubered there then walked to the beach.

column2: Lovely way to waste a couple of hours
column3: Just a nice, peaceful way to waste a couple of hours walking the canals and daydreaming what it would be like to live in one of the houses. Then after you can saunter off for a casual drink at one of the local bars. Bliss.

column2: Great activity if you are on the Westside
column3: We love coming here and strolling around a bit. Nice to see the setup and the houses. I would budget 60 - 90 minutes. You may have to park and walk a bit to get there.If I were not on the West Side of LA, I don't think that the canals are worth a visit on their own
The view is actually just repetitive but it's nice for an early morning or afternoon stroll. The houses are quaint and lovely. A few pictures around the area is recommended as well.
It was very nice to walk along the quiet canal away from the road and sound. Enjoyable walk looking at the beautiful houses along the canal.

column2: The other face of Venice, beautifully quiet and peaceful
column3: If you go to Venice don't miss by any reason ta walk through the canals! It's amazingly nice to observe all these different one to the other houses
I wouldn't aim to spend a whole day there but it is a beautiful area and we'll worth a visit if you are staying in the Venice area. The houses are lovely and you can get some great photos.
We came across the canals and enjoyed wandering along the edges. It was a surprise find and really pretty.

My sister and I were looking for something to do in the area and we fell upon this recommendation. Using google maps we found it quite easily. It is interesting walking around especially having been to Venice Italy. The only drawback of the walkways is that I felt like I was trespassing as we were walking behind people's homes. We were here on a Sunday afternoon and it was not busy so we were able to take some pretty good shots. It is something to heck out but I would not go out of my way for this.

The best time to visit the canals are during the Christmas season as many of the homes are really masterfully lit up and you will see people strolling through the canals. Yet, anytime is great to visit, because it is unique, great for kids (see the ever present ducks) and it is right across the street from Venice Beach which is a fun circus like atmosphere.

My wife found this walkway that I may have never have known was there without her! It's only a block or two away from the beach but is a lovely walk among canals that are aligned with unique charming homes and many foot bridges. A lovely walk you shouldn't miss when in Venice.

column2: Wonderful oasis in the hectic world
column3: I was treated with a walk in Venice Canals Walkway by a friend who lives in LA. After 4 days of conference from dusk till dawn it was magical to walk here, in nice weather and just take all the beautiful, funny, different houses and gardens in. It was around Halloween, so a lot of scary stuff in the gardens gave us a good laugh.Please take your time, enjoy the lovely views. Be aware, that the signs outside some of the houses says "Armed response" which was more scary than the Halloween stuff for a Dane like me :)

column2: A cool and delightful promenade through Venice Canals
column3: You cannot come to LA and not visit Venice, especially Venice Canals. A few minutes away from the all singing and dancing entertainment of Venice beach, lies the tranquil setting of quaint little houses bordering water and bridges that make Venice Canals a must for all visitors. Weaving in and out of its pedestrian walkways, one can encounter people and animals that share the special location that is this little corner of a Venetian type waterway engineered by Abbott Kinney in the early 1900.

We went to the venice canals expecting a nice, pretty walk before moving on to venice beach. What we found was canals with filthy, black water with a foul stench. I am not sure what other travellers saw in the positive reviews this area received but we did not see it.I would not recommend wasting time here especially with young children.

What an amazing place like a oasis in the middle of a bustling beach community I can walk around here for hours the houses are all different from modern glass houses to small wooden houses which have been there for years my favourite are the old colonial wooden ones the wildlife is spectacular must be one of the best places to stay or rent for a vacation only 5 mins from beach and fab restaurants and bars truly amazing place

I made sure we visited the canals on our second trip to LA. It was worth the 20 minute walk from our rental. Very aesthetically pleasing with the canal water, bridges, and beautifully remodeled homes.

column2: Hidden area of the beach community
column3: Get directions and visit the Venice Canals and enjoy this secluded residential area of a quaint beach community. It is an interesting area to check out if you're on the west side of LA.

column2: A little piece of Italy with a american twist
column3: Quaint location, great vibe and hidden treasure. You can walk along the bridges and feel as though you are somewhere completely different. Loved it!

column2: A beautiful respite from the very busy city
column3: Wonderful to walk through the canals, enjoy the wildlife and wonderful mixture of architecture and gardens.
I had lived here for years until I too this walk one weekend. I LOVED it. Not like anything else in LA maybe the world...

My husband heard about the history of the Venice canals in LA so we added it to our list. It is an eclectic mix of homes on the most peaceful waterways. We enjoyed walking through area! It was just a short stop but well worth it for us! It happened to be close to sunset when be arrived which made it even more enjoyable.

column2: A must for home design junkies
column3: Venice canals walkway runs through a small residential area adjacent to Venice Beach. Meandering through the area offers a close up of the outdoor living spaces of the charming homes in this dense, quaint neighborhood. Small patios, outdoor kitchens, compact gardens and a handful of architectural gems provide great ideas to take home.

I've seen the canals in movies and tv and always drawn to it. It was low tide when I took my walk, and I would've liked higher tide for pictures. But I'm so glad I found it. It was quiet, peaceful, serene. It was definitely my favorite spot on my California visit.

A local informed us about this area. An easy walk in from Venice Beach. It is only a small area of canals but we found it interesting. At present the water levels are low but it's still worthwhile. The houses in this area are all so different.

You wouldn't even know that these charming canals existed unless you were clued in - in advance. The greenery bordered canals are hidden away between in seldom used streets in Venice / LA. Fun to drive by, but so much more fun to walk the banks. See nice scenery, hidden houses and canal Ducks & seasonal birds. Fun outing while on the Westside. ...

We enjoyed having a stroll along the various canal walkways. Sometimes you could imagine your in Amsterdam or Venice but looking at all the different styles of houses and gardens, this is uniquely LA. Parking can be very difficult or costly. We paid $20 at a nearby lot but I think we saw cheaper afterwards.
Its just a walkaway which gives you a lil feel of the venice infrastructure. good for just an evening stroll if nothing else to see in LA on list
I live on the bay and this is just a walk away from my home. If you're ever looking for a nice sunset / sunrise walk this is the perfect place to go!

column2: Depends on what you like.. I find it interesting
column3: Great if you live close by or are in the area. It's a great walk with friends/family visitors. Close to Venice beach and Santa Monica where there is always something happening. Plan it out and enjoy your visit!

It's cool to walk around and see the houses.and see the canals. But it is not worth any kind of special visit. If you are close by, go for it. It's worth doing once. If not, you need not go out of your way

Great spaces for quiet, leisurely walks to see striking homes in historic picturesque settings. Thankfully, the bridges and narrow streets seem to naturally limit the vehicle traffic and pedestrian crowds, so you can enjoy the neighborhood stroll without feeling rushed or penned in.
This was not a place to visit, perhaps due to the time of the year. There is really nothing to do or see other than walk by the dirty water and peek into peoples backyards.
kinda a fun thing to see. it isn't venice italy but it is a small version. years ago the bridges went the opposite way so even if you have been years ago, it is cleaned up and a lot nicer.
Its just a nice walkway between some residential houses . The look is like the venice canals. I wont say its a must be in los angeles but for couples to spend a romantic evening its a good spot

We stayed in Los Angeles for 3 days after our cruise rented a car and went to Venice Beach to see the Venice Canals. We parked on side streets and walked to canals...the scenery is breathtaking so beautiful and the homes there are really nice...across the canals is Venice beach. We really enjoyed Los Angeles and California coast much more than Florida...IT IS WOW Cannot wait to go again

column2: Like the other Venice, there's good and not-so-good things about walking along the canals here
column3: With a name like Venice, what's not to like about strolling along the canal? Well, authentically, the smell and the neighborhood come to mind. These canals were built for the same reason as those in Italy: to drain the land. That means stagnation; hence the smell. The pathways do give you view of cute/nice houses and their fenced-off gardens. And some not-so-much: just like the other Venice.Go a half block in any direction and you'll get one or more of: down-a-step neighborhood, busy thoroughfare, upscale and semi-gated-off marina living, expensive but small apartments.Go several blocks west and you come to arguably the funkiest beach front on the planet: Venice Beach: home to the homeless and slumming center for those with with uncountable homes. With aggressive medical marijuana vendors and tourists from throughout the world interacting with those on every conceivable conveyance. A place where beautiful people go to noticeably talk with, or avoid eye contact with, the folks from the other side of the opportunity/motivation gap.Back to the point, the paths of the Venice canals offer a quiet place to stroll and to stay out of the glare of midday sun and the glare of public view.
Surprisingly quite neighborhood with a lot of fun housees. A "need to see" when i Venice. Not far from the beach.

This by far, one of my favorite places to hang out and photograph. It's tucked away in Venice, only a few blocks from the madness of Venice Beach. Once there you forget that you're in California. I love that it's never crowded, very clean, very little to no noise. I feel as though I've been transported to Venice Italy while there.

Lovely stroll along pathways, one a breast, past canal homes. We opted for metered parking after driving around for awhile, no way we were paying $15 to park for 45mins. Patience, a few quarters and we walked for an hour. Enjoyable. Recommended. Wheelchair, elderly friendly, no need to cross intersecting bridges, just meander around. Lots of greenery to look at most of it is in someone's abode. Nonetheless, hibiscus, bird of paradise, hydrangea, even found a wattle tree!

Had the place been properly managed, there would have been lots of opportunity for photography. Very few canals with hardly had any water during our visit. The bridges were covered in plastic, probably for some kind of renovation. Not many people around except for a few tourists. Just a walk from the Venice beach parking lot which charges you $9 for the whole day. Later realised that a street parking would have been cheaper.
We loved our stroll round this area. It was extremely pretty & a pleasant place to visit. There are some amazing houses in this lovely setting.
Just beautiful , full of flowers and landscaped areas . Lots of walking room , not a lot of people . Lots of Birds :)

It is fun to walk the Venice Canals imagining the great dream when they were constructed. Today, the fantasy is imagining living there in these million dollar homes. It is picturesque. The architecture and landscaping is phenomenal but I’m not sure if I would want hordes of tourists walking a few feet from my window. But if someone wants a house sitter, I’d give it a try!
This is a neighborhood and not worth getting to. A few canals which were "low water" when we were there. Probably nice enough to have a house on the canals, but not nice enough to visit.

column2: Beautifu,l and so many LA natives don't even know it's here
column3: Take a walk along the canals in Venice and find yourself transported to somewhere so much different from the rest of the LA area. Lined with beautiful homes and cute cottages, the canals provide a nice place to take a walk. You don't need to spend a lot of time here, but it's definitely worth taking a side trip if you are in the area!
Really loved taking a stroll through the Venice Canals. The homes and gardens along the way are so beautiful. Saw some kayakers and paddle boarders.. would love to do that next time!

The tranquil Venice Canals are just a short walk from the craziness of Venice Beach Boardwalk...what a difference! The original canals were built in the early 1900, fell into disrepair and filled in, then revitalized in the 1990's. It encompasses about a 9 block square area with concrete sidewalks and arched bridges across the canals.The residential neighborhood is made up of small bungalows each with it own character and many sporting lovely gardens, fountains and lounging areas overlooking the watery byways. The canals are peppered with colorful row boats tied up to the sides and giving even more of a romantic ambiance to the area.A beautiful and quiet respite if in the Venice Beach area. Take a stroll...highly recommended!

column2: How is this in the middle of Venice beach
column3: It took me about 10 minutes to actually locate this beauty... There isn't much to see, as its a residential area, but you can not visit Venice Beach and not go see this tranquil area..... its definitely millionaire paradise

column2: Such a beautiful place to walk!
column3: It's peaceful and beautiful and if you go during the Christmas holidays, beautifully decorated. So worthwhile.

column2: I Had Only Seen This in a Movie. What a Gorgeous Walk.
column3: I loved walking over the little bridges all over these canals. It is fun looking at the beautiful houses that line each one. Unfortunately, I did see some trash and sunken dinghies in the water. I would keep that area as pristine as I could.

column2: A thrill with every step you take
column3: Charm-loaded residential area like no other anywhere. Homes back and/or front on lovely canals which are home to an occasional personal canoe but mostly to ducks and other magnificent Pacific coastal birds. Many return visits deliver a new experience each time. Don't miss it. Take a half hour if you can't treat yourself to a luxurious hour or two stroll to view original style homes - elegant, kicky, mod - you name it, the Canals have it for you.

The Venice canals are a must-see if you are in the area. Free and easy to walk around (finding parking in the area might be your only issue.... park on the main street and walk over to the streets) and easy to spend time exploring. We went during golden hour around dusk and it was beautiful! We parked and walked through on our way to venice beach for sunset-- highly recommend. Makes for great pictures! Make sure you allow time to walk the many streets and see lots of them. We were pressed for time and just walked over one bride.
Nice way to spend an hour, strolling along a canal. The homes are beautiful, some of the residents are very friendly.

We cycled here from Santa Monica and were pleased that we did. It is very quiet and peaceful. A welcome change from the hustle and bustle of LA. You cannot cycle here, instead just walk your bikes at the side of the canals.

column2: The Wonderful "Must See" Canals of Venice, CA
column3: I LOVE the Venice Canals --wish I could live there! Beautiful architecture, lovely gardens, and curved bridges all make for an unforgettable experience!

We took a stroll through the canals and thoroughly enjoyed looking at all the colourful buildings, they are all different styles as well. New properties are being built by the canal side and some seem very futuristic. If you want somewhere for a slow meandering walk this is worth it. Afterwards we went to venice beach just 5 minutes away.

column2: A wonderful place for a walk
column3: Love to walk here, especially at Halloween and Christmas when houses are decorated. It is calm serene, and crossing the little bridges is fun, as well as getting a glimpse into some of the very modern houses and the few original bungalows that still remain.

Whilst it may not interest many, this area featured in a few movies and has beautiful properties along a pleasant stroll Criss crossing over the canals. Pushchair friendly and a nice hour plus stroll in a lovely environment.
this is a hidden gem off the main boulevard. Its a quaint and quiet meandering around the canals with beautiful homes, gardens and picturesque. we entered off Washington Blvd and loved it.

We thought the canals shallow and grubby, and the homes an unpleasant mix of new, neglected and run-down.People here don't seem to know how to look after their gardens or keep their yards tidy.The whole place was kind of like a trailer-trash park with water.

column2: One of the nicer spots in LA
column3: I enjoy strolling along the canals and looking at the different architecture in this little pocket of town. There are so many charming homes from cottage styles to modern ones and they all have a sweet view of the quiet canals. It's worth a stroll if you're in the area.

Totally unlike the canals of Venice, the canals of Venice, California have their own charm, house of varying sizes and styles line the canals most of them with very interesting gardens a multitude of plants, peace and quiet only blocks away from the mayhem of the Venice Boardwalk.

Stopped to have a look at this place after going to Venice beach. In contrast it is very beautiful area which was supposed to mirror the original Venice. But it got a little costly and was never finished some of it was reclaimed back again so not much of it left. But what is there is very nice and worth a look.

column2: Nice Place to Wander - Venice Canals Walkway
column3: We have been to the Venice Canal area several times. We have walked along the canals to the Pacific Ocean. We have wandered the neighborhoods (we knew people who once lived in this neighborhood). Its a charming yet funky type environment The favorite place to end a walk is at one of the delightful Venice Beach cafes.We normally take a walk during the daylight hours instead of at night.Its an interesting area. Today when we went it was blue skies and a hot day (rare for Venice Beach area).

Canals & waterway homes in LA? Sounds counterintuitive but both are here in the Venice section. Have to read about the Abott Kinney story, study maps, GPS it - & you'll find this unique section of Venice not far from the beach. Park & walk the canals for a special experience . Enjoy ....

Venice has had several incarnations in the past half century and this latest is one of the hippest. The canals have been cleaned and the nighborhood gentrified. A walk through the venice canals is like a stroll through Amsterdam, Brugges, or the real Venice in Italy. It is a charming area that is ringed with restaurants and bars, but insulated from other urban activity. This is a quiet respite from the bustle of the beach culture.

column2: look for the sign for canal walk past the mexican restaurant on Wahington Blvd.
column3: Charming area along the canals. Take about an hour to see pretty homes with beautiful gardens and whimsical sculptures
A beautiful and unique neighborhood can be viewed along the walkways of the Venice canals in LA. Many of the homes have unique floral displays that make it a must see if you are in the area.

Again I took a stopover to see this beautiful Canal setup. While walking you'd be envious of those who own their houses across canals. :)Not much to do here apart from a pseudo feel of 'Venice'.Spend some 30 minutes at the max and move on to other HoHo destinations.Yes, be polite with the locals and neighborhood.

You will not regret a walk around here, some of the houses are just stunning, yes they are mostly small but they are just picture perfect. People take great care of their properties and grounds here so there's lots to see and appreciate.
Best part of Venice Beach. Quiet and peaceful away from all the chaos of the beach. Stroll along the pathways and enjoy looking at the canals and houses

I found this through tripadvisor reviews and took an extended and Thoroughly Enjoyable nighttime stroll. This is just a neat little place - romantic too, if you're a couple. You will want to live here - however, pick an address of a modest bungalow and check Zillow before you pack your bags. If you have some time to kill and don't mind just wandering I highly recommend you budget an hour or two here.

Only in LA would a millionaire think what does this City need? Canals just like Venice and this is whats left of that crazy idea, very charming quiet just off the beaten track of the in your face Venice Beach, well worth a stroll through for about 20 minutes or so just to see yet another side of this mad City.

column2: Venice Canals Part of a Lost Era
column3: Most people who live in Los Angeles, themselves are likely unaware of this wonderful part of town, part of a lost era in the history of the Los Angeles and Venice area.These canals were once more publicized, larger (more of them) and likely more used. However, they are now a small part of Venice and pretty much an unknown delight.Unfortunately, parking in this neighborhood is so difficult as to make it perhaps not worth a special trip to Venice just to see them. There are really no "streets to walk" since the canals, themselves, are where the "normal" streets would be. They are difficult "walk" and very single dimensional. This is a very neat thing to see if in the area and you happen to stumble upon them or find a place to park. The neighborhood is extremely congested and the antithesis of what these canals were all about.Fun to see if in the area. Perhaps not worth a special trip.

Why do neighbourhoods always change for the better after I leave? When I was at UCLA in the early 1970s I had a girlfriend who leased a house here. This place was a dump surrounded by narrow, garbage infested swamps called canals. We were young and didn't care! It is completely different now, cleaned up and folksy-artsy-wealthy! And when you are done walking along the walks, if you are so inclined, you can always head away from the canals and toward the beach then turn right and head north a few blocks to view the weirdos left over from MY era! Enjoy!

column2: Basically a collection of modern houses tour on the water!
column3: This is particularly recommended for those who enjoy modern architecture and various modern house tours, but it is nicer because the walk by the water. Driving is not recommended. Park the car and walk. Great for getting ideas about house renovations, decorations, and horticulture design. Highly recommended.

This is an interesting section of Venice - quiet, residential, and you get a more intimate view of what daily life can be there. If you're in Venice, it's also a nice accompaniment to the scene there.

column2: A tranquil place to take a morning stroll
column3: This is a great place to take a quiet morning stroll before you hit the beach for the day and its simply breathtaking

Took a slow drive around the canals and found it to be a rather relaxing experience just off the heart of Los Angeles (as the car drives). Peaceful, calming and almost other worldly in contrast even to Santa Monica's laidback cool. However it resembles the real Venice canals about as much as I resemble Kylie Minogue.Also, beware, the parking lots around Venice Beach make one wonder whether extortion is actually a crime in California, disgracefully expensive if one only wishes an hour or twos stay and ignoramuses of the highest order running them.

column2: GORGEOUS BREATHTAKING BEAUTY STEPS FROM THE BEACH
column3: A gorgeous tribute to LA's creativity and culture, and a wonderful example of gentile nature and European charm. Based on the real Venice canals, this is a must see area of LA.
This is a lovely little walk and is great opportunity for some nice photos. Not too crowded which makes it better too.
Just walking along the homes around the canals has this wonderful vibe of peacefulness and calmness, just minutes from the main beach. What a gorgeous little part of LA.

Polit Venice Beach we could drive through the Venice canals area. It was worth the extra time to see the quaint neighborhood, interesting homes, the canal system. I wouldn't make a special trip to see them when in the area but if it Venice Beach, is worth the trip

column2: Enjoy picturesque walk amongst beautifully landscaped homes
column3: This is an awesome place to enjoy the ocean breezes, view gorgeous mansions and charming throwback cottages alongside canals and low bridges. The landscaping and architecture of the homes is stimulating and it adds some interest to a leisurely stroll or daily exercise whenever you're in the area. Parking is a challenge but we parked (free) on a street adjacent to Dell and walked over the car bridge to the first canal. Bring a water bottle.

Venice of the West, totally revamped since the hippy Doors days of the 1960s.. a wonderful way to spend an afternoon strolling along the canals, go and have something to eat on Abbot Kinney [names for the man who built the canals] and then drop down onto the boardwalk
I never knew there were these canals. An amazing surprise! Lovely picturesque area to see and drive around as there is some lovely houses and gardens, people look after their area here.

I loved it. Wanted to see how they coppied Venice. It wasnt close but it had its own magic. I liked walking along the canals and seeing the houses, how all of them have its own unique characteristics. It's kinda sad though that there is not enough water in the canals anymore. And above all now I've seen where they filmed all those movies and tv shows. And its free no need for a tour guide is to get there and out. Google map.

column2: Not Like the Real Venice Canal...But Will Do
column3: It was nice and pretty. I wish there were like gondola rides like they do in the actual city of Venice (Italy). The homes around is nice but too close to each other.
Unexpected little bit of beauty right in the middle of Venice. The canals had beautiful homes and flowers are were such a pretty area for a walk.

My teenage son and I had landed in LA and were headed up to Malibu. Thanks to GPS, we stumbled onto the canal area. Because I had read about the area ahead of time, I knew it was worth trying to park and look around. We drove back and forth for a bit but finally happened upon a parking spot that was legally open (not many of those, by the way). We thoroughly enjoyed taking a little less than an hour wandering around and seeing the interesting architecture and beautiful plant life. If I have the opportunity, I'd like to go back at night. By the way, I saw signs for parking that were up to $10 and several blocks away. I recommend trying to find a spot on your own first, but if you are really on a time constraint, then just pay the $10 and walk.

Not quite the canals in Venice, Italy but the walk through these canals was a treat. The homes are unique and most are beautiful. It was serene and relaxing. From here you can continue your walk to the beach. We were here on Friday and there was a great Farmer's Market nearby. Nice way to spend a morning when you are in the area.

This is totally worth the visit. I loved this place. Beautiful water ways and lovely houses just on the banks of this canals. Each are different but beautiful and has nice gardens. Lovely place to just walk about for sometime and feel the calm and quiet atmosphere.

We hired bikes and cycled down from Santa Monica. It was a little difficult to find the canals and we had to rely on our guide book to find the right streets to go down to access them. Once we were there it was like a tranquil haven away from the craziness of Venice Beach. Definitely worth a visit if you are staying in the area.
Lovely way to spend some time looking at the beautiful and funky houses on the canal. The little bridges are neat and I loved peeking at everyones gardens. Surprisingly, even my kids enjoyed it.

If you love photography deffinitly go visit the Venice Canals. Beautiful, quiet location. Amazing homes to gaze at.Every home is super unique and it's just amazing to look at the architechture. Really just a beautiful and charming little location. It's a must see when visiting LA.
this is almost secret but its one of the very special places. charming little bridges over quaint canals. A few little boats, everybody has lovely gardens.

Came here to see Venice Beach and ended up enjoying the walk through the canals. Peaceful, calm, scenic, photo perfect! We met many of the homeowners as we walked. They were all welcoming and seemed to enjoying chatting with us. Unexpected and sweet walk.

The Canals were far more sprawling than I had anticipated after viewing the location on a map. The water is clean and the homes are varied. I am a huge fan of observing different styles of homes and they have always captivated my interest. The homes on the canal did not disappoint. Skaters were taping themselves on the cute bridges, tourists were snapping pics and locals were enjoying a walk with their dog. Nice calm walk before you enter the whirlwind of the boardwalk.
A really enjoyable walk through the canals, many interesting houses and gardens to peer into. Very clean and easy to navigate. A really enjoyable and relatively quiet part of LA

My family really enjoyed an afternoon stroll along the Venice Walkway canals, passing by a fascinating mixture of the houses that line the banks. It's hard to grasp that this tranquil and beautiful haven is just five minutes away from the hustle and bustle of Venice Beach. Definitely worth a short detour.

column2: History alive and well in LA
column3: Abbot Kinney was a genius to replicate Venice, Italy and the California twist makes it a peaceful fantastic relaxing voyeuristic visit. The people are friendly. You feel like you are in Disneyland and a block over is the beach and all the crazy people on the Venice boardwalk.
Unique walk through canals for Venice. Terrible parking, but worth checking out just for the site of all of the little docks, and of course the beach itself.
A beautiful piece of peace a fem minutes walk from the beach. Walking by the canals and bing able to see the beautiful homes and gardens that surround them is a treat.

The Venice canal area is gorgeous,serene, lush with lovely gardens,sporting brightly colored architectural homes which are very expensive.Whoever heard of an architect building in a second rate area? AND the ducks are BAAAAK..quack! quack! Someone moved them out when they were cleaning the canals. I was simply furious. Who they did not move however, was a huge goose, who, on occasion, flung his wings wide so you couldn't pass and hissed in one's face for trespassing on his walkway. I knew what was coming,and took off running, But his short little legs ran faster than mine and he attacked me from behind with a good sharp, well "Goose". I looked back and he was sashaying off in the opposite direction looking around sternly for any other miscreant to award with their just deserts! There are many quaint white bridges, lots of scarlet bougainvillea, strange glowing succulents and various trees. If you are there on a weekend check yard sales (CL)on the little side streets(look on the map).You can usually find some really nice finds to remind you of this little Venice. As they say on Craig's list "be respectful of the neighbors'' and explore quietly.

If you have free time in your schedule you should visit the Venice Canals Walkway in Santa Monica. It's a beautiful neighboorhood with neat houses around a maze of canals. The walk will take you less than an hour but you will be able to see almost everything there is.P.S.Try to Zig-Zag the streets so you cand admire all the angles and routes available.

In about 1902 Kinney's dream of creating the Venice of America held such great promise, but like early Miami Beach 3000-miles to the east along the Atlantic it was ill-timed and quickly fell into anything but a paradise.For almost a century the Grand and periphery canals were not much more than empty or near empty sewers ringed by ramshack cottages.Today Kinney's grand plan has at least partially come to fruition. It is a nice walk and worth a visit.
What a beautiful neighborhood , beautiful houses around the canals ,ducks in the water ,worth a visit !

column2: Some of the most exclusive homes line the Venice Canals.
column3: SOOOOOOOO BEAUTIFUL!! Just a few blocks away from the touristy, bustling "almost anything goes" Venice Beach, and such a contrast in terms of the amazing architecture of the houses that line the canals & the tranquil environment. Almost every house on the canals has a dock & most of them have some form of non-motorized boat that they can take on the water. Thoroughly enjoyed the scenic, leisurely stroll.

column2: Unexpected Gem..So Close to Venice Beach, yet so Different...Enjoy!
column3: My partner had lived in LA some 30 years ago and he remembered it was interesting and took me when we were at Venice Beach. So close and yet completely different!A maze of canals and beautiful, cute homes, just a few blocks from the Boardwalk!It was fun to wander around all the streets and paths and admire the homes and gardens along the canals. The locals out walking dogs were friendly and it was a lovely few hours. Take the walk!

First impressions weren't great approaching the area but getting onto the little paths and seeing all the pretty houses and gardens, the bridges, the side streets, made it a really nice way to spend a couple of lazy hours wandering around. Recommended.

Walking through the canals is much more rewarding than the boats. We tried to get a boat, but they didn't have any, we didn't want to wait so we walked from the beach to Lincoln Ave. It was a lovely walk and we talked to some of the people sitting outside. Much more personal than a boat. Even our kids liked it.

I love walking the Venice canals whenever I visit LA! It's so nice and peaceful in the mornings. If you choose to walk at night (we always take a stroll after eating at C&O's) it's just beautiful to see the houses lit up! Always a great time!!

column2: Very Pleasant Place to walk. A unique experience.
column3: A very nice place to visit. There are lots of unusual and picturesque scenes and beautiful houses. The ambiance is very serene and relaxing.

column2: A world away from city sights and sounds
column3: Romantic walkways thru beautiful and unique homes spread out along these shallow man made canals. Twinkling lights are festive during Christmas and Valentines day - so be sure to bring your sweety. Some amazing flowers and plants line your walk, so be sure to stop and savor the experience. Friendly home owners and even a cat or dog to greet you. This attraction has been featured in a couple movies and once you walk the canals - you can understand why. One of my favorite places to stroll with my boyfriend - whom often just drives us over for a romantic walk. Definitely makes you dream of living on the canal with it uniqueness and quaintness.I can honestly say I love the Venice canals :)

Just a few blocks away from the seedy Venice beach are the lovely neighborhoods along the canals. Stroll along the sidewalks and imagine who could be living in these homes. Some are small beach shacks and many are oppulent, 3-story abodes.

column2: More Amsterdam than Venice but still charming
column3: Tobacco millionaire Abbot Kinney had a dream to turn this part of LA into a mini-Venice, so he had canals built over an area roughly four times what you see now. This was back in 1905 when such flights of fancy were encouraged in light of LA's burgeoning role as the American dream, and his idyllic dream lasted until 1924 when automobiles were taking over and roads were needed as a result. Most of the canals were filled in with concrete except for this small neighborhood where six small canals remain. They were saved simply because the contractor went bankrupt. I was aware of their existence but assumed they were dilapidated and wasn't all that motivated to see them until I saw them featured on a public TV travel show. It looked quite idyllic.When my partner and I strolled toward the boardwalk, we made our way to the canals quite easily right after crossing Abbot Kinney Blvd (...oh yes, his legacy continues). What's nice is that a free pathway skirts the canals on both sides, so you can stroll without bothering the residents. There are at least two footbridges per canal, each with a unique look, so it was easy to traverse the neighborhood and be a looky-loo at some of the pricier-looking homes. Gondolas of yore have been supplanted by plastic canoes, and 4th of July barbecue parties were not making me want to sing "O Sole Mio". However, I could see another sequel to "Chinatown" set here, this time focusing on JJ Gittes' efforts to trap a shady real estate developer for drowning his cheating wife. "Forget it, Jake, it's Venice."

There is nothing special when look at once but when call you movie history you may have seen these places many times before. It is nice to see many movie locations along the canal areas. But to enjoy this must go with a guide. I went on a guided city tour, and it is really fun. They explains everything.

Hard to believe this maze of canals and beautiful homes is just a few blocks from the eclectic Venice Beach Boardwalk! It was so neat to explore all the streets and paths and admire the homes and gardens along the canals. Don't miss!
Fun place.. a little Venice in LA... quaint homes..well kept gardens.Walking distance from the interesting Venice Beach.

column2: A nice escape from the craziness of the beachfront.
column3: This is a great area to just wander around and get lost. There are lots of great houses and bridges spread around several canals. This is definitely worth an hour or so to explore.

If you are going to the Venice Beach area, the canals are a must see. Have nothing to do with Venice beach and its craziness. It will be quiet, beautiful and a lot to see. You can walk most of the canal area.

column2: Escape the chaos of Venice beach...
column3: Since everyone feels the need to visit Venice Beach it's night to escape the crowds and craziness by walking a few blocks east and strolling the canals. Nice houses with beautiful gardens and bridges take you away from the beach and transform you to a little bit of "Venice". It's a nice walk and very peaceful!

Only 5 minutes walk from the chaos of Venice beach front, this is the most amazing beautiful calm little place. You won't get lost - it's only 4 parallel mini-canals - but there are lots of fascinating houses, and you can walk around all of it. Hardly anyone else doing the walk. We parked in a side street, and it did take about 10 minutes of driving around, to find a space. Then you need about an hour to have a really good look at the canals. I think it's a must see if you're in the area. I might even rent one for a few days one day - we saw a few parties who had done that. They all seem to have rooftop terraces etc!

My friend took me on a walking tour through just part of the canals walkway. She said even after living there several years, she could still get lost walking through them but if you have the time, it is worth it. The houses are beautiful. Wonderful plantings, and we saw water fowl, butterflies, and hummingbirds. No other word describes it better than "beautiful". Sometimes magical.

If you are planning on visiting Venice Beach, take an hour at the end of the day and do the Venice Canals Walkway.Walking around canals and bridges and see wonderful houses with their private gardens is a very refreshing option after being in the "crazy" Venice Beach.If peaceful, tranquility and architecture is a must for you this is the spot for a slow long walk.You can see plenty of Canals images in films and music videos with the unique architecture, different colors and the lovely pedestrian bridges connecting the streets so you can cross to the other side.The Venice canals is a wonderful place to take a stroll and feel a different atmosphere!. Bikes are not allowedDon't miss it if you're in the area ... small and charming!!

A beautiful neighborhood near Venice Beach with lovely houses along the canal. Difficult to imagine small boats parked near the houses in the center of the city. You can easily spend an hour exploring this beautiful area.

Just a beautiful, awesome place. I want to live here. I'm going to find a way, I swear. Its a bunch of cute houses along quiet, wonderful canals. These people have it made. Go walk around and see how made they have it, you'll be #jelly but happy.
Spend the time to have a look at the canal and the houses around the canal. Very unique structure you won't find anywhere else. hard to imagine the houses are worth 4-5 MM

column2: Fun little gem in the city
column3: My brother and I discovered the canals walkway by accident when we were walking to a restaurant in Venice. We were amazed at the beautiful scenery along the canals and had fun taking pictures on the bridges and walkways. we have been to Venice, Italy and it reminded us of that time - but with a hipster, California edge. It was a fun place to walk and get inspired!

column2: An unknown treasure in Los Angeles
column3: I discovered these canals a couple of years ago and return often to walk along the water ways and enjoy the unique homes and friendly folks who live her.

column2: Beautiful and tranquil away from the activity on the beach
column3: We walked here from Santa Monica Pier, and loved the peaceful atmosphere after all the activity on the beachfront walk. The canals are very picturesque and the houses that front them are really lovely. It is definitely worth walking through this area, it is clean, quiet and peaceful, and absolutely beautiful.

Do your research before you come so that you really know what you are looking at when you get here. You will appreciate it so much more. There is a lot of information online, and with just a few minutes of browsing you will be able to spot features and places from the past that would otherwise go unnoticed.Like why there is a huge roundabout on Grand Blvd with a gondola on it. That used to be the old swimming lagoon, and Grand was a major canal. I was pretty cold on the Venice Beach area itself, but just by turning a corner you are here in another place and time. Even the locals seem nice, and actually wave when you drive past.The canal area was originally much larger, but much of it was later back filled and is now gone, however remnants remain if you know what to look for. The original engineering project was quite massive in scope, but flawed in its execution. Even today such a project would be a huge undertaking with modern technology, but back then most of the construction was done by hand. Incredibly back breaking work.This is a world class historical district, and you can tell that most people have no idea what is right under their feet. When you have those discussions with people about what you would do if you won the lottery, you talk about this and that, blah, blah. I would definitely buy a house here. Just a little place on the water to hang out in and read the paper and feed the ducks. It is that nice.

This is definitely one of the places why I am so in love with this city. It is like Venice or Amsterdam in the middle of LA. Just breathtaking! Calm and romantic, so different from the loud and hectic typical LA, it is is absolutely a must visit while there. The most perfect time to go is sunset or dawn.
Much smaller, but delightful, with little ducks and all! The sidewalks are clean and well maintained, the water clear, and each of the homes lining the canals are different from one another.

If you're staying near Venice, don't miss the walk around the canals. They are absolutely stunning.We travelled here while staying nearby, and it was well worth the effort. The canals have quite a history and have been around for close to a century now. Enter at the Main Canal and then snake your way up each side of the canals for a beautiful view of the water, but also the incredible houses that line the canals. There are so many picturesque homes to see along this walk that it's quite remarkable.While it's reminiscent of Venice with the decorated white bridges and occasional gondala, don't be mistaken, this is a far more modern version, with some seriously expensive households in the area. Many celebrities live along these canals and it's not hard to see why as it's a very serene and peaceful area that's quite far removed from the hustle and bustle of the main beach boulevard.The walkways are too narrow for bikes, and you might get the occasional jogger trying to push past, but overall it's surprisingly quiet.Many homes take incredible care of their gardens and there are some wonderfully eccentric and highly decorative courtyards to peer into. I particularly love all the use of string lights and tree lamps used to add to the already magical atmosphere.If I could afford it, I'd definitely be looking to buy - but as one home reads 'eat your heart out, not for sale', and that pretty much sums it up because property here doesn't go up for sale very often.

This is a nice change from the usual hustle and bustle of LA. It's a nice quiet walk along the canals with lots of old beautiful houses. Not a very extensive walk and wouldn't exactly say it's worth a visit unless at this end of Venice beach anyways
Had a beautiful view of Canal and took advantage of the wonderful walk around the canal area. Clean and walkway was very nice.
This is a lovely walk, peaceful and picturesque. It strikes a refreshing contrast to the lively and colourful hustle bustle of vibrant Venice.
Very peaceful, there are beatiful gardens, perfect for walk after the lunch and closed to Venice beach. Nice place

column2: Lovely area of town for a walk
column3: It's lovely to walk around the canals near Venice Beach and a nice respite from the busy boardwalk. It's probably not worth making a trip here just to walk around the canals, but a nice way to spend some time if you're already in the area. It's fun to look at all the different houses and explore at your own pace.

I went with mi bike so it was a really nice ride getting there, but the canals itself are nothing special. I would only recommend to go there if you are in the zone or if you are going to see more places near.

column2: a very pleasant part of Venice
column3: This is not a touristic area. It is a quiet area, not as crowded as the Venice Beach area. The tour is well worth it and show different side of Los Angeles than the
Just a short walk from Venice beach you will find the canal walkway. Beautiful houses, gardens and tranquility of the water. A lovely stroll after lunch.

The Venice Canals are worth a visit when the area is not busy. You can take a peaceful stroll and experience a totally different aspect of Venice. The homes and gardens are interesting and it is and OK way to spend some time.

column2: So peaceful and different from the beach boardwalk
column3: So peaceful and different from the beach boardwalk it is a must-see. It will change your idea about Venice beach area. Then you may want to extend your walk to the Abbot Kinney bld where you have plenty of options for drinks, eats and shopping. You will be nicely surprised.

We found this place when searching for stroller walk friendly places. I don't remember the website who made the recommendation, and that's a good thing. Whoever recommended this should be drawn here on foot and forced to smell the water. It's pretty foul and you can tell from a distance. This place, isn't worth putting in comparison with the real Venice. Do yourself a favor and stay away. It looked kind of cool when I saw in the TV series Bosch, so I will give it 2 stars for that

It's a good walk but basically you are walking behind someone else's house that are built along the canals. The canals seem to be drying out because of the drought but this walkway isn't my cup of tea. I'd rather walk by the beach
I'd much rather take a stroll here, than down by Venice Beach. It's quieter and much nicer. It's a joy to see the ducks, the beautiful flowers, and the tranquil setting.
It's so cool how people here live and a walk through is so interesting. The various homes, the canals, and to see how people live there is pretty interesting. Makes me want to live there!

column2: A surprise to visit and walk though
column3: Not what we expected to find in the middle of Venice.These houses are located near the beach and in the reclaimed canals from the marshland Venice once was. It is fun to walk the walkways along the canal and see the houses, some of which embrace their tourist visitors with neat yards and lights.If you are near Venice Beach and want to walk along something surprising, check out the Venice Canals.

Not the first place people will think of when travelling to Venice, sure the beach and boardwalk are cool then there's the Santa Monica pier, BUT this is a sweet little stroll for about an hour away from the hustle and bustle. Nice to hear the sounds of ducks, you wouldn't think you was in LA. We enjoyed it for what it is; a nice tranquil setting that's pretty where you can chill out whilst wondering how much each home must cost! Unique little place.

column2: A different, cool kind of suburb
column3: We kind of stumbled onto this area by accident, but it was pretty cool to see what it’d be like to live in a tight neighborhood with nice, interesting homes with narrow canals as your "backyard." Several varieties of plants and flowers lined the walkways, and it was very different from most any other American suburb. Wandering around the canals for a good hour will allow you to observe some neat birdlife and be greeted by friendly, domestic felines.Within walking distance of Venice Beach. You can park your vehicle at the public lot across from the Marriott Marina Del Rey. Check it out if you haven't been and are in the area.

column2: A little on the dirty side
column3: to be fair I wasn't all that impressed with the canal walkway. The canal itself was a little green and had some rubbish in it. Overall I would have expected it to be cleaner.

I wanted to spend the morning at Venice and decided to walk through the canals after spending some time at the beach. The houses and gardens are beautiful, and it is interesting to see how each property has been built around this man-made canal system.That said, I don't think I would go back. The canals are a nice place to wander for a short while, but I didn't think there was anything terribly spectacular about them.

If you're in the Venice Beach area, remember to walk through the Venice Canals neighborhood. Vey pretty, small bridges and walkways all around, interesting houses to look at. Well worth a visit. A great contrast to the busy hustle and bustle of Venice Beach.

Absolutely gorgeous stroll along the banks of the Canals. Missed this the first time we visited Venice Beach. Tour guide didn't even mention them. Saw them on some travel show and made sure to visit this time around. Well worth it. Nice to dream of retirement here. Very lucky people living here.

I've been to Venice Beach before, but due to a parking error, we wound up walking the canals! What a fortunate error! The canals were covered with bridges, kayaks and row boats docked in front of many houses. People were out walking, kids were riding their trikes and it felt like a place in another country.

column2: Beautiful, Tranquil Walk in Venice Beach
column3: I live near here so I walk through the Canals almost daily. Spring will bring you fragrant flowers and early evenings will get you a peak INSIDE some Mutli-Dollar homes and its furnishings :-) Residents don't really mind, just PLEASE DON'T PICK THE FLOWERS and a great place to walk you dogs too. Just CURB your dogs. Easy Access from the South Venice public parking to Washington Blvd where you'll find some really good restaurants. For a good workout, just keep going from Canal to Canal and you'll log in at least a half mile on your pedometer. Simply lovely.
