This neighborhood is so beautiful. You could spend hours walking around the canals and taking all the beauty in. There are little bridges over the water, birds everywhere, and every house is more unique than the next. The houses are stunning and lovely to look at. There are little boats scattered throughout the canals. It's such a departure from the Venice beach area. Love coming here!

Read your history on how these homes on the canals were brought to today. So interesting that most of the area was filled with canals!!! Wouldn't that be wonderful!! We rented beach cruisers right from the guys in the parking lot right on the beach. Then road over to the canals and walked our bikes. No bike riding but I we didn't have locks so we tried not to take up too much of the path... And it was nice to walk the paths bath and forth then hope on our bikes and ride down the path all the way past Santa Monica Pier. I would consider renting the bikes after walking the canals next time. But the neighbors that live there seem to be fairly friendly if you're polite. We also stopped for a hamburger along the road. Overall, perfect afternoon. Do it!
If you are visiting Venice Beach than take an hour and walk around the canals. There are some very interesting houses to see and just a nice relaxing walk to get away from busy Venice Beach.
Beautiful place to roam around, checking out the houses. Very peaceful, even though it is so close to the mayhem on the beach !

column2: Scenic beauty within the city limits
column3: Very close to Venice beach,, 10 mins walking... this place is a 3 by 4 blocker set of roads with a stream going in the middle and surrounded by beautiful houses... Best done by walking on the 4 brick bridges and then perpendicular to the lanes in front of the houses.. Must do .. especially for some great pics....

This is the best reward for your effort to walk along Venice Beach. Great homes and a very pleasant stroll. Venice beach itself is a bit kitschy, but seeing this idea of Abbot Kinney still alive an pumping is pretty kewl! I am a Los Angeles local, and enjoyed seeing this very much. There is a parking lot that is CASH only nearby. We paid $8.00. In fact, Venice in general is very old school and is a cash only place. Be prepared.

We went to Venice to buy touristy t-shirts for a family member living overseas. Before we left Venice I wanted to find the canals and see if it was worth walking around. Don't go here thinking you are going to find Venice Italy. This is So Cal and the canals with the homes are beautiful. Very quaint and unexpected find away from Ocean Ave and the weirdness. We really enjoyed it. So many of the homes were fully decorated for Christmas. Each bridge had a theme. A wonderful neighborhood. I wish I knew someone who lived there so I could visit more offer.

column2: This is how it should be
column3: You have to see to believe how beautiful and stunning this place is. Very similar to Naples Island in Long beach. Only if I could afford to live here.
If you have time this is a beautiful place to walk through. You really feel like you're in another country. All the houses are unique. We went right after halloween so many were still decorated.
A lovely peaceful walk to view varied homes in the Venice Beach and Marina area which makes you feel in the neighbourhood.
We came here to see the canals and were belying belief with the beauty of it. It was adorable, quaint and quirky area. Everyone will find this place fun and beautiful
It is hard .tp believe that this lovely serene spot is just minutes away from cray cray Venice Beach! But then L.A. is all about contrasts!

We ended up here by complete accident because we made a wrong turn. It worked out perfectly because the Venice Canals was something we wanted to see! The houses were gorgeous and it truly felt like we were in a different country. The walkways were very romantic and the whole area just had a relaxed feel to it. The landscaping, trees, colors, and water all combine for a perfect look.
I needed to check it out and so expected it was a disappointment. They are smelly just like Venice and there are tons of Mosquitos.

It’s a charming and peaceful neighborhood and the views are pretty scenic. The views are breathtaking and an absolute delight for any camera addicts. It’s close to Venice beachfronts and contrary to its proximity this place is far better picture than the beachfront.
It was simply beautiful. I stayed in Venice for a few days during October and I walked the canals a few times, both with a friend and alone. It's nice.
Quiet atmosphere, pretty houses of various styles and standing, interesting to see the mix, not busy, that was a plus
cute area to walk in to view the homes and gardens. Great for picture taking. walkways and bridges beside and goind over the waterways.

We took a bus to Venice. The bus stop was really far from the Canals and it was hot. So many locals couldn't direct us to the Canals Walkway which was surprising. What beautiful homes and gardens. It's a short walk to Venice Beach from there.
loved it the boats the houses the peace and quiet hard to believe its minutes away from the busy beach front

After visiting the filthy, grimy, disgusting Venice Beach take a stroll to the Venice Canals walkways. I promise you you will not be disappointed. Beautiful, clean relaxing walkways connected by numerous bridges. It is a must see. You will not believe such a lovely place exists so close to the very dirty Venice Beach.
It feels like a million miles away from Los Angeles. As different as night from day. I love this little community with its canals and small homes and little bridges. I just love this place.

We didn't spend a lot of time here as we were waiting for our flight from LAX, but took the opportunity to stroll around here. The homes were close together, but still pretty large. Not much lawn, but the number of roof-top patios made up for it. Many varied styles of homes, which created a nice eclectic hodge-podge community. Like how there were bridges connecting areas so you could walk around. Enjoyed seeing the boats berthed at the homes, and could imagine the residents paddling around the neighborhood. Would love to come back and see more.

column2: A complete contrast from venice beach
column3: After walking along the beach, i expected the Venice canals to be similar, full of tourists and a bit tacky. How wrong could I be. We spent a good hour walking around the canals, looking at the beautiful homes and hardly saw another person. It's very tranquil, peaceful and pretty.Definitely take time to wonder around, take some pictures and explore this pretty neighbourhood.
It's a wonderful contrast to the happening Venice Boardwalk. The area has been featured in many movies and it's a nice stroll in the area.

column2: Fantastic area to walk around! Not to miss...
column3: Fantastic area to walk around. You should not miss it. They are listed on the National Register of Historic Place and they deserve this designation. You need to walk the sidewalks, cross the bridges and really discover the neighborhood. All the houses are delightfully different, a mixture of architectural design. The canals are the perfect settings for all of them. One of my favorite places in LA.
Highly recommended for a visit.Charming place.Peacefull and quite.You get a feeling that you are in a small place not a big city.Very pictures place.

Super charming canals.A quick walk from Venice beach.It feels like a small town away from Los Angeles.Some people even have boats tied to their back yard on the canal.It is mostly private houses and besides the bridges and designated walkways there isn't anywhere else you can really walk.I would stop by here white visiting Venice beach for sure!!Really cool street art along the back alleys as well. A photographers dream!

I had read about these prior to our L.A. trip and was intrigued. It's worth it if you are driving to the beach nearby. These walkways are just south of Venice Beach and you may find on street parking nearby and then walk through the canal walkways to the beach. They extend several blocks and the canals have 'docks' with paddle boats and kayaks. You walk over bridges to get to the connecting sidewalks. It appears that many people are creating extravagant gardens and some places even have rooftop decks to look at the ocean. It is not tacky - it's quite charming and unexpected. Worth a look if you are nearby!

column2: Very Unique Walk (When the Water's High Enough)
column3: It's a nice, quiet respite from a day at the beach. Some nice views and unique houses. The water was very low when we visited, so it wasn't as nice as it could have been. Overall, it's worth a few minutes.

column2: Great companion to the Venice Beach walk
column3: Pair the canal walk with the beach walk and you have a good combination. The canals are more sedate and calming. Definitely worth a visit!

Enjoyed the Venice canals they were so pretty and the little chocolate box houses most fascinating. I hadn't realised this little treasure was tucked in behind Venice beach and it's eclectic mix of people.

column2: Perfect sort of Holland in LA
column3: With our friend who lives in Venice we did our own tour. Since he lived in Amsterdam for years he could understand that this is a pretty odd sightseeing tour for Sutch people in that big city of LA. It shows the many faces the city has and how different areaa are. Also what a city can donig developments are taken seriously. Great for the people living their, for business, tourists, citymarketing etcetera. Great place to be!
Be sure to walk around through the canals!! LOVED it!! Such a cute area with unique homes and gardens to see. Well worth the quick detour! Very picturesque! Highly recommend if you are in the area!

column2: Def worth a visit if your in the area
column3: I recently stayed a couple of nights in Venice beach, waking up one morning to a very grey & cloudy sky I decided to go in search of these canals, having read about them. After a bit of trouble finding them, I was pleasantly surprised at what I did find, the canal area was very pretty and very quant. Def worth a look If you have time to spare.

so glad we managed to find these canals. it was only by chance we came acorss a pathway that led into them. People didn't seem to know where they were. Perhaps its a bit of a secret and I can see why, because you are walking past peoples gardens. So pretty.

Wandering through the narrow, cute bridges and walkways, we saw many nice bungalows with well kept gardens. There were also a few canoes on the canal. We also came across many joggers and owners walking their dogs, enjoying this tranquil patch of paradise. After the walk, we headed to the Cold Stone shop just across the road to have icecream. What a nice outing

This little piece of Venice in California is a must see! An oasis of small pedestrian bridges over channels, in front of beautiful Californian architecture, flowering and fruit trees. Everyone owns a paddleboat of some kind (row, canoe, kayak). Pretty amazing.

column2: Very nice, but not worth a special trip
column3: Venice beach itself is very tawdry, hardly worth a walk through. The canals are beautiful and very well kept, but don't take more than a half hour to walk through. Hardly worth the $25 to park (this was on a Sunday afternoon, perhaps cheaper during week or off season?) I would come back with out of town visitors only if driving by on way to some place else (Getty is near)
Beautiful place.. Perfect place for an afternoon stroll..My parents loved it ! I highly recommend for a family vacation
We were so happy to find these canals!! Off the well-beaten Venice Beach Boardwalk path, we found these winding trails refreshing. Lots of picture ops and very enjoyable.

After the huge letdown of Venice Beach, my expectations weren't high, but this was one awesome walk! We had such a great time strolling leisurely down the paths with beautiful homes on one side and the canals on the other. A very enjoyable afternoon and completely free!

column2: Cute but dont go out of your way.
column3: If you happen to be in the area then by all means have a small wander through this area. If not it is not a big deal to skip this part of town. The area before it is a little creepy so be wary. Wish we could take a ride in the gondolas which i thibk are just for show.
This is a nice little walk nestled around the canal and beautiful swanky homes , perfectly manicured. I enjoy walking here early morning or near sun set , a nice break from the busy boardwalks .

column2: Do not disturb these peoples privacy
column3: Yes it was great but I felt a like a voyeur. You walk along these small sidewalks looking into their backyards, terraces and into their living rooms. Even more tourists would destroy the magic of this place...

column2: Cool but nothing like the real Venice
column3: If you've never been to Venice, Italy, the Venice CA walkway is cool. Unlike the Venice in Italy, the walkways in Cali really don't go anywhere unless you actually live in the neighborhood. The walkway cuts through residential areas and often lacks upkeep.

Amazing canals in behind Venice Beach in Los Angeles, quaint houses with beautiful gardens, we even saw a swan swimming around the canal... we even meet one of the home owners out in her garden with her cat, such a wonderful experience. Lovely bridges to walk over... certainly I would visit again. Just such a contrast to the beach only a block away. Sheer charm and beauty.

column2: Beautiful - pictures do not do this place justice! It's awesome!
column3: This place was utterly enchanting. Take your time to walk around the canals - the architecture, gardens, landscape, everything is just beautiful. It's a great place to spend a few hours strolling around.

You just don't expect it. But you get directions or someone who knows takes you there and then you have this walk into a wonderland of creative archetecture and gardens. There are countless viewpoints where every house has a different style. And every block has the old and the new. A quaint bungalow with beautiful gardens is next to a ultra modern with a minimal, but appropriate landscaping. And all of these houses are within 5 to 15 feet of where you are walking.And all are on both sides of the canals.Just a great visual and relaxing excursion in the Santa Monica/Venice Beach area.Not to be missed.

Walking along the canals we passed lovely houses with gardens of roses. The paths over bridges along the canals are great walkways, shaded by trees and bourganvillae. They reminded me of Amsterdam's canals, rather than Venice. great photo spots.
Such a romantic place to visit. Beautiful houses by the canal and totally unexpected in LA. Really pretty place

Totally worth the visit. I never imagined such a beautiful, serene, calm place existed in LA!!Amazing place to spend a nice afternoon/evening.This walkway is just behind Venice beach and can be easily missed if not seen before. Credit to my local friends who discovered it by chance!!
It feels almost like walking in real Venice in Italy. Beautiful and gorgeous gardens lots of flowers. Really narrow paths and bridges but feeling is so great there:) definitely must see experience.

column2: Beautiful houses and character surrounding canals
column3: I visited the area and took a walk through the canals. There are bautiful homes surrounding the canals with an interesting mix of eclectic and artsy styles. If you are in the area, it's worthwhile to go.

Tucked away from the busy Venice beach area are these wonderful canals,so quiet and peaceful fronted by lovely houses with immaculate gardens.Picture post card lovely and well worth a visit if only to get away for a few minutes form the noise and bustle just a few hundred yards away.You will need a map to find them or ask one of the locals for directions
Absolutely ingenious planning! The canals are breathtaking! Would live to see this at Christmas! Lots of artistic landscaping!
There is nothing spectacular about this place. We visited in the afternoon, so it is possible that it is better at night, but I doubt it.You may wish to skip the place. Not worth it

The Venice Canals are beautiful! Such a pretty and enjoyable walk along the path and across the many bridges! Everyone's property is different with unique homes and different flowering tropical plants and flowers in bloom. It was gorgeous! Well worth the time!

I first found out about this place on TripAdvisor, and couldn't wait to visit there. My parents and I first went to Venice beach, which was too crowded and not clean, we were kind of disappointed.Since Venice Canal is only a few miles away from the beach, we didn't hold our hopes high for it. I drove into this neighborhood, with houses built very close to each other, narrow streets and few parking spot. After we parked, we walked to the place, it seems like another world after entering the area. Distinctive and well-designed houses along the little canal, you can tell the canal was artificially built, very shallow, but certainly makes this place fairy tale like. It was very quiet, various sorts of plants decorated the houses and walkway. It's very romantic as well, with vintage bridge crossing the canal, and its image reflected very clearly on the surface of the water. This place is like a beautiful picture in real life.Big thumb up for this place.

The Venice Canals are breathtaking! Photo's do NOT do this beautiful place justice. Its so peaceful and tranquil. I bought a little bottle of champagne from the liquer store next to the canals and walked through the canals NEVER FEELING HAPPIER. I found a place to sit and put my feet in the cool water, listening to Fiona Apple on my Android phone.. the gongola's were so cool, I saw a couple paddling. I felt like I was in Madonna's video LIKE A VIRGIN! .. there are many beautiful flowers and bungalow's...I wish I was so fortunate to have money and live there.. The only fall back was the homless people. They do not bother anyone but I feel they should be in mental hospitals, NOT in a place that are peoples homes! I can not convey the beauty of the canals.. it is even more amazing at night, all lit up.. water sparking.. ohhhhhhh i love you VENICE!!!!!! I get chills thinking about going back! A MUST- SEE!

We walked for over an hour up and down the canal walkways. Our teenage daughter took over 100 pictures and I took probably 50. Between the gorgeous houses, interesting birds, beautiful flowers and plants, it was AMAZING! Who would have thought this quiet place could exist amongst all of the hustle and bustle and craziness not that far away.Talk a walk - you'll be glad you did!

column2: A hidden gem in Los Angeles
column3: You won't feel like you're in Los Angeles at the Venice Canals Walkway.I visited a few weeks ago for the first time, and I was pleasantly surprised. It's much different from all the hustle and bustle found at Venice Beach. It's a serene spot that's perfect for a walk. The houses are quite intriguing as well, which is what I paid most attention to while I was there.I'm surprised this place isn't hyped up as much as others, but at the same time that's a good thing so you have enough space to walk around, as the walkways are narrow.I'll definitely be taking visitors to this place in the future. Highly recommended!

Unlike Venice Beach, this really is worth the detour. You'll find this up market area situated behind the tacky Venice Beach. It comprises around a 3 mile grid of canals with some really beautiful properties. It makes a great walk over a number of inter-connecting pathways and bridges; and, surprisingly, one that doesn't seem to attract many visitors. But it's definitely a part of LA to see.

column2: Worth an hour if you are bored
column3: Having read about the Venice area in various crime novels I was keen to see them for real. Parking in the area is a premium and we ended up on a meter which wasn't hugely expensive. The canals themselves are interesting but this is not that picturesque more unusual. There are lots of residences that have canal frontage and that's it.

This is a hidden gem of a place. Apparently there isn't one canal, there were a few canals with beautiful, unique, charming cottages up and down the canals. We just wandered around a few of the canals to soak up the beauty of this place. We arrived around sunset so as to catch some good light for photos. This place didn't disappoint. Each home along the canal was customized and just awesome. I've traveled plenty of places, including overseas, and there is nothing like the Venice Canals walkway. We were enjoying the serenity of the place but a few obnoxious people who were excessively loud ruined the peace.It's important to bear in mind that this is a neighborhood with private homes. So be curtsey and mindful to respect peoples homes. Otherwise you will ruin future opportunities for others to visit. If I could choose one place to live in California, it would be somewhere along these canals!

This area in the heart of LA takes you back in time to an area in Italy where there are also canals. The real Venice Canals in Italy are more grand but this is pretty nice for Los Angeles. Well worth the trip and best if you park the car and walk around leisurely on foot. There is lots of parking around but there are no facilities anywhere. The houses and gardens are very well kept and there are a lot of different styles of homes. The canal is clean and is not very deep. There are small bridges all over the place so you can cross back and forth for that perfect picture no matter where. You can walk to Venice Beach in 5 minutes from there. Well worth it.

The people who live on the canals do a remarkable job of decorating their homes and the bridges over the Christmas holidays. We go every year and bring friends or family. First timers are always amazed!

We wanted to stop at Venice and walk around, but unfortunately there was not enough time. Instead we ended up doing a quick drive through the Venice canals. They were certainly pretty and are something you would not expect to find in a big city. It was worth a quick stop.

It is a very pleasant walk. We spent around hour and something or two just looking around at the beautiful houses and the cute ducks swimming in the water. It is a hidden gem and it is worthy the visit :-)
Lovely walk by the canal. Loved the very different kinds of architecture and the peaceful water.Take an hour to just hang around and take pictures.

Well, not really an island since it's a network of canals. But you get the idea. All types of houses along these canals: Big, small, old, new, well-kept, tired-looking. There's some very interesting architecture along with everyday stuff. I'd love to live here but I believe I'd need to win the Lotto in order to do it.
Neat place to visit for a nice walk over an hour or so. Combine this with venice boardwalk and a nice meal and a drink on main Street.

column2: Lovely, romantic diversion from city life
column3: We visited this remarkable walkway after a long cross-country plane ride where we picked up 3 hours of daylight and really needed to walk off the plane-seat paralysis. Oh, what a treat! The canals are between Venice and Marina del Mar, about a $20 cab ride from LAX or a couple of dollars on 2 buses, if you get really nice Angelinos to direct you and a good map to enter the walkway. Once there, the architecture is a joy--from the humble cottages that were first there in the 1920's to the outlandish tudor or gothic palaces, grand mediterranean villas and minimalist glass contemporaries . Each one has a small garden and usually a dock, and as a visitor, you are almost part of their family barbecue. It seemed to me to be the neighborly intimacy of a bygone age. This is strictly residential, so no bathrooms or restrooms. But there is a superb inespensive Italian restaurant on one of the streets that border the canals, Canoli Cafe on Washington Blvd.

My husband, son and I had a great time walking around the canals. I would defiantly recommend taking an afternoon to walk around here, such interesting and gorgeous homes. Also it's a very relaxing atmosphere. We visited on a Saturday afternoon and it wasn't crowded like everywhere else in the area. After the walk we had lunch at Canali Cafe, which I also recommend their pumpkin ravioli is amazing.

column2: The quiet side of Venice is hidden treasure
column3: For an unexpected change of pace visiting Venice Beach, take sone time to wander along the picturesque canals. I admit, I was intrigued after watching the movie "Valentine's Day" and wondering where this peaceful area was in LA with quiet canals and sweet bridges. We found street parking on Ocean Ave. and from there meandered the walkways all along the canals, checking out the rear views of the many homes jammed into the area. Some of the residences have a vintage feel, others are new, modern construction. Didn't take more than a 1/2 hour or so, but a lovely respite.

column2: Romantic Walk with that special someone; bring camera; bring water
column3: They say the layout was designed after Venice Italy. I have not been there. This is a residential area. So, there is no business, no food trucks, no bathrooms, etc. This is nice place to walk and see the nice shallow water and canoes everywhere. You can spend several hours here with a loved one standing on the bridges or holding hands and walking very slow. Just keep in mind no bathrooms, no food and very few tourists. The main issue will be parking. You will have to find a place to park or pay the $15.00 or $20.00 for public parking. There are places to park you may have to walk up to three blocks but it is worth it to do street parking versus being stuck in a lot. The view is nice. The walk is easy. A few the walkway bridges are step so watch your toes if you wear flip flops. I would recommend this place early morning, early afternoon but not really in the evening.

Such a nice reprieve from the craziness of Venice beach. Beautiful homes! The canals were not busy and people walking around were pleasantly strolling. I think some of the movie Valentines Day was filmed here... so pretty :)

column2: A Beautiful Hidden Gem of Los Angeles
column3: If you see yourself as a traveller, not a tourist, the Venice Beach Canals Walkway in Venice near L.A. is a must see for you. Venice Canals Walkway is situated in a private neighbourhood surrounded with bridges, canals, and quaint homes. It is a quiet oasis away from the traffic jam and crowded tourist places in L.A. An excellent place for couples and a romantic stroll. So keep this place a secret gem before more L.A. tourists find out about Venice Canals Walkway.
We were on vacation with our 9 year old and 13 year old. We were on our way to Venice Beach and made a quick stop to walk around the canals. Beautiful.
We quickly walked through here and it was lovely. Not like Venice in Italy of course, but I dont think it's meant to be an exact copy anyway. It was very quiet and peaceful.

column2: Great Place to Walk After Getting Off a Plane at LAX
column3: The Canals are peaceful, quiet and beautiful. The perfect place to stretch your legs after a long plane ride. The Canals are about 15 minutes north of LAX. See cutting edge architecture (David Hertz, Steve Ehrlich, Glen Irani architects), fanciful architecture, 1900's era cottages, and some houses that ought not to have been built. Park on Washington, 28th, or in one of the parking lots on Venice Blvd. There is great bird life: ducks, egrets, herons, and in the winter - pelicans. After your walk, visit one of the great restaurants on Washington Blvd. (e.g. Canali Cafe, Kaya Sushi) in the Marina (e.g. Killer Shrimp or Best Western Hotel's restaurant), or on Abbot Kinney (e.g. a food truck, Joe's Cafe, Gjelina or Hal's). If you have children under 4, there is a small, charming park on Linnie Canal and Dell Ave.

This really was a hidden gem and worth the 15 minute detour if you're on Venice beach. It's an amazing area, which you really don't expect to find, the properties along the canals are fabulous and it 's so tranquil to just stroll along wishing you owned a property here.

We decided to check out the canal area based on reviews. We were not disappointed. Even the kids (12 and 10) enjoyed walking around the quiet pathways. Homes are a blend of modern and traditional. Fun to stroll around and get away from the craziness of Venice Beach.
Hidden between busy Venice and Washington Boulevards, this unexpected, peaceful enclave is a great place to walk and relax; we do it all the time, for many years now.
Peace and calm away from the frenetic boardwalk. Beautiful houses, gardens and serenity. Highly recommended

Real estate speculator Abbott Kinney developed Venice, CA. as a small city of canals. Pollution and poor water management caused city of L.A. to pave over most of the canals, except in this little enclave. Here you have funky frame shacks sitting next to multi-million-dollar McMansions -- all on tiny lots facing a canal. It's the most picturesque community in all of L.A., I think.

column2: There are canals, but a bit voyeuristic
column3: A calm walk away from the busy beach and restaurants in the area and a great way to see some of the amazing homes along the canals. Homes that are practically in the canal to some ultra modern homes seemingly made of only glass.Definitely voyeuristic at times as while your walking you can practically touch the side of some of the homes and you attract the gaze of all of the home owners in their yards, but they had to expect it as they moved there.So enjoy the experience and don't be put off walking past the endless barbecues and glass houses.

column2: Venice Canals Walkway Just steps away from the beach
column3: The Venice canal walkways are the perfect diversion from the crazy pace of Venice Beach. While the Venice Beach "boardwalk" sports a never ending stream of people from all, and I mean all, types of life, the Canal Walkway are a perfect place to escape and enjoy the tranquility of some of the most beautiful back yards you have ever seen. This combined with some of the most stunning architecture makes for an overall wonderfully relaxing experience.

Saw an Instagram photo of the canals and couldn't believe it. I was there tonight to see it with my own eyes and they were stunning! Literally a block away from the insanity that is Venice Beach, there are these lovely, quite canals with their colored boats and very eclectic mixture of homes...all stunning but different. I can't wait to return to spend more time here! A must see...and it is less than 10 mins from Santa Monica Pier.

I was recently in Venice visiting friends and they asked if I had seen the Venice Canals? As I hadn't even heard of them, let alone seen them, we made the trip after breakfast and I was simply amazed.In the corner between Pacific Avenue and North and South Venice Boulevard, which is in effect one block back from the beach, you will find the Venice Canals. If your in Venice Beach and you don't come and have a walk around, your missing something as its a tranquil calming oasis in what can be a full on side show.Strolling along the pathways along the canals, admiring the beautiful houses built along the banks and wondering who lives there, could become my next past time its so relaxing.Keep in mind as you look at, what can be quite modest sized houses, that the minimum value of these is most likely about $1 million and many are in the $3-$4 million bracket. You don't get much for your buck around here but looking at the very special neighborhood, you can understand why if you have that kind of money, you might want to live here. In a way it reminds me of being in The Keys, but smarter.If you have an hour or so to spend, do come and have a walk around, its well worth it.
It is a nice place to stroll and relax. It was peaceful and just looking at the houses and their unique structures and how some are painted is worth seeing.

Once we found the footpath to the canals we were amazed at how only one block away was Venice Beach. The two share a name but appear totally different in nature. It was peaceful to walk the canals, admiring peoples homes and gardens.

You can get a nice taste of what the canals are like with a 1-mile round trip from the intersection of the Grand Canal at Washington (near Canali Cafe). We found it to be a very peaceful (and surprisingly quiet) escape. The homes are typically quite modest looking but their location is beautiful.

column2: You've got to enjoy the unusual!
column3: A walk down Venice Beach is a true blast from the past. It is a 60's time warp with lots of 'free spirits' and gorgeous view of the beach and the Pacific ocean. When in LA, it is a must see! Don't deny yourself the pleasure of the unusual.

With its European feel and the quaint wooden bridges spanning the canals, this is a part of Venice that is as delightful as it is unexpected. You can meander the walkways over the different canals at your own pace, enjoying the scenery - ducks, foliage - as well as the beautiful homes. If you know someone who lives there borrow a rowboat, kayak or canoe for a leisurely exploration. And if you have little ones, don't forget the Duck Park on Dell.

If you are looking for something off the beaten path, unique without the weird, then take a walk along the Venice Canals. We loved the gardens and bridges and the peace and quiet. It was refreshing after a lot of time in the car getting from point A to B.

Venice is very eclectic and as you might expect full of strange characters. Its pretty much a collection of cheesy venues. We used a local docent, Johnathan Kaplan who did a great job of sharing the history of his city. It was actually very interesting. Even though the city name is "Venice" I did not associate this city with actual canals. While the main body of canals no longer exist, a secondary canal system in fact provides a very pleasant walk through a neighborhood of unique homes built right on the canal system. It is well worth the walk and a pleasant break from the "strangeness" of Venice.

My first introduction to Venice was through Venice Beach. While I loved seeing the drum circles, freak shows, and "green" doctors, this was definitely a very pleasant break from that culture.The homes along the canals are notable for their varied architecture. They are all gorgeous beach homes, and I love seeing the individual style of each house.
Lovely casual walk around the canals. This is not normally on the tourist map but well worth the little extra time.
The canals are small and sometimes littered up with debris. hopefully they cleaned this place up a little since i walked there last summer.

column2: Venice canals and the beach etc
column3: The walk along the canals is a delightful way to spend some time in the Other Venice and most of the gardens are interesting. I have always found something different to catch my eye on every visit. It is very tranquil and there are some of the houses are quite unique. Go on down to the beach and walk along the pier. The sea air is perfume to this landlocked former seaside dweller .On a clear day the snow caps are visible in the distance when you walk back from the end and if you are lucky a pod of dolphins might swim by doing their acrobatics in their natural setting. Thank heaven there are no man made ' Attractions' and canned music just the sea, the fishermen and the distant mountains.

If your tired of being in the same old environment and want to travel but can't afford it, take a bike ride to Venice Canals. It will have you believing that you have escaped to another country. That is.. if your good at lying to yourself. It is a change of scenery.

One of my favorite places in LA.There are pop color houses and flowers, but very quiet and nice place to take a walk.We had engagement photo session here.It was not sunshine day, but still very picture like location.

I was in real Venice and even though this is not exactly copy, it's really amazing and beautiful! It was very interesting walking along the canals and look at the houses and boats. They even have some gondolas there!
amazing is the word that comes to mind. very scenic and peaceful did not know this was here. great for the family to see.

It was very interesting to walk along the canals and see the homes that were there. It was a little dissappointing. The area around the canals is so built up it just doesn't have the magical feeling it had years ago.

Nice easy stroll along walkways and over the bridges. Helped work off lunch from C & O Trattoria. Lots to see and a very wide range of houses to look at. We entered off Washington and worked our way to the main Venice Beach area. The tree with all the old house lights in it was very unique and we are going to try and get back at night when it is lit up. The few residents we came across were friendly considering that they have all the tourists. Beautiful setting on a sunny Saturday on Presidents Day weekend.

column2: Not the Venice we think it will be -- kind of smelly and dodgy.
column3: This is not a nice place to walk around. It's close to questionable areas in Vencie. So it's not really safe. Go to Naples in Long Beach for a cute canals walk. Much safer and more fun.

column2: fun walk away from the beach road
column3: it's nice to take a walk through the canals and get out at the other side to come back through the beach. the canals are very nice, the houses are amazing and all that is left is to be jealous of those who live here everyday. parking in one of the small streets just before the canals start is easy, especially on Sunday. if look for the set from "californications" it's not on the canals at all... walk for a few minutes to the other side of the beach and find hank's old place in 26 Brooks Ave, and Karen place with bill on 2420 McKinley Ave.

Most of the residents know they are living in a fishbowl so they keep the lights on and drapes open in the early evenings. Nice evening stroll on a mild autumn night holding hands with your sweatheart and see all the houses that look like they belong on Architectural Digest.
great walking the canals and just admiring the homes. Nice to dream of eventually owning one of these homes. Great picture opportunities!
Been living here for years... It's calming, peaceful... An oasis from the wildness of Venice... charming and well gorgeous!

A short walk from the the over the top Venice Beach is a calming walk through a hidden gem in Southern California. Take the time, cross the many walking bridges and see homes on the canals that range from simple to special. All at cost of parking your car.
This is a beautiful way to get away from the craziness in Venice and relax. It is quiet and beautiful. Ducks for the kids to feed and a relaxing way to spend part of a Sunday.
A really nice place to walk, see some nature and watch the contrast of the homeless on the beach and the wealth of California.

column2: Do it, if you have covered everything else
column3: This is close to venice with the canal and water. But its not really worth going as a tourist place. Its an OK place, but not so impressing to any of us. It looks good in the pictures, than it really is.

We drove over the bridges at these canals & there's some pretty interestinh houses!One house looks like it's straight out of the Hobitt.Another house is made out of glass(I couldn't figure out what holds it together.This is a small area but well worth taking it in!

column2: Worth your time because of the History and escape from the Venice Beach Boardwalk.
column3: Reading some of these negative reviews is kind of funny. People give negative reviews based on their experience on the Venice Beach Boardwalk. Venice Beach is the 2nd most visited and touristy visit in LA. Yes, there are crazy people. Yes we have a homeless problem. Know what you're in for when you visit. Fri is the best day to visit both. You avoid weekend crowds/parking and the water level of the canals are at the highest level. A nice quiet escape from the madness of the Venice Beach boardwalk. All the homes are different and unique. Just because these canals are not like the Venice Italy canals, doesn't mean that they're not worth seeing.

column2: Just a poor copy of actual Venice channel
column3: Nothing special, don't waste your time here, go to the beach...It is nothing but a poor copy of actual Venice channels...

There's nothing here! Cannot tell you how disappointed I was after we made a detour to visit this 'sight' after reading about it on here.. Someone said in a review that it's a piece of Europe in the middle of LA.. coming from an English person, who's been to Venice in Italy more than once, this is NOTHING LIKE Europe, or Venice for that matter. It's got more in common with the LA storm drains!Of all the exciting places to go, and fun things to do in LA, and people are recommending this as one of the top attractions? Seriously, don't bother, it's like walking around someone's back yard.

We Were on a organized bus trip in a mini bus,we loved going over the 4 I think canals as the driver would stop and talk about ea one and give us time to take photos,who would think that this existed so close to LA.

The canals are a beautiful and interesting place to go for a walk by yourself or with a date. A staple of LA, you've seen them in movies and TV and it puts you in the feeling of being in Europe right in the middle of Southern California.
I was seriously disappointed. It's pretty but it ain't Venice! Not sure why its even on trip advisor to be honest - should we start reviewing every pretty street with same water in it?

column2: Romance in a simple walk about
column3: Beautiful walk! Butterflies everywhere! Gorgeous homes and fun site seeing for sure! Take tons of pictures!
Very peaceful to walk through the canals. Not as nice as the real Venice, of course, but really cute and fun nonetheless.

column2: Picturesque and interesting, various architectural designed homes
column3: The canals are great to visit putting some in mind of the ones in Venice, Italy. You can see a wide variety of styles amongst the homes.Walking the canals and driving through is a treat.
WOW! The homes you can glipse into while strolling along these waterways are well worth the effort, just do it!

We combined the Venice canal walk with Venice beach in 1 day.It was an amazing experience. I 've been to Venice, Italy. Although I believe they are not comparable, The LA Venice walk is Enthusiastic by itself!I recommend it if you are nearby. The architectural aspect of canals are priceless. I'm Engineer with water and eartfill structure specialty, So I can imagine the attempts to achieve this modern artificial masterpiece.

A walk along Venice Beach and through the canals is a very nice thing to do with visitors to LA. The houses along the canals are varied and interesting. We especially like to go in December in the evening when the bridges and many houses are lighted.

We took a pleasant stroll along the Grand Canal, taking pictures of the great homes and gardens along the way. We're up in age, so we only had stamina for 30 minutes going and 30 minutes back. Would have liked to see more.

column2: Good place to walk in solitude
column3: Sometimes I come here with my DSLR to take photos of random things. Highly recommend for those who are into photography, you'll find there are, surprisingly, many things here that your camera would love to capture. Also is a great place to drop by after work (if you live close by) to walk and de-stress after a long day in the office.

column2: Take a walk on the quiet side
column3: It is different than the rest of Venice, a pleasant, short walk that keeps the spirits high. You forget about the funkiness of the rest of Venice here

If you are with your sweetheart, your dogs or just yourself, this is a beautiful, unusual stroll. The care that was taken in designing this little oasis is worth experiencing once. You will marvel at how and why people are willing to live so exposed to so much foot traffic! Lovely.

Some really cool architecture in unlikely surroundings . A peaceful oasis in the centre of LA. Try and find a map to find your way around because there's not much information when you find the canals! But worth searching out!

Probably not worth the time unless you love to look at residential architecture, but if you do (and I do--just ask my patient husband), you will appreciate this charming little neighborhood with it's "Venetian" canals. As other reviewers have pointed out, you can stroll around in an hour or less, and it's a lovely alternative to the carnival atmophere of the beach.Architectural styles range from cottage to contemporary on a pretty water setting. Who knows? You might just pick up a few ideas to implement back at the ranch.

While only 10miles from LA. The drive is not worth it. The best part of our trip was taking a nap in the safety of our rental car. The canals look like a bunch of exposed sewer lines. And smell like it to boot. We decided to try and 'explore' Venice Beach. Not a good idea....unless you want to use substances to help you 'explore your mind'.Key point: Do not plan on going here. It is a TOTAL WASTE OF TIME.

This is how the area inherited its namesake after the Italian Venice but also a very quiet and tranquil area and those fortunate enough to live on the canals have something to invite friends over to see for themselves...

column2: Don't miss this on your visit to Venice Beach
column3: This is the history of something that was supposed to be more than it is, the "Venice of America." Ok, that didn't happen, but it's still cool. It doesn't take more than 30 minutes to stroll through the neighborhood of canals and get a California flavored Venice with palm trees and beautifully colored homes. I wouldn't make a special trip to the canals unless unless I was planning on seeing Venice Beach bordwalk - but that's a must see!
Park on Venice Blvd, walk in to this unique area of LA. We had lots of fun walking and gawking. Not crowded at all, and really pretty.

We recently stayed in Venice and took several walks through this peaceful oasis. Another reviewer complained about no parking, which is true, but if you are already at Venice Beach, it's worth the short walk to the canals. The water itself isn't much to look at, but if you enjoy walking, looking at pretty gardens and seeing a wide variety of architecture from humble cottages to large modern magazine-worthy houses, this walk is for you.

This is a nice quiet walk away from the bustle of Venice Beach. There are a variety of house styles along the canals to look at and various bridges to cross. There are some film locations to spot if you look them up. We parked at the top of Washington on a meter (cheap enough) and walked along the main canal for about an hour. That's all the time you'd need but we were glad we went.

It's nothing like its Italian name twin but it sure is worth the time. Take the easy tour by car across the narrow bridges or do it by bike. The latter of the two will give you a greater impression of the canals. It's not crowded like almost every nearby street.

column2: Have a look wheile in Venice Beach
column3: Better than the Broadwalk. Quiet area. But it is just houses around canals (manmade obviously). A few bridges across to have your photo.Have a look while in Venice Beach.

Turn left at the end of the Madness on ther Boardwalk go straight ahead and i am sure i turned right after 3 streets and there it is. If you like looking at houses of the rich and famous there are some beautiful properties in a fantastic location

This place is totally delightful. Take an early evening stroll through the canals to make the most of it, though. That way you see the funky people as well as the funky architecture. It feels like a walk through Robert Altman's Short Cuts, hearing different snatches of conversation and different scenes and scenarios. I wouldn't make a massive journey to get here and do this, but as we were staying nearby it made for an entertaining evening event. And such a drastic difference from what you'd expect from LA. I love the Venice Canals. I went on to read about Abbott Kinney, what an amazing guy.
Reviews on this website hyped up expectations, but all I saw was canals that were almost running dry and a few ducks wading.

Loved walking around the canals, and I guess my only criticism would be why there hasn't been more effort to make this more tourist friendly e.g. pedal boats, kayaks. Most of the boats we saw looked as if they'd not been used for years and it just seemed a shame that such a beautiful network of canals didn't appear to be in actual use.Some lovely, very arty houses in this area as well. Well worthy of an hour or two strolling along the banks of the canal.
Must see if in Venice!Very nice houses, flowers & plants.Worth going to take a relaxing stroll!Beautiful

A few meters from the sea and long beaches of Venice Beach, where tourists flock, come enjoy the tranquility of the place and you walk along the very discreet canals of Venice. Cross the small bridge spanning in white wood. Many beautiful photos to take, for the houses but also the flowers that grow in abundance in many colors. Respect the silence of places because it is a haven not yet privatized and it would have to rest on much longer. Allow an hour's walk if you want to see everything. Watch birds or colored boats, guess which star of TV series lives behind the facade of a house persimmon wood ...If you want more activities, go to the more noisy Venice Beach, a few meters away, only one road to cross: restaurants, tattoo artists, vendors of clothing or gadgets, palm readers, jewelry, incense, ice cream and improvised music by street musicians.
were not overly impressed with all the people trying to get a buck off you --- they must have smelled tourist because they ,at time, were pretty aggressive and persistant.

I never had understood the attraction to this rather eclectic, bohemian neighborhood. This place has always seemed rather seedy. You can see the houses from the bridges, but where do you park? Where do you walk? There is not a real walkway. What I have seen from the bridge is dirty, stagnant water and ducks.

This place is so unique. This is like mini Venice in Europe. The place gives us a very peaceful atmosphere and the houses are cute. The walkway is very well maintained and we walked comfortably while enjoying the calm scenery. We took lots of pictures there and have not regretted driving to Venice just to see this place.

not much to do here but walk and take in the scenery, but you are ony a couple minutes away from the walkway on the beach and Muscle Beach, and it's relaxing...wish I could live there..also you are too far from a wonderful restaurant called Baby Blues BBQ - yummy!!!! A hole in the wall that is very tasty

column2: Like an image from a fairy tale , Venice canals
column3: This is the most splendid little secret in Venice Beach so gorgeous romantic and the perfect picture to wander thru the pretty houses along the canals on our honeymoon! Picturesque scenery bright sunshine and friendly home owners wanting to chat , I'd recommend this to any traveller heading to Venice ! Brilliant , I'm going back before we leave for one last fairy tale viewing !!!
Just go there on your bike and leave the car at home. Grab some brunch near Venice Pier and you've had a perfect So Cal day.

This area is very small but beautiful. It's a great little neighborhood to walk around in and enjoy the quaint homes on the canal. There's a path between the homes and the canal you can walk. There are little gates to access the canal if you have a kayak. Very close to Venice Beach but feels very peaceful and quiet, a world away from the LA chaos. Worth a short visit.

The Venice Canals are a must see for friends visiting L.A. I bring them to the Canals and we walk the dirt walk way to the end and return down the walkway/"alley".This is a VERY SAFE walk. I've been visiting the Canals with my daughter since she was in elementary school and she's now in the 11th grade.What is impressive is the architecture and the massive sizes of the homes. They are gorgeous and my friends and I (my daughter included) fantasize about living in one of the homes. Is the water beautiful, not at all. Is it a bit dusty, oh yes.This is a FREE event, simply park at the marina entrance and pay a minimal fee a the meter ($0.75) and walk, talk and enjoy.Wear casual clothes and sneakers or walking shoes. Think hiking, but on flat ground!How do I know? I'm a native Angeleno who has lived in Los Angeles for 42 years.
It was just a very quiet retreat and so lovely to see the canals.
No where on any of our travels in the US did we feel as unsafe as here. Not very clean and not very inviting.

column2: Great for artists and laid back people
column3: We loved strolling down Venice. There are so many flea stalls and people selling their unusual crafts. It's good for leisurely shopping.

Quaint residential area off busy Venice Beach. Much quiter area that makes for an interesting walk and is in contrast to the tackiness of Venice Beach itself. Just be aware of all the duck doo on the side walks.

column2: Nice Walks, Cool History and Photo opps
column3: I enjoyed the history of the canals, not named "Venice" for nothing, and the ease of exploring them while still being close enough to the beach to not have to drive and find the near impossible parking spot all over again.One of the dozens of little neighborhoods jewels in L.A. where one can get a real feel for the popular, feast or famine, saying - "In L.A. you can make a million but not a living!"

We walked from Santa Monica pier through Venice beach to see the canals. They were worth it (but next time I'd probably call a cab)! They were beautiful! I loved the little bridges and the gorgeous landscaping! There were ducks swimming and it was so peaceful! We thought about skipping the canals and just going to the beach, but I am so glad we made the effort and visited these hidden gems!

Was recommended to take a walk & visit the canals - was so very pleased we did.The area was so unlike any other part of LA - so peaceful & tranquil - it is a truly charming area.Most of the homes are stunning & it is wonderful to be able to navigate a walk through the canals & over the bridges - a wonderful area for photos.When you are visiting LA this is an absolute must.
and very interesting architecture too ! It was cool to see all the different housing styles ~

If you didn't know it was here, you could completely miss the Venice Canals. This quaint area of Los Angeles is steeped in history, and it's a marvel that it hasn't been bulldozed down to make way for developments. There's a charming collection of bridges that allow you to navigate a walk around all of the canals. Nice to visit, but I wouldn't want to live here. It's difficult to wander around the canals, without taking a sneak peak glance through peoples front windows!

If you are visiting LA the canals can be a fun activity. If you enjoy looking at beautiful homes ~ this is the place for you. It truly is a charming area.Afterwards, you can go to the beach or walk around the trendy street "Abbot Kinney". The shopping is expensive but fun.

So much of Los Angeles is about the car, the Venice canals offer a walking experience without the car, with pretty vistas, quaint and characterful houses, and the dlight of peeking into people's yards.

column2: Take time to find the oasis
column3: Grab a map and find the canals of Venice. Walk the sidewalks, look at the gardens, feel the serenity. About 3 blocks east of the board walk.
What a great start to the day. We wandered and watched and loved the leisurely stroll through the canals and interesting homes. The weather was great so lots of fun photos.

column2: This was not exactly what I had expected.
column3: We went on a Sunday morning, which we had been told it would be real busy on Sunday. We did see the canals near where we parked and they were very pretty. We walked out onto the beach and put our feet in the Pacific for the first time. It was very pretty. Then we walked up to the main beach street. It was basically a lot of souvenir shops, marijuana shops, and tattoo places. There seemed to be several homeless type people there too. There were some people selling art they had made. We walked a long time and it was just more of the same. No one was at the Muscle Beach area. It was just not that impressive but maybe we were just too early in the day.
Beautiful surroundings and vistas to be seen. Not to mention people watching.!
A very nice neighborood with the famous canals et designed houses.
As the title says. A little disappointing but then Venice is probably best in summer.

column2: Quaint walking paths along and over the canals
column3: Wonder off the beach a couple of blocks and down one of the paths between the houses and you come across the venice canals and the gorgeous cottages from ultra modern to more traditional on the Venice canals in LA. We really enjoyed peaking into the gardens and taking in the varied architecture and colours of all the different houses, and the lovely pedestrian bridges. This detour doesn't take too long, and is well worth it!

The Canals are beautiful. Although there are only a couple left, they are such a nice site to see. Take a bike tour so that you can get a close-up view of the canals. Riding through the neighborhood over the bridges and canals is definitely a great experience. Don't miss it! Happy Traveling!
Instead of Venice go to Naples in Long Beach....those canals are simply spectacular....
We found the whole Venice Beach thing ok, but the cheap stands and regularly being approached by homeless people begging burst my Venice Beach bubble

The water on the canal looks stagnant ... but the view with the houses lining up along the canals looks nice and quite like a post card picture... but I didn't think it looks spectacular... The houses look more interesting as one muses on who and what kind of people might be living in them... But after walking around and looking at the view for a few minutes, I was ready to move on to other attractions... To me, that was very forgettable...!
One of the few places that travel brochures didn't do justice to. Relaxing and enjoyable place to stroll or sit and take in the view.

If you want to walk in L.A.'s past, then Venice Canals walkway is the place to go. You can just envision the gondolas (just like Venice) that used to run up and down the canals. Great people watching...and some wonderful, unusual homes too. Not a great place for a weekend visit as it is much to crowded....go during the week, if possible.

I went for a day trip to Venice Beach and also visited the Venice canals. It was quite an amazing sight. The houses are literally built along the waters edge, and are quite pricy from what I was told. You're able to drive over little arch bridges that go over the canals... and you invariably see a film crew along the way shooting something. It was a unique sight that you must take in if you're anywhere near Venice Beach.
Venice canals will always have a special place in my heart! It is so peaceful that I can easily spend hours walking along the canals...
This was an interesting walk along the canals to see all the different houses. Many of them were in need of maintenance, some of them were newer and modern. It was a nice stroll.
This is a walk for socially conscious people so they can see what gentrification is all about, with large "architectural" houses squeezed into tiny lots.

column2: A must visit when you are in Los Angeles
column3: If you are in Los Angeles and (obviously) are visiting Venice Beach then take a couple of hours to visit these canals and the gorgeous multi-million dollar homes around it (avg house is around $1.5M). I have traveled many places in the world and this secluded rarely talked about area is just a fantastic small yet beautiful place that reminds me of small tight neighborhoods in Japan and maybe cozy colorful architecture of London or Amsterdam. Its a fun 30 minute walk with family. We went there with our bikes which was a bit difficult to carry up and down the bridges and very tight when people were passing by us so dont do what we did lol. Also there is no way you can ride your bike as you could easily fall in the water although the water is not very deep.

column2: Great short escape, good way to walk off your meal
column3: After a great meal which included homemade corn tortillas at Baja Cantina restaurant in Marina del Rey, we litterally walked out of the restaurant, took a right hand turn, and started walking the Venice Canals.Other people have posted pictures of the homes, and they are even nicer in person. It is a completely different area compared to Venice Beach which is just a few blocks away. Very serene, very nice place to walk off your meal, take a few pictures, and dream about having enough money to buy a vacation home here.If you are planning on visiting Venice Beach, take a few minutes of your day, and do the Venice Canals Walkway.

I'd say this area is one of the best parts of Venice, if not the best. It is a little more private and secluded than the beach homes which see a lot of foot traffic. The Venice canals were modeled after the canals in Venice, Italy. There used to be gondola rides but not any more. There are some very nice homes along these canals, ranging from modern to cottages. The Venice canals is a wonderful place to take a stroll. There are bridges connecting the streets so you can cross to the other side. This is also the cleanest part of Venice Beach. Lots of ducks hanging out.

column2: In Spring, take the kids to see the ducklings
column3: I lived on the canals for many years and I've visited several times since. Venice, CA was originally built as somewhat of a replica of Venice, Italy. The remaining canals are an almost hidden place to get away from the hubbub of Los Angeles. In this park-like setting, there are lots of fascinating houses but the ducks rule the canals. You can hear their sporadic quacking everywhere. In the Spring, the ducks and their ducklings calmly float up and down the waters of the canals. It's a nice place for a quiet, relaxing, leisurely stroll. Use Google to find out about the interesting history of Venice, California.

The canals were how Venice, CA got its name but today most are filled in with only a small section remaining that is hidden away but worth finding to see. Parking can also be a bit tricky but once you find the canals (my GPS, zoomed out, helped me locate the area) and a parking spot, you will find a unique scenic and photographic area with a lot of interesting architecture.

column2: Lots of culture, people and interesting sites
column3: Venice is certainly not Beverly Hills, so leave the high-end garb at home. Shorts, sneakers and t's are the only way to go in Venice.Take a stop at the sidewalk cafe for a snack--the plate of nachos is huge!
Nice place for an afternoon stroll, parking can be a little trickyinteresting architecture and scenery
Not a long walk (30-40 mins) but its quiet and relaxing. Seeing the beautiful houses and crossing the picturesque bridges is a treat.

column2: is not for family in the night
column3: is really good for young people,you find a lot of really good art. the only factor that is kind of freaky is that they offer you the service for marihuana so, if you have kids don't go there.

column2: historical canals hidden behind the crazy Venice boardwalk
column3: The boardwalk in Venice defines just part of the Bohemian air in Venice California. Another part of the split personality are the lovely historical canals that define the artistic (and expensive!!) neighborhoods above Washington Blvd. The beautiful restored or modernized homes bring such charm and character to this area. The canals have small boats sometimes resting within and you can find ducklings and frogs and other marsh animals hiding in between or under the bridges. Take a slow stroll and take your camera. Respect the neighbors, and make sure to walk the area in and around the canals so that you can get the full flavor and balance of what Venice, California is really like.

The homes and gardens at the canals are really beautiful. It's one of my favorite walks in L.A. Also, try to catch site of where the ducks live, and in the springtime you may catch site of some cute little ducklings!
try to tour at christmas time, when all the homes are decorated!
I love this area. Interesting homes and architecture. The best part for me is that there are many beautiful photography opportunities.
I was attracted to go to Venice Canals Walkway because I saw them on Californication. They don't look exactly the same (there was much less water than in the serios), but still very impressive!
Great place to walk and look at the fancy houses. It's like you are not in Los Angeles.

column2: Canals are nicer than the Venice boardwalk.
column3: The canals were a pleasant surprise in Venice. Unfortunately parking was very difficult and my husband kept the car running while I took pictures. We walked from Santa Monica pier to Venice Beach and after a few blocks turned around. to say Venice Beach was seedy would be kind.
If you've been to the real Venice canals than this place is a drag. Pretty much just regular houses surrounded by water, not really worth the walk.

Typically a has been site. Nice to see if you are passing by. But not a must. Just a nice relic from the past. Avoid when the tide is low. Venice is clearly less attractive than Santa Monica Beach or Manhattant Beach.

I wouldn't go out of your way to go here but if you are in the area it is a nice area to walk through and check out. The water level was very low when we were here but it was fun to walk though and check out the homes along this area.

My wife and I had an extra day in LA before taking a midnight flight to Tahitit/Bora Bora and we spent part of it in Venice Beach. Had we not read about the Canals Walkway on this site we would not likely have found or done it. It's only a couple of blocks off the beach but it is not well advertised. Once you find it's starting point on Washington, it's less than overwhelming. My wife and I almost elected to pass it was so unimpressive, but we are glad we started and continued on. It is a very pleasant 30-45 walk through a very interested series of canals, with some very nice homes, landscaping, etc. Well worth the time and a nice change of pace from the beach itself.

column2: If you can't get to Venice, Italy......
column3: Loved the quaintness, the quirkiness, and the quietness of the Venice Canals. Grab a bike and enjoy. Easily done on foot as well. A hidden gem in LA
Peaceful change from Venice Beach, lined with houses which are superbly unusual and colourful for LA

column2: Go, if you're in the area!
column3: A nice little stroll - an hour is enough. Great way to walk off a weekend lunch or a hot time at the beach. Cute homes, nice ambiance. Parking right at the canals is atrocious, so hopefully you've parked elsewhere and wandered in. You can also walk down the marina del rey side all the way to the marina jetty -- fun to watch the sailboats and yachts cruise in and out of the harbor - make sure you've got your walking shoes on for that!
Worth veering off and having a look if you're walking venice beach/santa monica walk
Nice to wander around for an hour. Does not deserve a long drive.
Nice place to see. 30 min is enought to see it all..
The canal itself is just OK but it is situated in a very lively nightlife area with a very young crowd. Parking is hard to find.

column2: Great leisurely walking away from the city!
column3: We spent about an hour strolling through the canals, enjoying a quiet morning. The homes are full of character, people are friendly, and it's fun to imagine living there!

column2: a wonderful retreat from the craziness of Venice beach
column3: This area makes a delightful break from the beach front. It is like stepping into another world. The houses and gardens that you pass by are full of colour and personality. From early C20th to cutting edge contemporary. There is even a recreation of an English Elizabethan cottage/hobbit dwelling ! Keen photographers have lots of opportunities for quaint character filled shots - with boats, moorings, canal reflections and garden gateways.

column2: Hidden and you'd never know it is there...
column3: I went for the first time after living here for a year, insane! How cozy to live in front of the little canals! A must visit :)
Beautiful beach and great people watching. There were a lot of tourists and not a lot of restaurants.

We walked to the Venice Canals and were pleasantly surprised. The streets are rivers with a pedestrian pavement on either side with homes facing the water. The rear of the homes have bitumen roads leading to private garages. There are some nice photo opportunities but that's about all. Overall, it was worth a look.
peace and tranquility of walk around canal and the houses by the canal and close but away from the hustle and bustle of the beach area

The canals in Venice Beach are a nice surprize. We live and Belmont Shore and walk through Naples in Long Beach all the time, so it was interesting to see the difference. There are no motor boats on these canals and they are very peaceful. Of course we like ours too!
Unexpected pleasant walk through scenic canals designed by Abbott Kinney many years ago. Great traditional homes and modern replacements.

Most people when visiting Venice head for the touristy and, in my opinion dirty and creepy, boardwalk but skip the canals. The canals are lovely and really what makes Venice Cali unique. Head over to Abbott Kinney and have a walk and a meal there-the food will be better! Then head over for a walk along the canals after and visit the ducks. You will be glad you did!
It is a shame that the government has made it impossible to provide generations with manmade wonders like the Venice canals.
These things may have once been pretty, but they're beyond their golden years. A decent stroll, but it seems a little seedy. Go eslewhere. Santa Monica is nicer.
It took us an hour to find it as we drove around the Venice Beach area (we should have started asking for directions after the first 15 minutes) but it was worth it.
Peaceful tranquillity and if archtecture is your thing then a great place for a slow long walk away from the exceses of venice beach.
Small canoes parked near the houses, great place for taking pictures early in the day or late afternoon, especially in spring, the flowers are wonderful.

column2: A Nice Way to Spend a Few Hours
column3: A nice way to spend a few hours on a breezy LA afternoon.
Seeing the varied architecture of the houses and the lovely gardens.
Most people who live here don't even go here to see the canals. They are hidden and something so special to walk through or drive over the bridges. I've never seen a more charming site.

column2: A fun place to walk around
column3: Great restaurants near by. Try the Gondola's. The houses and boats are amazing to see for free

column2: Great escape in the city.... excellent walking tour
column3: We come to Santa Monica and the LA area for vacation every year but this was the first time we spent time walking and driving around the Venice Canals.It's quite unique to see something like this in the area and it's beautiful and kids love walking on the bridges. Very serene and fun walking around and seeing the Canal and waterway and the homes.Beautiful birds and ducks around. Great for young kids. Definitely worth spending some time walking around before you hit the beaches which are only a few blocks over.

column2: a treasure island in a horrible car centred city
column3: The only place it seems that you can get away from the lonely gas guzzling society destroying cars. Small, intimate interesting and varied and you can walk all around the area. A great vision of the man who first set it up, what an effort it must have been, I am sure he would have had a lot of opposition to create such a dream? This area should be treasured and supported and more areas like them made for the future tourist to enjoy.
Not your typical sub-division. A quick way to escape from the housing norm and see broad range of creative solutions to the combination of a small plot of land and a bunch of money.
... particularly during the week when not likely to encounter anyone to disrupt a peaceful walk along these scenic waterways. Interesting houses and gardens. Very scenic.
beautiful to wander in the evening; I grew up near here and didn't even know this wonderful place existed.
We enjoyed the walkway while heading to the Venice beach.

column2: nice place for a long walk
column3: It's crazy that a developer cut all these canals in to sell his houses. Couldn't do that today unless in Dubai. Ducks wander freely. Cute little beach houses. I can walk around for hours.

column2: A tiny taste of Europe a few blocks from the beach
column3: If you are looking for a quiet stroll near the water and the crowds of Venice Beach are a bit too much, then head a few blocks inland to the Canals of Venice. The walkways next to the canals are peaceful and the neighborhood is lovely.

the view of these channels is very nice, beautifull houses and very relaxing atmosphere.if you stay at the Venice on the beach hotel you need just 5 minutes walk to reach this area.i do suggest to do this during the sunrise, take a lot of pics and share .just at the south end of the area there are some restaurants where you can end well your tour.
So fun to walk the canals. Seeing the homes is especially fun
Venice is always full of surprises, no matter what the season. That is probably due to the personalities of it's citizens. Try it - I think you'll like it!
past houses, cleaner than expected canals. Likely nice for the residents if there are quiet times without strangers walking by. Just a few houses to see and a little urban history to review.
The canals are a must see if you are anywhere near Venice Beach. The houses along them are absolutely beautiful and so unique. The best part is it's FREE to walk along there.
